Because of the intentions of the opposition, the bill will be divided in respect of items 38 to 40 of schedule 5. The question is that items 38 to 40 stand as printed.

termination time , in relation to special consent provisions, means the end of the period that is specified in the award under section 147 of the Principal Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 42 Exercise of Commission's powers under this Part

SPEECH.PARA: In exercising its powers under this Part, the Commission is to have regard to the desirability of assisting parties to awards to agree on appropriate variations to their awards, rather than have parts of awards cease to have effect under item 44 at the end of the interim period.

For the purposes of this Part, special consent provisions are provisions of an award that give effect to a decision of the Commission that is expressed to be made in accordance with one or more of the following principles:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Enterprise Bargaining Principle adopted by the Commission in the National Wage Case decision of October 1991 (Dec 1150/91, Print K0300);
(b) the Enterprise Awards Principle adopted by the Commission in its Review of the Wage Fixing Principles decision of October 1993 (Dec 1300/93, Print K9700);

(c) Principle 2.2 (Consent Award or Award Variation to Give Effect to an Enterprise Agreement), adopted by the Commission in its Review of the Wage Fixing Principles decision of August 1994 (Dec 1408/94, Print L4700) and incorporated without amendment in wages principles established by the Commission in its Safety Net Adjustment & Section 150A Review decision of October 1995 (Dec 2120/95. Print M5600).

PARA.EMPHASIS: 43 Variation of awards during the interim period

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If one or more of the parties to an award apply to the Commission for a variation of the award under this item, the Commission may, during the interim period, vary the award so that it only deals with allowable award matters.
(1A) For the purposes of this item, an exceptional matters order is taken to relate wholly to allowable award matters.
(1B) Special consent provisions cannot be varied under this item before the termination time for those provisions.

(2) The Commission may only deal with the application by arbitration if it is satisfied that the applicant or applicants have made reasonable attempts to reach agreement with the other parties to the award about how the award should be varied and the treatment of matters that are not allowable award matters.

PARA.TAB: (a) the award provides for rates of pay that, in the opinion of the Commission:

TAB.TAB: (i) are not operating as minimum rates; or
(ii) were made on the basis that they were not intended to operate as minimum rates; and

PARA.TAB: (b) the application under this item seeks to have such rates of pay varied so that they are expressed as minimum rates of pay;

SPEECH.PARA: the Commission may vary the award so that it provides for minimum rates of pay consistent with sections 88A and 88B of the Principal Act and the limitation on the Commission's power in subsection 89A(3) of that Act.

(4) If the Commission varies the award under subitem (3), it must include in the award provisions that ensure that overall entitlements to pay provided by the award are not reduced by that variation, unless the Commission considers that it would be in the public interest not to include such provisions.
(5) The Commission must, if it considers it appropriate, review the award to determine whether or not it meets the following criteria:

PARA.TAB: (a) it does not include matters of detail or process that are more appropriately dealt with by agreement at the workplace or enterprise level;
(b) it does not prescribe work practices or procedures that restrict or hinder the efficient performance of work;
(c) it does not contain provisions that have the effect of restricting or hindering productivity, having regard to fairness to employees.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) The Commission must also review the award to determine whether or not it meets the following criteria:

PARA.TAB: (a) where appropriate, it contains facilitative provisions that allow agreement at the workplace or enterprise level, between employers and employees (including individual employees), on how the award provisions are to apply;
(aa) where appropriate, it contains provisions enabling the employment of regular part-time employees; and
(b) it is expressed in plain English and is easy to understand in both structure and content;
(c) it does not contain provisions that are obsolete or that need updating;
(d) where appropriate, it provides support to training arrangements through appropriate trainee wages and a supported wage system for people with disabilities;

(e) it does not contain provisions that discriminate against an employee because of, or for reasons including, race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin.

SPEECH.PARA: (7) If the Commission determines that the award does not meet the criteria set out in subitem (5) or (6), the Commission may take whatever steps it considers appropriate to facilitate the variation of the award so that it does meet those criteria.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 44 Parts of awards cease to have effect at the end of the interim period

SPEECH.PARA: (1) At the end of the interim period, each award ceases to have effect to the extent that it provides for matters other than allowable award matters.
(2) For the purposes of this item, an exceptional matters order is taken to relate wholly to allowable award matters.
(2A) For the purposes of this item, an award that is made under subsection 170MX(3) of the Principal Act is taken to provide wholly for allowable award matters.

(3) If the termination time for special consent provisions is after the end of the interim period, then this item and item 45 apply to the special consent provisions as if a reference to the end of the interim period were instead a reference to the termination time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 45 Variation of awards after the end of the interim period

SPEECH.PARA: (1) As soon as practicable after the end of the interim period, the Commission must review each award:

PARA.TAB: (a) that is in force; and
(b) that the Commission is satisfied has been affected by item 44.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Commission must vary the award to remove provisions that ceased to have effect under item 44.

(3) When varying the award under subitem (2), the Commission may also vary the award so that, in relation to an allowable award matter, the award is expressed in a way that reasonably represents the entitlements of employees in respect of that matter as provided in the award as in force immediately before the end of the interim period.
(4) If, immediately before the end of the interim period, the award provided for rates of pay that, in the opinion of the Commission:

PARA.TAB: (a) were not operating as minimum rates of pay; or
(b) were made on the basis that they were not intended to operate as minimum rates;

SPEECH.PARA: the Commission may vary the award so that it provides for minimum rates of pay consistent with sections 88A and 88B of the Principal Act and the limitation on the Commission's power in subsection 89A(3) of that Act.

(5) If the Commission varies the award under subitem (4), it must include in the award provisions that ensure that overall entitlements to pay provided by the award are not reduced by that variation, unless the Commission considers that it would be in the public interest not to include such provisions.
(6) The Commission must, if it considers it appropriate, review the award to determine whether or not it meets the following criteria:

PARA.TAB: (a) it does not include matters of detail or process that are more appropriately dealt with by agreement at the workplace or enterprise level;
(b) it does not prescribe work practices or procedures that restrict or hinder the efficient performance of work;
(c) it does not contain provisions that have the effect of restricting or hindering productivity, having regard to fairness to employees.

SPEECH.PARA: (7) The Commission must also review the award to determine whether or not it meets the following criteria:

PARA.TAB: (a) where appropriate, it contains facilitative provisions that allow agreement at the workplace or enterprise level, between employers and employees (including individual employees), on how the award provisions are to apply;
(aa) where appropriate, it contains provisions enabling the employment of regular part-time employees; and
(b) it is expressed in plain English and is easy to understand in both structure and content;
(c) it does not contain provisions that are obsolete or that need updating;
(d) where appropriate, it provides support to training arrangements through appropriate trainee wages and a supported wage system for people with disabilities;

(e) it does not contain provisions that discriminate against an employee because of, or for reasons including, race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin.

SPEECH.PARA: (8) If the Commission determines that the award does not meet the criteria set out in subitem (6) or (7), the Commission may take whatever steps it considers appropriate to facilitate the variation of the award so that it does meet those criteria.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 45A Corporations not bound by State awards

PARA.TAB: (a) a constitutional corporation is bound by an award in respect of an employee; and
(b) the award is varied under subitem 43(1) or wholly or partly ceases to have effect because of item 44; and

(c) as a result of the award being varied, or ceasing to have effect, as mentioned in paragraph (b), the corporation would (apart from this item) become bound by a State award in respect of the employee;

SPEECH.PARA: then the corporation is not bound by the State award in relation to the employee unless it becomes bound as a result of an application by the corporation to the relevant State industrial authority.
(2) Subitem (1) does not operate so that a State award, or part of a State award, prevails over an award of the Commission.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 46 Matters to be dealt with by Full Bench

SPEECH.PARA: (1) After the commencement of this Part, a Full Bench may establish principles about varying awards under this Part.
(2) After such principles (if any) have been established, the power of the Commission to vary an award under this Part is exercisable only by a Full Bench unless the contents of the award:

PARA.TAB: (a) give effect to determinations of a Full Bench under this Part; or
(b) are consistent with principles established by a Full Bench under this item.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A provision of an award does not discriminate against an employee for the purposes of paragraph 43(6)(e) or 45(7)(e) merely because:

PARA.TAB: (a) it provides for a junior rate of pay; or
(b) it discriminates, in respect of particular employment, on the basis of the inherent requirements of that employment; or
(c) it discriminates, in respect of employment as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with the teachings or beliefs of a particular religion or creed:

TAB.TAB: (i) on the basis of those teachings or beliefs; and
(ii) in good faith.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Paragraph (1)(a) does not apply to a decision or determination made by the Commission made under this Part more than 3 years after 22 June 1997, except where the Commission decides, on a case-by-case basis, that the paragraph should apply. Decisions by the Commission as to whether the paragraph should apply must be made by the Commission in accordance with principles established by a Full Bench.
The repeal of subsection 111(1A) of the Principal Act does not apply to any proceedings before the Commission that commenced before the commencement of the repeal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage, I just indicate the approach of the opposition for the remainder of this bill. In order to facilitate the timetable, considering where we are in the debate in the committee stage on the industrial relations legislation, on behalf of the Labor opposition I will be reading for two or three minutes our position on the entire schedule and then tabling and incorporating our comments at the beginning of each schedule on all of the amendments that we are proposing.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be some contributions from my Senate colleagues on a number of the amendments as we move through. We are conscious of the enormous program before the Senate and, in order to facilitate the conclusion of the debate, we do believe that this will be improved significantly by a responsible approach.

With respect to the remainder of schedule 5 awards, the transitional provisions are the provisions which demonstrate the greatest breach of promise by Mr Howard. Mr Howard said that no worker would be worse off under this industrial relations policy. Even more explicitly, on 6 October, he told the Freight Congress:
. . . no worker in Australia under the Howard industrial relations policy can have his or her award conditions taken away.

This is precisely what these transitional provisions do. In 18 months time, all award conditions outside the 20 allowable matters or any exceptional matters will be abolished by these provisions. Employees will have to bargain during that period just to preserve their existing entitlements. Where this is not achieved, employees will lose entitlements and will be unambiguously worse off.
We are very surprised that the Democrats have agreed to these provisions. Senator Murray, in his Senate report on page 333, said:

The Government's `sudden death' solution of deleting a wide range of award conditions in 18 months would breach the clear commitment of the Prime Minister in the lead up to the election when he clearly stated that . . .
Senator Murray then quoted Mr Howard in the Freight Congress speech. Now we see the Democrats actively supporting the government in breaching this commitment.

So we oppose the transitional provisions outright. The sudden death approach to award simplification is wrong—the commission should be allowed to continue its job of simplifying awards. Given the change in the Democrats' position about this matter, we are not hopeful of succeeding in repealing the transitional provisions.

We have circulated two amendments to the transitional provisions which I would call on the Democrats to support. The first, on sheet 226, ensures that existing paid rates awards are not subject to the sudden death award simplification process. Given Senator Murray's comments about the harshness of that solution and the Democrats' alleged commitment to workers who rely on paid rates awards—like nurses and teachers—I would be surprised is the Democrats do not support this amendment. If Senator Murray says that the provisions he has agreed to will do this anyway, he is incorrect. As drafted, the only paid rates awards exempted from the transitional provisions are those made in future under section 170MX(3).

The second amendment, on sheet 227, provides that consent awards are not subject to the sudden death solution. The deal provides that this is the case during the period the award was stated to be in effect. But consent awards continue in effect beyond that time, and should be free from award simplification for their effective life, not just their normal life.

Again, I call on the Democrats to join with us in protecting the interests of all those employees, particularly those in the retail sector, who work under consent awards and who do not deserve to be worse off as a result of this legislation.
I have another two pages of comments relating to the remaining provisions of this schedule that I seek to incorporate in the Hansard. I will not be making any further comments on this schedule.
Leave granted.

Whilst the Opposition recognises that the Government/Democrat deal improves the transitional provisions in some respects when compared to the provisions in the original bill, we remain fundamentally opposed to the transitional provisions and will vote against this amendment.

Paid rates awards is defined by reference to the new definition provided in section 170LG of the Principal Act which is certainly broad enough to pick up all existing paid rates awards. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on the government-Democrat amendment No. 30. The opposition has put forward this amendment in an attempt to rectify what we see as a serious flaw in the government-Democrat agreement and the amendments that have arisen from it. Whilst I would very dearly like to make further comments with respect to the sudden death award simplification process, I will confine myself to what I call the sudden death consent award process.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry referred to the problem for vast numbers of retail industry employees covered by consent awards who, if amendment No. 30 goes ahead, will still be penalised because they entered into the enterprise bargaining process early by general industry standards and they undertook the choice—often the employer's choice—to ratify an enterprise bargaining agreement as a consent award rather than as a certified agreement.

In relation to these consent awards there are two problems. With the proposed legislative regime, consent awards will not continue. In the future there will be no such thing as a consent award. One of the problems faced by workers currently covered by consent awards is included in amendment No. 30 as it stands. Only one of the problems highlighted during our inquiry has been rectified and another one has not.

The first of the problems was, under the original bill, those awards could be simplified by the sudden death provisions within 18 months despite the term of the agreement. In some cases the term of the agreement is around four years. Amendment No. 30 has dealt with that problem and introduced a provision which says, essentially, that for those workers their agreement cannot be reduced until the term of the agreement expires.

There is a fundamental problem which is going to be faced by retail workers—many of whom are not in a great bargaining position and are young women who face large corporations such as Coles Myers. At the expiry time, they are going to be at a significant disadvantage because, unlike certified agreements, the employer can allow the agreement to be minimised as would any award.

Senator Murray would recall that there are many provisions included in these consent awards which may not come under allowable matters even though they have been improved to some extent with the agreement between the Democrats and the government. They include things such as health and safety provisions, rostered day off provisions and provisions for part-time workers in the retail industry which provide protection—they will no longer be allowable matters under awards.

I would like to remind Senator Murray of one of those—and there was clear evidence of this put before the committee—that is, the case of part-time workers in the retail industry being worked for 37 hours per week so that their employer could avoid the obligation of providing a rostered day off. Protections against those sorts of things will not survive in these consent awards once the nominal expiry date has been reached. The opposition's amendment No. 30 seeks to address this problem.

I would like to acknowledge that, arising out of the committee inquiry process, Senator Murray for the Democrats supported the general principle that agreements should not be terminated at their expiry time and should continue. The majority of the committee found that `it was far more orderly and convenient for agreements once made to continue until amended by later agreement or by order of the commission'. This will not be the case with respect to current consent awards. They will be able to be reduced down to 20 allowable matters.

I commend the Democrats for their success with the government in rectifying the situation in relation to certified agreements, but I call on the Democrats to support the opposition in relation to consent awards, which are essentially the same as certified agreements. I challenge some people to go back and look at some of the transcripts for the arguments put in cases before the commission that awards should be processed as consent awards. In many cases it was the employer's choice that they be consent awards rather than certified agreements.

I would like to highlight the magnitude that this seemingly small problem will have for some of Australia's largest industries and largest employers—and these were included in the SDA's submission in appendix I—that are currently under consent awards, which will be able to be minimised even under amendment No. 30 at their nominal expiry date. I refer to companies like BBC Hardware, Bi‐Lo, Coles supermarkets, Dulux, McDonalds, Franklins, Harris Scarse Ltd, KFC, K-Mart, Myer Grace Bros., Pizza Haven, Pizza Hut, Safeway, Harry Heaths, Hungry Jacks, Target, Woolworths and World 4 Kids.

Think of how many people are employed by these companies and ask yourselves: why has this agreement between the government and the Democrats allowed discrimination against these workers who are often not powerful, disadvantaged in a bargaining sense, young, generally women and employed on a part-time casual basis? Why are they being disadvantaged in their bargaining position?

Now, in relation to some of the other amendments, I have heard some interesting excuses as to why we could not have equal remuneration, rather than equal pay, and why we could not deal with the particular problems in respect to outworkers in regard to right of entry and how the additional matter in the 20 allowable matters will mean very little if the union cannot not get right of entry to the distributors in the textile, clothing and footwear industry. I am interested to hear what the excuse is for clearly dealing only with part of the problem.

Consent rewards, which reflect enterprise bargaining agreements, will be able to be reduced to 20 allowable matter type awards at the expiry date of the agreement. So unlike those workers under certified agreements, these workers will face the reduction of their agreement at the end of its term.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told, Senator Sherry, that you have a number of amendments to amendment No. 30.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to seek the leave of the committee of the whole to incorporate my notes on government‐Democrat amendment No. 30.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
GOVT/DEM 30

The new transitional arrangements differ from the old in several respects. It allows for consent awards made under enterprise bargaining principles to continue to their expiry. It allows for exceptional matters order. It amended items 43, 44 and 45 to provide more protection of paid rates employees. It adds two new criteria to the award simplification process. It adds a new item 45A in relation to the State awards. It adds a new item dealing with junior rates, 47(2). It allows the completion of Victorian 111(1A) applications. And, it amends item 43 to make it clear that employers must seek to reach agreement on the treatment of non-allowable matters before seeking to amend their awards.
I commend these amendments to the Senate.

What I want to talk about is in more general terms the award simplification process. The Democrats strongly support the maintenance of the award system. It is a system which, when running well, suits both employees and employers, particularly small employers, in providing a ready reference as to the state of the labour market.

But awards are immensely cumbersome documents. It is difficult to ask a small business employer to ensure that everything they do complies with a badly written 70 page commentary as many awards are. Badly written because each word has been haggled over and negated over decades. For almost a decade now, the AIRC has been trying to simplify and modernise awards. But, the AIRC has found it is much easier to put a clause in than to take a clause out, even a clause which has long outlived its usefulness.

The Democrats believe that to maintain support for the award system, it is essential that the award system be user friendly. The situation we have at present where there is probably hardly a small business employer in the country not in technical breach of at least some overprescriptive award clause, even if they are trying to do the right thing, is ludicrous. It is crucial, basic politics. Based on independent legal advice, we have been persuaded that the list of allowable matters as amended picks up all of the important industrial conditions. This, then should form the basis for an accelerated and more effective award simplification process.

However, there must be protections within that process. The object of this process is not to eliminate conditions, but to produce workable, effective documents that protect employees conditions but without placing excessive restrictions on employers. Five years into enterprise bargaining, as part of the evolution of the industrial relations system, now I believe is the appropriate time to review the award provisions.

As I said, we have sought to ensure that employees are protected. We have done this in several ways. First, item 43 makes it clear that the Commission cannot proceed to arbitrate on non-allowable matters until the applicant has made reasonable attempts to get agreement on both the award matter and the treatment or future regulation of the matter.
Second, we have introduced the exceptional matters orders system to ensure that conditions that protect employees from harsh or unjust conditions can be retained.
Third, we have protections for paid rates workers, not just in the terms of their rates in items 43 and 45, but also in expanded access to arbitration under 170MX.

In short, we are persuaded that this transitional schedule offer the prospect of awards being reshaped around what independent experts tell us are the real core of the employment relationship in allowable matters, while ensuring that any other matters cannot be taken away unless the employee agrees or the Commission determined it would not be harsh or unjust. That, in our view, is a fair outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to hear a government response to the matters that have been raised by Senator Sherry and Senator Collins. It is a very serious question indeed. The government is rather silent and I would like to hear its response, particularly in regard to those matters raised here on behalf of the retail employees by Senator Collins, the chair of the committee which investigated this matter thoroughly. It has been pointed out that there is a discrepancy, entailing clear discrimination against those employees who are currently covered by consent awards, as distinct from certified agreements. It just does not make sense to me for such discrimination to be allowed to be included in the final piece of legislation. So I would like to have the government explain to the committee why it would not agree to an amendment which would then exclude that discrimination which is going to be felt by quite a large number of those amongst the most vulnerable of employees.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had said that he wanted to see a situation in which no employee would be worse‐off as a result of this legislation. Here we have the potential for hundreds of thousands of employees to be worse‐off. We heard the government say over the weekend that it was concerned about low‐paid employees. Well, here we have a large number of employees who are low‐paid but they also have some fairly reasonable protection as a result of the consent awards that have been negotiated between the union concerned, the association and the employers.

As Senator Collins has pointed out, the decision to go along the consent‐award track—rather than the certified‐agreement track—has often been determined by the wish of the employer concerned. Now we find that the government is not agreeing to an amendment that would cover that situation. I would like to hear why it is determined not to accept a reasonable proposition which would eliminate that sort of discrimination—just because an employee is now under a consent award, he or she would be discriminated against compared with the employees who are under a certified agreement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry, Mr Chairman, for the delay. I was just taking some advice. On the concerns raised by honourable senators, my advice is that certified agreements and con sent awards are not entirely analogous. In the transitional period, parties can of course renegotiate consent awards as certified agreements. Where any unfairness does occur, the parties will of course have access to the exceptional matters orders. They are the government's main detailed responses to the concerns raised. The government's position, as made clear by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Industrial relations (Mr Reith), is that we want to make sure that no‐one is worse off, and that, indeed, the conditions of employment for Australian workers, particularly low paid workers, improve as a result of this law. We believe the provisions of this act, as amended by the amendment we are debating at the moment, will ensure that is the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to that, I think at least for the record I need to highlight and challenge what is obviously the department's advice that consent orders are not entirely analogous to certified agreements, because in some cases they are. I would challenge the officers of the department to actually review some of the transcripts of hearings of matters which determined whether it was possible to proceed with an enterprise bargaining agreement under an application as a consent award. That sort of review would highlight that in some cases there is very little difference, apart from the fact of the past award coverage and the employer's preference. In some cases it may even just go down to the fact of the employer's preference.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense, the approach that the commission took is that where the parties came together to the commission with an enterprise agreement and generally indicated that it was their preference that it be a consent award rather than a certified agreement, that is basically what happened. These are the people that are now going to be penalised. I heard the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) say last week that the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 was about agreement making. Why are we penalising those people who, several years ago, were busy agreement making? It is simply being done under what I would say is poor departmental advice that they are not entirely analogous. I am sorry: that excuse is not good enough.

Apart from that, the further explanation which Senator Campbell gave—that there can be a negotiation process over the period of time—ignores the logic that the Democrats argued about why certified agreements should not be able to be terminated at their expiry date. The same logic, I am afraid, applies to consent awards. I am interested, however, in Senator Campbell's comments about unfairness: that if there is unfairness, the parties can rely on the exceptional matters. I must say that this is the first occasion on which I have heard any description of any particular circumstance which might fit into an exceptional matter. I am pleased to hear that much at least, but I still must say that it is not good enough.

The Democrats have not responded to several requests in regard to this matter. I would have to say it will essentially be on their heads that up to 200,000 retail workers will be seriously disadvantaged in their negotiating position when they face their boss and their boss says, `Why should I? Why should I bother? If I just do nothing I can have all of these conditions removed.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

I would like to ask the Democrats what is wrong with in some way deeming consent awards for the purposes of their continued operation to be certified agreements? A number of employers have suggested that that should be in the form of an award rather than a certified agreement. It seems to me strange that, by not agreeing to this amendment, the Australian Democrats may be proceeding against their preferred position.

I am just wondering whether Senator Murray could enlighten the committee on the Democrats' views on this matter. I know that we agreed to allow Senator Murray's comments to be tabled, but I would like to hear verbally and in person his views on the matters that have been raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —So far every call we have made to the Australian Democrats to support us in improving this bill and in improving the lot of employees affected has regrettably fallen on deaf ears. This time I am again calling on the Democrats to support us in providing a measure of protection for independent contractors. These are small business people, vital to the economy of Australia, who need a range of protections.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will be aware that the bill repeals provisions in the existing act which give some protection to independent contractors. Independent contractors are becoming more and more common, especially in the building industry and the transport industry, but we are seeing the spread of the independent contract sector into other areas that have not been regarded as traditional.

As employers require their workers to incorporate and offer their services not as employees but as independent contractors they are invariably in a very weak bargaining position and need additional protections. We are opposed to the repeal of these existing provisions which permit the court to review contracts with independent contractors and to make orders relieving them of unfair contracts. These at very least provide an incentive to employers contracting with these people to do so on a fair basis.

We are opposed to the repeal of the existing provisions which permit independent contractors to bring proceedings for the imposition of a penalty or for the recovery of wages under the act. Employees are able to bring these proceedings under the act and independent contractors who are, in substance, employees should have the same rights.

But the need for protection of independent contractors does not end there. It has been brought to our attention, and I am sure to the attention of the government and Democrats, that independent contractors who bargain collectively, including by union representation, are at risk of being prosecuted under the collusive bargaining provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

Many independent contractors are forced to incorporate. They should have the right to bargain collectively without being caught up by these collusive conduct provisions. The opposition is therefore seeking to insert a new provision into the Trade Practices Act which ensures that contracts which are wholly or principally for the performance of work—that is, the contracts of independent contractors—are not subject to the collusive bargaining provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Thus, independent contractors who bargain collectively will not be open to penalty under the Trade Practices Act.

We call on the Democrats to give thoughtful consideration to this amendment. We call on the government to do the same. Help us redress the bargaining imbalance between independent contractors and those who seek their services. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech notes read as follows—

The Opposition opposes the repeal of the provisions which permitted the Court to review contracts with independent contractors and to make appropriate orders. The Opposition also opposes the repeal of the capacity of independent contractors to bring proceedings for the imposition of a penalty or for the recovery of wages under the Act. These amendments seek to omit these repeals.
I have already explained why the Opposition opposes the repeal of these provisions.

These amendments insert into the Trade Practices Act a definition of contract of service which "includes any contract or agreement which is wholly or principally for the performance of work by one party to the contract". This definition is wide enough to pick up contracts of the nature entered into by independent contractors. The effect of the new definition is to exclude these contracts from the definition of services in the Act, and therefore from the prohibitions in the Act on various practices (especially collusive conduct) relating to the provision of services.
Thus, independent contractors who bargain collectively cannot be penalised under the Trade Practices Act.

This amendment opposes Schedule 6. If Opp (62) and (63) are not agreed to, the Opposition supports this amendment for the reasons stated in relation to Opp (57), (58)-(61) and (64). If Opp (62) and (63) are agreed to, the Opposition opposes this amendment to the extent that it would repeal Schedule 6 as amended by Opp (62) and (63).

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (57) Schedule 6, Part 1, page 40 (line 4), omit " Workplace Relations Act 1996"

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Schedule 6 repeals the provisions incorporating the 1993 Industrial Relations Reform Act which allows the industrial relations court to deal with a limited range of unfair contract disputes, particularly in relation to the review by the court of a contract for the performance of work by an independent contractor on the grounds that it is harsh or unfair.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing provisions are important. They are important to prevent exploitation of individuals in circumstances where their status as an independent contractor is used by the employer to avoid obligations which would otherwise arise under an award. It is not good enough to put people on a contract just to limit wages and conditions and there certainly seems to be evidence that this is happening in Western Australia.

In relation to the opposition's moves to oppose items 1 to 4, you will notice that it is the same as the Greens, who would certainly be supporting that. We will certainly be supporting an alternative definition of `contract of services', as with the opposition's amendments 62 and 63, which effectively states `includes any contract or agreement which is wholly or principally for the performance of work by one party to the contract'. We fully support the ALP amendments in that regard.

The issue of contracting as opposed to employing is going to become more prevalent and we should all be ensuring some form of protection in this bill for workers under contracts of services. In this instance the Democrats do not have any amendments to this schedule and their position is unclear. It would be very good to get clarification of whether or not the issues that have come up in relation to contractors have been taken into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will support the Labor Party's amendment 57 on independent contractors. The Democrats supported the inclusion of provisions in the IR Act in 1992 to protect independent contractors against unfair contracts. This is a growing sector of the work force as increasingly employers convert employees, often in our view against their will, into so-called contractors in an effort to reduce costs.

SPEECH.PARA: One way of reducing costs by employers by moving employees to contractors is to avoid payment of PAYE tax. If a contractor is regarded as a business person, they fall under PPS or provisional tax, not PAYE, and that saves the employers but costs the taxpayers. I am surprised that this government and Treasurer Costello with his commitment not to stand by and see the tax system riddled and rorted has not cracked down on tax avoidance by employers forcing employees to become contractors. In seeking to abolish these provisions, the government is effectively sanctioning employers to continue to undertake these conversions by not only allowing tax avoidance to grow but by insulating employers from action by contractors for unfair contracts other than by under the very strict and difficult regime of the common law.

I am also surprised that the coalition is opposed to the retention of these provisions given they are largely modelled on the jurisdiction against unfair contracts introduced by the Greiner conservative government in New South Wales in 1991 and by the very conservative Bjelke‐Petersen government in 1988. The existence of provisions in industrial law to provide some protection to independent contractors is not therefore unusual.

The provisions in the IR Act in our view have not been as helpful as we had hoped. Since 1992 there have only been a handful of cases, maybe 20, under these provisions. That is hardly great comfort to the hundreds of thousands of workers now on contracts, most of them forced.

In my supplementary report on the Senate inquiry I propose an alternative approach of moving the prohibition against unfair contracts to the Trade Practices Act, providing for industry codes of practice, a small claims procedure and the implementation of unconscionable conduct provisions. These sorts of provisions have worked very effectively for other small businesses such as the motor trades. Again I was disappointed that the coalition is not prepared to match its rhetoric and treat independent contractors as small businesses needing appropriate protection—that is, if they refuse to regard them as employees under the Industrial Relations Act.

The Democrats believe that our proposal offered more protection than that provided by the cumbersome, high cost and legally difficult provisions in this act. We intend continuing to pursue those changes in the Trade Practices Act. In the interim we will vote to retain the current provisions, ensuring that independent contractors at least are afforded some legal protection from unfair contracts. For those reasons, we will be supporting the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the opposition's amendment which opposes and deletes the repeal of the proposed section put forward by the coalition. The difficulties these provisions present to the thousands of contractors in industry, whether it be construction or transport, are quite obvious.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I welcome the Australian Democrats' support for this amendment, this amendment is not enough in itself to protect these independent contractors; it does need to go further. Subsequent opposition amendments to schedule 6 provide for the necessary support and will put in place the necessary mechanisms to make that protection complete and unambiguous. Whilst it is a very positive move to retain these provisions in the current bill, there will still remain some ambiguity.

I want to make reference specifically to some of the concerns and issues in industry. There is a push, certainly from many large employers—sometimes in specific sectors in industry; others more generally—to force on to contracts independent contractors who would by general definition in fact be employees.

It is acknowledged certainly by workers' representatives and unions in industry that the current provisions under 127A, 127B and 127C are in fact quite complex and do not go far enough in providing the necessary protection to those workers. The pressure is not going away and there are going to be more and more problems facing independent contractors in these areas.

The so-called enterprise that establishes them, basically under duress by employers, is really starting to change the nature of industry. It certainly has been noted that in the construction industry this transition from employees to independent contractors over a long period of time—but gathering momentum more recently—will really change the way in which those workers are capable of maintaining a reasonable income and a fair and a living wage.

One example of this is what is happening in the housing sector of the construction industry. I would like to ask the government what advice specifically they took from the Housing Industry Association on the repeal of the unfair contracts provision. I would like to refer to a letter from Clarendon Homes that demands all subcontractors become proprietary limited companies. Clarendon Homes say that subcontractors should set up their own companies to `avoid union interference in the subcontract system'. In a 1991 letter, Clarendon offered to help workers set up their companies. Clarendon said:

We have approached a firm which specialises in the setting up of companies and secured a discounted rate of about $700 per company. You can choose your own name for your company for an extra $50. To help with the cost of setting up, Clarendon will deduct from your contract payment the $700 in three equal instalments.
How does the company explain this to the workers they are forcing to become companies? They say:
Now I know you are all grumbling and saying, `Why should I?' But remember, this is union driven and we don't have any choice; it must happen.
Do they give subcontractors any choice in the matter? On this issue they say:

To make sure you continue to receive regular work from us you will have to become a proprietary limited company by 15 December 1992. Our supervisors will not be able to give any work to subcontractors who are not in the company structure after that date.

What sort of contract can building subcontractors be expected to sign? It just so happens that I have an example here. For $18 per hour the subcontractor gets no rostered days off, no travel allowance, no payment for public holidays, no annual leave, no sick leave, no wet weather allowance, no picnic days, no superannuation and the subcontractor must supply his or her own tools and equipment, including light power tools, to carry out and complete the said works. Is that fair?

Does the Industrial Relations Act, with all these coalition amendments, render it possible for people to seek adequate redress? No. Even the retention of 127A, 127B and 127C, as this amendment puts forward, is not going to be enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not enough.

—It is not going to be enough. The amendments the opposition has proposed with respect to independent contractors form a package that will remove this outstanding ambiguity. The amendments will provide adequate redress for a growing group of workers who are under extreme pressure, as I have just described, to change the way they earn their living. More responsibility is being placed on them although they are still employees. This is acknowledged by Clarendon in the example I have just provided. Clarendon acknowledges the fact that they retain the liability for workers compensation. Their contract states, `We agree to pay your workers compensation policy.' That definition of employees under workers compensation has been a crucial one in the never ending dispute and saga with respect to independent contractors and it provides a clear insight into this government's agenda with respect to independent contractors.

SPEECH.PARA: The issues that Senator Murray raised with respect to a transition from the PAYE tax system to PPS have in themselves another set of outcomes or results that are certainly quite serious in that they go to the heart of addressing the revenue base and the way people earn their money. How effective in application will this workplace relations be when you put in place a 20‐allowable‐matters award yet the coalition's amendments with respect to independent contractors really promote a drive away from even being covered by an award at all?

I believe that the support for this opposition amendment is one step towards addressing the specific needs of independent contractors—the ones that are bona fide. But it also goes right to the heart of specifically addressing the needs of independent contractors who have been forced into that position by virtue of threat or blackmail from their employers that they will not receive work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the comments made by Senator Lundy in relation to these issues. What has become clear here is that the Australian Democrats are supporting the repeal of sections 127A, B and C, but that, in fact, is that dotted line which never gets passed amongst all the Democrat‐government amendments—that is, even getting close to existing provisions. Things are changing anyway and we are beginning to see that there is the need to address collusive conduct in relation to private individual contractors. Therefore, it is absolutely essential that we as a chamber deal with this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly there is no crossing of the dotted line. Many of the provisions in the bill are getting worse but, in this particular case, there is no intention at all to address some of the real problems that exist in the workplace and to improve them. Let it not be said at the end of this bill that there has been anything in the Democrat‐government amendments which has gone to improving the lot for workers, because the very most that has happened, as we have seen here, is that some of the existing provisions have been retained but not improved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to rise to support Senator Lundy's comments. I see that Senator Murray has not said anything or attempted to respond yet, and I hope that he will respond.
—He has already spoken.

—I hope he will respond further to the points that Senator Lundy has made. He has to accept that, in the report that the Australian Democrats brought down, under the heading `Vulnerable Employees,' this was the recommendation that the Democrats put in:

SPEECH.PARA: Independent contractors: That the Government give consideration to establishing a new low cost dispute resolution procedure for unfair contracts under the Trade Practices Act, based on the New South Wales model,
in preference to the current regulation under the Industrial Relations Act.

Where are they, Senator Murray? Where are they? The sort of example that Senator Lundy just read out to you is commonplace in the transport industry. What we are doing today is an improvement on what the conservatives wanted. But what about the very points you made in your speech? You said that the Bjelke-Petersen government and the Greiner government were both prepared to accept what we referred to in the transport industry as contract determination.

Where are your amendments that you were negotiating and you were promising? You have given every indication up until the last few weeks that you were prepared to talk about doing it. You led people up the garden path. People thought that they were going to get a chance. You knew that you had our support and that we could put it into the legislation now. You are the one who has backed away and given in to the coalition on this.

As you correctly say, the conservatives in New South Wales and Queensland were prepared to accept this, and they were not notably progressive on these issues. What you are agreeing to is something that is less than Joh Bjelke-Petersen was prepared to accept. That is what you need to think about when we call the division in a minute and we are over that side and you are staying where you are. That is what you need.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Could I correct the record. Senator Conroy might not have heard that we are actually supporting the opposition on this amendment.

—I have and we welcome that you are finally going to come to the party on one division. You can all come and join us. We welcome that. I accept that. What I want to hear from you if you want to get to your feet again is where the amendments that you promised in your report are. Where are they? There are a lot of people in the transport industry and building industry that were hoping that you were going to keep your word on that and come to the party on what you suggested in the report.

BREAK.PARA: In the transport industry you have examples of people who are forced to accept contracts to drive from Dandenong to Geelong to deliver a package for $4. If they are not prepared to accept that as part of their conditions, they get no work. By your going to water, that is the sort of impact that people in the transport industry are now faced with. That is prevalent. It riddles the courier industry in Victoria—and, I am sure, around the country.

The coalition have quite a specific agenda on this. They are interested in seeing a weakening of the tax base. They want to see that transferred because it is going to open the doors for them to bring in their GST. That is what it is going to mean. That is what they are about. This was a chance for us to put a plug in it and stop that movement away from PAYE. That is what they want to do. They want to introduce the GST. They want to undermine the existing tax base.

This was our chance to really do something about it. We were ready to stand with you opposed to the coalition on this and support your further amendments that you indicated in your report you were prepared to make. When you vote with us today on 127A that will be good, but we will be interested in pursuing a reference next year. We both know that they will never accept it in the House of Representatives. This was the only chance we had to get it accepted in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few things about this. I am glad to see Senator Murray is supporting the opposition and the Greens (WA) on this. I think when he does support us we ought to give him some thanks for that, because he has been getting a fair deal of stick, if I can use that expression, Senator Murray, and they are often difficult decisions to make.

SPEECH.PARA: Listening to what Senator Lundy and Senator Conroy said, this is one of the big issues in this legislation. It is a problem that has been growing for years. There are cases such as the Odco case. That was a very prominent case and one you will remember. May I say just as a passing reference that it was the first case my son, Sean, ever instructed in. It was wrong, because he was on the losing side. I always thought the bench was a bit astray there.

I understand the government's position on this. This legislation moves further along the line of industrial legislation in this country being supported more by provisions in the constitution other than that which refers to the settlement of interstate disputes. For example, it relies more on the corporations power. If you were to give independent contractors—they are vulnerable, for the reasons that have been given already—protection under this act, would that not be more consistent with the underlying constitutional bases this act will now have than has previously been the case? In other words, would not giving protection to independent contractors be more consistent with the way this act is going?

Why is the government not taking this opportunity that is now presented to it by shifting to new bases for the legislation to look after independent contractors, who in very many cases are in identical positions to that of employees—except for very fine lines drawn, usually as a matter of evidence, trying to distinguish between employees and independent contractors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to a couple of points and will keep my comments as brief as I can. Firstly, I refer to the question Senator Cooney raised. On the workplace relations bill—I took advice on this, it seems like a few months ago—Senator Cook raised a question about the heads of power the bill relied on. I do not want to encourage Senator Cook to come back and have a debate on this, but he did agree with me privately that, indeed, the corporations power had been relied upon under the so-called Brereton IR reform bill of 1993. So there is not a new head of power. That was a misconception. Senator Cooney, I do not think—I have not taken advice on this—that we would go around doing the things you want us to do just to flesh out use of that particular head of power.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, if workers are employees, as you have described them, they would indeed be covered by the workplace relations act. A worker does not cease to be an employee merely because he or she has entered a so-called sham incorporation arrangement. On the point that Senator Conroy makes relating to this so-called hidden agenda about the revenue and undermining the PAYE tax system: it would be a fascinating conspiracy in politics if we were seeking to undermine the revenue. It is entirely counter to the entire budget strategy. I hope that Senator Lundy and Senator Conroy share the same concerns about the tax base, the revenue and the budget when the budget bills come on for debate tomorrow and the next few days. I hope they are concerned to make sure that the tax base, the revenue and other measures in the budget can go through this place in absolute integrity so there is no temptation.

For the record, it should be noted that there has been only one government and one Treasurer in the history of Australia that has worked very, very hard to introduce a consumption tax. If you read John Edwards's exceptional biography of the former Prime Minister and Treasurer, you would believe that the former Treasurer was very committed to a consumption tax. Indeed, from my knowledge of history, he was the only Treasurer who worked very hard to introduce one. The now Treasurer (Mr Costello) has made quite clear his views about a GST.

The only other point I want to respond to, since I have been provoked into making a response, is Senator Lundy's putting the case about people being forced to become incorporated. It is a shame that Senator Lundy was not here—I am sure Senator Cooney will remind her, as he was a diligent member of the select committee on the land fund bill—when we had a long debate at that stage about what we in opposition thought was a very wrong move in forcing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians to be incorporated if they wanted to receive assistance from the land fund.

This was not Clarendon Homes forcing people to be incorporated if they wanted assistance and support; this was the Australian government—the Australian Labor Party at that time—forcing probably the most disadvantaged people in the country to become incorporated if they wanted to receive assistance under that legislation. It was an act of the previous government that forced the most disadvantaged people in Australia to become incorporated if they wanted to receive assistance under that act.
Amendment agreed to.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (62) Schedule 6, after item 4, page 40 (after line 12), insert the following heading:
(63) Schedule 6, after item 4, page 40 (after line 12), insert:
Insert:
Contract of service , without derogating from its common law meaning, includes any contract or agreement which is wholly or principally for the performance of work by one party to the contract.

I have already incorporated my comments on these opposition amendments. Whilst we welcome the support the Australian Democrats have given us in respect of the previous amendments, I think it is the first time we have had the support of the Australian Democrats—I suspect it will be the only time—on independent contractors. It is very welcome. But the position that we have just been able to achieve, whilst it is welcome and it is good that that has occurred, is a holding operation in respect of the spread of independent contractors.

We have to move forward to take account of the particular problems under the Trade Practices Act that we know will occur in order for the current workers—and future workers—who are being disadvantaged, to stand still and protect their current position against oppressive action by the sorts of actions that have been outlined by Senator Lundy and my colleague Senator Conroy. These amendments to the Trade Practices Act are very important. I understand the Democrats are not going to support them. That is a grave disappointment to us.

Senator Murray made the point in his earlier contribution that we did not have this particular provision in our 1993 amendments. That is correct, Senator Murray, but over the last few years it has become apparent, firstly, that the so‐called independent contractors are spreading and, therefore, the protection they need needs to be clearer and, secondly, the Trade Practices Act has not yet been used in this area. It seems to us, looking into the future, that it will be. So we appeal to you, Senator Murray, to change your position and support us on these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to opposition amendments Nos 62 and 63. The Democrats do have some sympathy with these amendments but we believe they will not achieve the objective that the ALP has for them. The objective is to ensure that valid collective bargaining by independent contractors against a single employer or employer association is not subject to the price fixing and other competition policy rules of the Trade Practices Act. We support that, but the reliance on the words `contract of service' becomes very inappropriate. On the one hand, there is no question that owner‐drivers all wearing the TNT badge and all working solely for TNT should be able to bargain collectively with TNT, but somewhere along the spectrum it becomes inappropriate because, on the other hand, when roof tilers, for example, collude to set a single high inflated price for roof tiling across Sydney, it is not right. More seriously, when professionals such as doctors and lawyers on contracts of service seek to slide into these provisions to avoid the operational competition policy, it becomes wholly inappropriate. In short, I do not believe that these provisions will work or are appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Our preferred approach is the development of industry codes of practices which might include guidelines on price. Even under the current Trade Practices Act this can be done and given an authorisation under section 88. In our discussions with the ACCC it has been made clear that the ACCC has no interest in pursuing owner‐drivers or other workers working closely akin to employees, but where genuine collective bargaining slips into punitive price fixing, the ACCC is interested. I would suggest to unions and their representatives here that they pursue the authorisation of industry codes as the better approach than the amendment being sought by the ALP with its much wider implications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, what advice did you obtain specifically from the ACCC with respect to this matter and how did it assist you, if in fact it did, in coming to your conclusions with respect to opposition amendments Nos 62 and 63?
—We have had meetings with the ACCC and telephone conversations with them.
—Did you receive any of that advice in writing, Senator Murray? If you did, is it available?
—I personally did not. I will undertake to find out whether anyone in our office did.

—During the course of the committee consideration of this bill, I tabled a letter which was, in fact, brought up in parliament by Alannah McTiernan MLC in Western Australia and specifically—ironically—mentioned roof tilers and the reality of what is happening in Western Australia. I would like to draw the attention of Senator Murray and the government to this: the reality is that groups like roof tilers in states such as Western Australia are getting the very raw end of the stick and certainly are not benefiting from highly inflated collusive activities. In fact, if the collusion is there, it is not because people are bad but because, in a very competitive industry, if the law allows you to take certain actions to decrease your ongoing costs, that is what will happen. It is not because people are bad; it is because transport and building have become very competitive. The reality is that no business will be able to stand up and give their workers a fair go if it is possible under the law for them to reduce their wages and conditions. Some may, but they will find that other people who are less scrupulous will undercut them by doing the very things which the law allows.
—Senator Murray, can you give a commitment that, if it is available, you will table in the Senate any written information from the ACCC on the issue we were discussing before?
—I would if I had a commitment. I cannot give a commitment for somebody else but I will definitely come back to the Senate and advise you if any of the Democrats have received written advice.
—If another Democrat has received it, would you undertake to try to get them to table it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly ask them the question, Senator.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry 's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that, on 11 November, Senator Ian Macdonald was appointed to the post of Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Leader of the Government in the Senate and Senator Ian Campbell was appointed Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to your government's miserable proposal for an $8 a week pay rise for a minority of Australian workers. Do you recall Mr Reith saying on 25 June last year that if low paid workers receive $14 per week increase for each of the next three years, as proposed by the previous Labor government, they would still be worse off in real terms? How can your government then maintain that over the next three years a worker receiving an $8 a week increase will not be worse off in real terms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is: no, I do not remember Mr Reith saying that. I will deal with the substance of the question and that is whether workers will benefit from an increase of $8 a week over each of the next three years. The answer is, overwhelmingly, they will.

ANSWER.PARA: As we know, inflation is currently at historic low levels. What we need to achieve is a level of wage increases that will not jeopardise that low inflation environment, and that is what this proposal does. Low paid workers can have confidence that the government will not ignore their needs and circumstances. Indeed, it was, of course, open to us to range far and wide in terms of the submission we made. I think you will find that we are much more generous in our approach than some others who have made submissions. We have not put in the usual ambit claim that the ACTU put in to all these sorts of applications.

What we have done is strike a balance that does ensure that the lowest paid do have the safety net, do have the ability to get an increase irrespective of their capacity to bargain but at the same time not put at risk any of the gains that flow from low inflation. Quite clearly, to the extent that inflation starts to get out of control and causes interest rates to rise, once again you are putting job creation and current employment at risk. Our submission will propose that workers whose award rates of pay are below average weekly ordinary time earnings—approximately $670 per week—should have access to the $8 a week increase. With absorption against over‐award payments and outcomes from enterprise agreements—

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be worse off.

—They will not be worse off. There will simply be a new role for the award system as an effective safety net for the low paid, and I can assure you that low paid workers will continue to achieve improvements in wages by making agreements with their employers. The ACTU's centralised approach to this particular claimant, and presumably others in the future, is not the way to go. The way the government has approached this is to strike a figure that does indeed ensure that those workers will be fully protected.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, isn't it the case that even the minority of workers who receive your paltry wage offer will, after three years, be around $1,000 worse off than under the previous Labor government's proposals?
—I don't know; you pick figures out of the air. Maybe you would like to explain them after question time.
—What a weak agenda.
—It has been put to me that this is a fact of life, that people will be $1,000 a year worse off than under the Labor Party.
—You don't know.
—I don't know anything about that.
—That's the position; you don't know.

—I think I have said that. There is no need to actually repeat it. It ought to be clear that I have not been following that level of detail, but I am aware of the merits of the argument and the need to ensure that we do not simply turn our backs on those who are at the bottom end of the pile and to ensure that awards serve the purpose that will best protect them—in other words, providing an effective safety net. If you want me to go back and get you some facts and figures that make all those spurious comparisons that you are trotting out, the fact is they will not. I will get you the figures that demonstrate that. I know nothing about the basis for your $1,000. I am sure you would like to explain it to us after question time and that will enable us to respond to you properly. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The minister would be aware of the winning economic trifecta of low inflation, moderate wages growth and two official drops in interest rates occurring under the first eight months of the Howard government. Firstly, what effect have these had on the level of business and consumer confidence? Secondly, will the minister indicate how important it is that the Senate passes the first Howard‐Costello budget in full?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Although dismissed by the Labor Party, in fact, low inflation, moderate wages growth and two official drops in interest rates clearly good news for all Australians and, I would have thought, would be applauded by all within this—
—It all happened in the last eight months, did it, Robert?
—It is; we caused it.
—Order! There are far too many interjections on my left. I ask that the minister have the opportunity to answer the question and be heard.

—I will repeat it, Madam President. The Howard coalition government is pleased that we are able to deliver low inflation, moderate wages growth and two official drops in interest rates in such a short period of time in government. That is clearly good news for all Australians. What is pleasing is that surveys are starting to indicate a growing consumer confidence as a result of a government that has been prepared to take the hard decisions and to give Australian business, in particular small business, the chance to grow and to employ more Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: Members of the Labor Party want to dismiss it. I remind them of the Westpac‐Melbourne Institute index published on 14 November, which said that consumer sentiment leapt 8.3 points to almost 110 points in November, hitting a five-month high, with Sydney leading the way at an index rating of over 116 points. Westpac's General Manager, Economics, Bill Evans, said the response was `remarkably strong'. That is Australians responding to good economic management. It is interesting to see that 58 per cent believed that it was a good time to buy major household items, which represents the highest degree of confidence in over two years. That is good news.

The Roy Morgan survey put out last week found that 35 per cent of those surveyed believed that they would be better off next year under a coalition government. An employment agency survey by the Manpower organisation was reported in the Bulletin on 19 November. Malcolm Jackman, Manpower's MD, said—listen to this Labor—that the positive effects of the Howard-Costello budget are starting to be felt in the business community and should flow on to increased employment next year. He said he was seeing clients with a lot of confidence with business people still talking about growth and that no-one is downsizing for downsizing's sake. He is very optimistic—in particular, Senator Alston—about the telecommunications industry, forecasting the hiring of 123,000 people over the next three years. That is good news for Australians.

Morgan and Banks surveyed 3,200 organisations with more than a million employees. It reported on 13 November for the first time in the last 18 months that there has been an increase in the net hiring plans of business. The survey found that over 32 per cent of those businesses expect to add employees and 86 per cent of businesses with up to 30 staff expect steady or improved employment conditions.

So as a result of good government and as a result of a government that was prepared to take the hard decisions in a budget, business confidence and consumer confidence are growing. That gives Australians a lot of hope for the future. What is important now is that this Senate respond to the same sentiment, respond to what Australia is asking of it—that is, to endorse and support the program that the government has put before the parliament, to support the budget in particular, to let us implement the decisions that we have made in that difficult but well supported budget, to get the workplace relations bill through, to get the budget bills through, to enable this confidence to build and to get more employment growth in the next 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister Assisting the Treasurer. Minister, do you agree with Senator Boswell when he said last week, `Competition policy would act as a giant vacuum cleaner sucking people from rural areas.' In the light of these comments, can you inform the Senate what the benefits are to rural and regional Australia from the Liberal-National Party coalition government's competition policy? How many jobs do you expect to be created in rural and regional Australia from those reforms?

—Thank you for the question. We are all aware of the importance of competition policy. I think it is true to say, Senator Cook, that, when your party was in government, it was very keen to develop policies to improve competition policy around Australia. It is not a new issue.

BREAK.PARA: I have not seen the comments by my colleague. I would always look very closely at any issue when a member of the opposition stands up and purports to quote in full a member on this side of the chamber. I will look closely at what Senator Boswell has said—as I always do—and then see whether it is worth responding to.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise on the left‐hand side of the chamber. Please allow the minister to answer his question.

—Thank you. In relation to the benefits of competition policy, I hark Senator Cook back to my earlier comments about his government being very concerned to improve and develop competition policies in Australia. I imagine that he would be well aware of those things. Just to run through a few of the benefits of the competition policy, we would hope to provide, among other things, a more competitive economy, lower prices to consumers—
—Can you answer the question?
—That is answering the question. Through those sorts of measures, we hope to provide a more productive economy which can better compete on world markets.

BREAK.PARA: I am rather surprised that Senator Cook, who is now writing articles for newspapers dealing with a range of policy issues, raises questions about competition policy and the benefits that a sound competition policy can deliver to this country. I am very surprised that he has raised that particular issue.

As far as the creation of jobs is concerned, that was a dilemma which the previous government had in spades. It had 13 years to develop a policy which could deliver real jobs in this country. You and your ministers, many of whom still litter the opposition frontbench, presided over the worst recession in 60 years and so many jobs were lost.

Just to summarise, Senator Cook, we would hope that the creation of a more competitive economy, among other things, will assist in delivering considerable benefits to consumers and will allow Australia to compete better on world markets. That will deliver large benefits to this country, including more employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a brilliant answer, Rod!
—Thank you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you have dodged the essential part of my question. I ask you now to answer this part of the question or, if you cannot, bring back an answer to the Senate: how many jobs do you expect to be created in rural and regional Australia because of these reforms? In light of the fact that the National Party has given the government its unwavering and unquestioning loyalty, will you undertake to meet with Senator Boswell and explain to him the government's policy and ensure the coalition is not working both sides of the electoral street at the same time?

—What an absolutely pathetic follow‐up! Senator Faulkner just said, `What a brilliant answer' and you get up and complain. Talk about divided views! In relation to Senator Boswell—and it does not need to come in a question from you—I am happy to meet Senator Boswell at any time and at any place. Senator Boswell is a valued colleague and I do not think he needs you to ask me to make an appointment with him. I thank Senator Cook for his question; but, if Senator Boswell wishes to meet me, I would be delighted.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Following his recent visit to India, will the minister report on export opportunities for Australia to that country? Are the prospects of increased exports to India confined to the resource areas, in particular coal, or are there opportunities in other areas? If so, what are they?
—Ian, what are you doing sitting at the back?
