—Order! Senator Sherry, it is not appropriate to yell questions across the chamber from one senator to another and I would ask you to desist.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to report to the Senate that the most recent mining mission that I led to India was very successful for both India and Australia. I was accompanied by 12 representatives of business interests in Australia. Over a seven‐day period meetings were held in Delhi, Mumbai and Calcutta with senior ministers, senior government officials and private sector companies. I was accompanied by expertise from Australia which ranged from exploration, feasibility studies, mine development, transportation, electricity generation, materials handling and of course mine technology.

ANSWER.PARA: There were two major areas of interest for both Indians and Australians and they covered coking coal and thermal coal. It was particularly pleasing for me to be there in regard to coking coal because it was just 20 years ago that I in fact signed the first contract with the Steel Authority of India for the sale of coking coal. From a modest 200,000 tonnes of coal in 1976, we have seen sales grow to around nine million tonnes in 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —All your own work.

—I thank Senator Alston. I will take that interjection. This shows that India is now the second biggest market for coking coal outside Japan. Compared with other Asian countries, the Indians take 98 per cent of their imports of coking coal from Australia. From the discussions I had with them they were very pleased with both the quality and the reliability of supply, although I might say that the latter was marred to a small extent by one of the Indian agents asking me why there was a strike at a particular supplier's mine because the company dared to write and communicate with its own employees and suffered a 14‐day strike.

ANSWER.PARA: Of greater importance to the Australian coking coal industry are the Indian projections that over the next five to six years they intend to increase their coking coal imports by 100 per cent, from nine million tonnes a year to 18 million tonnes a year. This is good news for the Australian coking coal industry. In respect of steaming or thermal coal, the Indian authorities made it very clear that to meet their energy demands they will need to increase their capacity by about 10,000 to 12,000 megawatts a year per year for the next 10 years. This is an enormous ask because, if you put it into Australian terms, that means three Eraring power stations every year for the next 10 years, but it does open up big opportunities.

The Indian government owned and operated Coal India supplies just over 400 million tonnes. It is worth mentioning that because it is often thought that Australia is the largest coal producer in the world. It is not, but it is certainly the largest coal exporter. While the Indian coals are low in sulfur, they are very high in ash. The opportunities it opens up for Australia are direct supply of Australian thermal coal, blending of our lower Australian coals with high ash indigenous coals, cooperation between Australia and India in the supply of technology, for example in washeries where they have no experience, and infrastructure planning. A major impediment is the size of their ports, the capacity of their ports and the participation and development of India's own coal resources. This represents major opportunities for Australian companies and of course major challenges for both India and Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. In your speech at the Australian National University on Friday you called on unemployed Aboriginal people to start small businesses as a way of solving their unemployment problems. You highlighted a number of programs that they should access including—and it was in your speech—the Business Advice for Rural Areas or BARA program. Were you aware when you made that speech that the Business Advice to Rural Areas scheme was in fact abolished by your government in the last budget and will in fact come to a halt completely in March next year when its current funding runs out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did say that; and I was aware, Senator Bob Collins. If you had watched Meet the Press yesterday you would have got an explanation which would have saved you getting up this afternoon and asking a question like that.
—You are answerable here, not to Meet the Press .
—Order! Senator Herron! Do not answer questions directly across the chamber.

—We frequently get asked questions from the other side about whether we have read newspapers or watched television so I think it is only fair that I should respond in that way. I thought if the opposition were alert they might have got the answer yesterday. Mr Ian Warden of the Canberra Times said the other day that the questions asked by the opposition in this chamber are so flat that he thinks all the people in the press gallery up there were wishing they were a bit more senior so that they could be in the other chamber and get the questions there. I see he is not present today so maybe he has been elevated. I was aware of the matter that Senator Bob Collins referred to and I will be discussing with the ATSIC board of commissioners when the new board meets ways of overcoming this particular problem. It is possible that we can finance and stimulate that through ATSIC itself.

BREAK.PARA: In addition to that, and which Senator Bob Collins did not have the grace to ask about, I mentioned many other things in the Dame Enid Lyons Memorial Speech on Friday. I emphasised that the way forward for the indigenous community of this country is self‐empowerment through economic independence. That can only come through small business enterprises. In travelling around Australia I have seen many examples of this throughout the country. The way forward for Aboriginal people is through their own business enterprises. Many of them, of course, have been successful. It is by this sort of mechanism that they can attain their independence and go beyond self‐management to the stage of self‐empowerment. They can then collectively and individually get away from a dependence on government handouts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Minister, the reason I am asking the question is that in fact I did watch what you said on Meet the Press last night. That is the reason I am asking the question. The BARA scheme was successful in creating 1,400 new jobs last year. On Meet the Press yesterday—I have the transcript in front of me—you said:

QUESTION.PARA: The decision to axe BARA was a decision made at the time by the ATSIC board.
You said that you were going to arrange for interim funding from the board of commissioners to see if you can get funds in the interim.

Minister, are you aware that the business advice in rural areas scheme has nothing whatever to do with ATSIC; that it is in fact a program which is administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and that it was in fact axed by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and its minister? Are you seriously suggesting that, having taken $470 million, you are going to divert funds from ATSIC into DPIE's budget area to maintain the BARA funding which is in fact their program and not ATSIC's? The ATSIC board, Minister, had nothing whatever to do with the decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I was aware of that, as I said to Senator Bob Collins. But it is the thrust of what we are going to do through ATSIC.
—You don't know what you are doing; that is the problem.

—It is, Senator Collins. With respect, it is. After 13 years the opposition failed in this regard. It is hypocritical of them to get up and criticise what we are doing, which is a solution to the problems that are there. It is grossly hypocritical. They had 13 years to do something about this. When we come forward with solutions for these problems they have the hypocrisy to get up and criticise them. I would ask the opposition what their policy is to break away from what they did in the past and to try to get outside the problems which they created?

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the government accept that the recent disrupted conference on East Timor held in Malaysia a week ago was a legal gathering? On what advice did the Prime Minister say that the violent disruption of the conference and subsequent arrest of 10 Australians was unfortunate and that they should have had respect for Malaysian law before they decided to attend the conference? Was consular assistance immediately available to all the Australians arrested? Finally, does the government still subscribe to the universal human charter on human rights and, in particular, to article 20, which states that everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of legality, of course, was a subject before the Malaysian court after the event. If Senator Bourne is saying that the Australian government should have in some way anticipated that the Malaysian court would find that the meeting was legal in advance, then she is perhaps asking just a trifle too much. In fact, we are having some difficulty—Senator Bourne might have better sources, of course—in getting the details of that Malaysian court's determination. As I understand, it was heard by a single judge in chambers and there was no court report available. But we did read the reports in the press as to the outcome.
—Are you denying it?

—I am not quarrelling with that, but Senator Bourne is raising the issue of legality under Malaysian law. I am saying that it is quite difficult to determine the basis upon which the Malaysian court made its determination. But, in any event, that was after the event.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the event itself, the government said, as you have conceded, Senator Bourne, that what occurred was clearly regrettable. Those words speak for themselves, really. I would have thought that we would all regard what occurred as regrettable. Nevertheless, as the Australian government noted, the Malaysian government had in turn made a clear decision on 4 November that the conference could not go ahead. I understand that this decision was clearly conveyed to the conference organisers and through a press conference on 4 November. That was widely reported in the Malaysian and regional media the next day.

I am advised that the Deputy Home Affairs Minister spoke to some conference organisers and advised them of the Malaysian cabinet decision. The Malaysian government's intention was further clearly demonstrated by the arrest and subsequent deportation by immigration officials of a Filipino conference organiser, Renato Constantino, on his arrival in Kuala Lumpur on 6 November. So the signals were clear in relation to the Malaysian government's attitude to this particular conference.

What the government said is that it is not for the Australian government to tell the Malaysian government how to conduct its internal policies. Interestingly, that view was shared by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, who, according to the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 November, said:
I think it is entirely reasonable that a nation will determine . . . precisely what might be said by other people on its soil.

In relation to the issue of consular responsibilities, I am told that Mr Downer, his staff and his department worked through the weekend of 9 and 10 November to ensure that the welfare of Australian citizens was not compromised. The minister spoke with the Australian High Commission in Kuala Lumpur three times on 10 November to assure himself that Australian citizens were accorded the best possible treatment.

In relation to the ABC journalist, Catherine McGrath, it is pleasing that the ABC wrote to the minister thanking him and the department for the energy with which they assisted Ms McGrath. In relation to the international covenant, obviously we continue to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. The minister did say in his answer, however, that he believed the signals were clear. Obviously, they were not clear to participants such as Bishop Deakin, who had no absolutely idea that the Malaysian cabinet had made the decision that the conference would be illegal. I did not believe a cabinet could make a decision on legality and illegality; I thought that was a matter for legislation. Would the minister please go back to the Prime Minister's office or the foreign minister's office and get all the details of whether or not the Australian participants in that conference—and they obviously were going to be participants in that conference—were told that Australia believed this was going to be an illegal conference? Could the minister provide us with the details of that?
—I am happy to refer that back to the Prime Minister and/or the foreign minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to reports in the Melbourne Age of 13 November which stated that bundles of secret DFAT cables were accidentally released at a public auction of second-hand government furniture? Can the minister confirm that a bundle of 16 cables was handed by an auction official to a public servant whose identity was apparently unknown to the auctioneer? Can the minister further confirm that the public servant has stated that he saw two filing cabinets containing cables marked `in confidence' at the auction? Can the minister confirm that the department paid a security firm $55,000 to secure classified material during the eight weeks of the move to the department's new offices? What damage has the lax security surrounding the handling of these documents done to the image of Australia in the United States and what arrangements are proposed to ascertain how this incredible gaffe occurred?

—I seem to remember asking similar questions when I was in opposition when not dissimilar facts were alleged. In this instance, I am told that the relocation of the department of foreign affairs from the Administrative Building to the R.G. Casey centre obviously involved the transfer of a vast quantity of official documents. Comprehensive arrangements were put in place both prior to and during the move to ensure the security of this information, including a series of checks made of cabinets and desk draws. Of the literally millions of documents involved—I do not know how this gets calculated, but I am assured that there were in excess of 10 kilometres of papers—it was found that just three were picked up afterwards, having being jammed down the back of a cabinet draw.
—Is that three kilometres?

—Three papers, I understand. The article in the Age newspaper claims that documents were left in cabinets and that 16 were handed by an auction official to someone described by the reporter as an anonymous off duty public servant.
—Nicknamed `Spook'!
—That is in quotes. The department has written advice from the auctioneers categorically denying that any of their staff handed any documents to a third party, let alone an off duty public servant.
—We used to give better answers than this one.

—This is as good as it is coming. It may be suggested that the Age has been given documents that are purportedly departmental cable traffic. However, the department has seen no evidence that any purported documents came from the furniture auction, and the department does not believe that they did.

BREAK.PARA: The Age has handed to the office of the foreign minister one document which is allegedly part of the bundle referred to in the Age article. As a matter of established practice, the department does not confirm deny whether such documents are genuine, but the document handed to the government does not in any way bear out Murdoch's article.

The department does not accept the Age story about an off duty public servant being handed a bundle of documents by an auction official. As is usual practice, the matter will be investigated by the Australian Federal Police. It would therefore be inappropriate to say anything further now as it is in the hands of the AFP.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, last Thursday you launched the national re-establishment of the job placement, employment and training program—JPET—designed to assist young disadvantaged people. Can you inform the Senate of key aspects of the program and the very real difference it will make to the lives of thousands of disadvantaged young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Eggleston, for that question and the answer is, yes, I can. Last Thursday I relaunched the job placement, employment and training program in Mornington, Victoria, at one of the new program sites. The programs will operate across Australia, from places such as Mount Gravatt in Brisbane across to Wanneroo in Perth.

ANSWER.PARA: This government is determined to raise the understanding of issues involving young Australians generally, to celebrate their successes, to listen to them and to ensure that all young people have the opportunity to participate to the best of their abilities. However, as I have said in this place before, sadly today a number of young people live in circumstances that are far from ideal, and the government is determined to ensure that these young people are given a helping hand.

The re-establishment of the JPET scheme is a very important part of our commitment. With funding of $11 million per annum for the next two years, the scheme will assist young people who are homeless or at risk of becoming so. The JPET program provides funding to services to help disadvantaged young Australians who are facing barriers to employment, education and training.

One of the barriers to participation is homelessness. Homeless young people are often without any family support, and the government is committed to addressing their needs and has increased assistance to them through programs such as JPET. Many of the young people being helped by this service have left school early or have been wards of the state and some are ex-offenders. Reinstatement of the JPET program is a very important step in providing a range of support and assistance to meet these most disadvantaged young people.

I anticipate that the program will be fully operational early next year and will fund somewhere between 80 and 100 organisations to provide support to about 4,000 young people each year. JPET services will assist unemployed young people, students, young refugees, young people in state care or those about to exit from it and young ex-offenders. It provides a holistic approach to assisting people under 21, particularly those in the 15 to 19 age group.

The program will offer ongoing support and referral services for young people with problems, including a lack of suitable housing, substance abuse, sexual or other abuse, lack of self esteem and financial difficulties. Once the underlying problems are addressed, participants in the program will be assisted in their efforts to gain access to education, entry level training or employment and will be supported to maintain their participation in these activities. It is the government's hope that JPET services such as these will help many young people realise their full potential and enable them to plan their futures with confidence.

There are a number of other initiatives that this government is taking to assist young people, not the least of which is tackling youth unemployment by reducing the budget deficit and creating a climate for sustained economic growth, thereby keeping pressure off interest rates, reforming industrial relations law, reducing paperwork on small business, introducing a modernised Australian apprentice and traineeship scheme, introducing the green corps and, very importantly, ensuring that young people entering the work force have the literacy and other communications skills essential for getting and keeping a job. All of those things, combined with the reintroduction of the JPET scheme, auger very well for opportunities created by this government for young Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer the minister to the conflicting messages that the government is sending over the status of foreign ownership policy in the current federal government review of cross-media rules. Minister, is it your intention that foreign ownership policy be considered in the cross-media rules review? If not, can you explain why the Prime Minister stated in today's Sydney Morning Herald :

BREAK.PARA: You couldn't look at cross media ownership rules in isolation to foreign investment policy.

If it is the Prime Minister's intention for the review to include foreign media ownership policy, what consideration will be given to those who have made submissions on your mistaken advice that the review would not include these issues? Is it your intention, in light of the Prime Minister's urging on foreign ownership policy, to extend the closing date for public submissions?

TALK.START.PARA: —Good question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only a good question if you don't know the answer, Bob. If you bothered to look at the terms of reference and the issues and discussion paper that we circulated several months back, you would see that this is about cross-media.
—Not according to the Prime Minister.

—We will come to that in a moment. There are those who seek to manufacture differences that are not there, such as Senator Schacht, who presumably is still wresting with his ABC submission. I notice that you have managed to take your home page down. You might like to explain to us when you are going to resurrect it. If you did, you could put the discussion paper on it.
—Answer the question.

—All right, I will. What we have said consistently is that we want to review the cross-media rules because they are flawed and because they were put in place for naked political reasons. In the process of doing that, it is necessary to have regard to, or do it against the background of, existing foreign ownership regulations, and they vary from radio where there are none, to television where they are in statute, to print where it is the responsibility of the Treasurer.
—You just contradicted yourself.

—Those who do not want to understand will never understand. The fact is that it is a review about cross-media, but you cannot stop people taking account of the background against which those rules are in position. It is not surprising that those players with significant foreign interests either wanting to increase them or simply protect them will address that aspect in their submissions. They understand, having read the issues paper and the terms of reference, that at the end of this inquiry we will be looking at the extent to which we change the existing cross-media regime.

ANSWER.PARA: In other words, out of this inquiry will not come changes to foreign ownership rules. They are always capable of being changed. They are quite flexible, thanks to you and the approach you have taken in respect of print media—endlessly flexible. Every time Mr Keating wanted to do a deal with someone in exchange for balanced coverage, they jacked the rate up a bit. So there is endless flexibility in relation to print, and you can change those rules at any time. No-one has put in an application. Presumably they are waiting till the end of this inquiry to understand what new regime might be in place in relation to cross-media.

At any given time in the future it is possible to make decisions in relation to foreign ownership. I say once again: the Prime Minister has been in heated agreement with the Treasurer and me, and that is that this inquiry is about cross-media ownership. It is against the background of, or takes into account, the existing foreign ownership regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has done you again, Richard.

—I am sorry that you do not want to know or understand. Those who think it is about something else will be missing the point. They will have failed the exam. They should not be paying their consultants for putting in something that is not in accord with the terms of reference. If you want to go back and have a look at it, you will see that it says exactly what we said several months ago and what we are saying now. That is: you have to take account of the foreign ownership regime but, other than that, this is an inquiry into the cross-media rules.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, if the Prime Minister is in heated agreement with you, why did he say in today's Sydney Morning Herald :

QUESTION.PARA: You couldn't look at cross media ownership rules in isolation to foreign investment policy.
Why did the Prime Minister say on 11 November:
It's impossible to completely isolate that investigation from some consideration of foreign investment rules—
when you stated on Wednesday, 13 November:
. . . this review is about cross media . . . I am not suggesting (foreign ownership) is currently in need of review.
Who is right: you or the Prime Minister? Who is telling the truth: you or the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —You really ought to get some better advisers. This questions committee is clearly in need of a dramatic overhaul. I would have thought if Senator Robert Ray were earning his money he would tell you that when you get an answer as comprehensive and as definite as the one I have just given you you do not simply serve it up again.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the Prime Minister and I have consistently made the point that I have been trying to make for the last four minutes; that is, this inquiry is about cross-media. If you read the press releases, if you read the terms of reference, that is what it is about. All he is saying is that when you are a media proprietor you are dealing with a number of factors. You have to deal with incompetent oppositions. You have to deal with regulations that are in place. You have to deal with foreign ownership restrictions.

In taking account all of those things you simply do not just focus on one aspect in running your business. A lot of people will want to make comments about the foreign ownership regime in the course of getting to their principal submission in relation to cross‐media. We know that. We accept that, but that is not what this inquiry is about. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, at the beginning of your answer to this question you referred to a senator by his given name. It is not appropriate to address senators in that fashion.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What priority does the Prime Minister intend to give to promoting and advancing human rights in his discussions with the President of the United States, Mr Clinton, with the head of state of China, Jiang Zemin, and with other heads of Asian governments at the APEC summit next week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I might address the background of the policy of the government and the attitude of the government to this very important matter. The promotion and protection of human rights are certainly an inseparable part of the government's foreign policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The human rights policy is pursued on the basis that the promotion and protection of human rights serves Australia's broader national economic and security interest and that human rights are both universal and indivisible, as enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other international human rights instruments. It is to that background that at the APEC meeting which, as the honourable senator knows, is primarily an economic forum no doubt the Prime Minister will be addressing these issues.

The Australian government does use a range of different opportunities to advance its position on human rights and try to influence a better outcome from those who may not be adhering to the standards of the international declaration, at least to the minimum international standards that the international community accepts. It is done through the bilateral fora, such as I think is the opportunity Senator Harradine sees in this forum, through multilateral fora and through, whenever possible, the strengthening of institutions.

I presume, if I am correctly interpreting the honourable senator's question, that the reference to the United States President and the President of China is suggesting that the Prime Minister should raise China's human rights record again with the President of China and perhaps speak on the same issue with the President of the United States. As Senator Harradine is aware, whenever the opportunity has presented we have raised the issue of China's human rights record with the appropriate authorities in China. I make specific reference to the dialogue on human rights that took place between Mr Downer and the Chinese foreign minister, Mr Qian Qichen.
On the very specific question of priority, as I do not have a brief that actually tells me exactly what the Prime Minister's intentions are, I will refer that to him for his further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Has the minister's attention been drawn to recent reports and comments attributed to her parliamentary secretary, Mr Tony Abbott, to a Community and Public Sector Union conference? Is the minister aware that Mr Abbott stated his belief that support for skillshare should be boosted? How does the minister reconcile Mr Abbott's view with the fact that she recently slashed the skillshare budget by 20 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to press reporting of what Mr Abbott said in that respect. He, I think, was simply indicating that skillshare is a very respected program. That is why, in allocating what skillshare funding could be distributed and how, I took the opportunity to appoint an independent committee with George Polites, who was appointed chair of the CESAC review by your government, with David Thompson, the national president of the skillshare association, and of course representatives of my department.

ANSWER.PARA: As you would well know, Senator Foreman, it is very important when these decisions are made that they are open and clear and there for everybody to see. As you also know, there is not a skillshare provider I believe who will look you in the eye and say that they are all as good as each other. They freely admit, especially the better ones of course, that some skillshare providers are better than others. That was the purpose of establishing this independent review committee with the president of the national skillshare association to give them the opportunity to sort out who were the good ones, who did we want to help ensure they survive. That is why that committee was set up.

The funding has been allocated and there has been very little complaint about reductions in funding. No-one welcomes that at all. No-one ever welcomes getting less Commonwealth money. It probably comes as no surprise to you that no minister enjoys telling people that they are going to get less. But, when you come from the side of government that you come from that went on a spend, spend, spend with Beazley's Bankcard running up into billions of dollars, sooner or later you get kicked out of office because the community says that you have made a mess and it wants someone else to fix it up. The community wants people who are prepared to take the hard decisions to get these things fixed.

That meant that skillshare, along with a lot of other providers across my portfolio and others, had to bear some of the pain of the mess that your former government created. We are prepared to make the hard decisions to fix up that mess. But I make no bones about it. Skillshare are, relatively speaking, good providers. That is why an independent committee was set up—so that the good providers would be rewarded, not the ones who were not pulling their weight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, on what basis did you decide to slash skillshare?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks for the opportunity to give you another minute on your government's fiscal incompetence. I hardly believe my luck. You might have been unwell, Senator Foreman, but at the last election your side lost. The reason they lost was partly because of their financial and fiscal incompetence. They had such a huge debt. They kept hiding their heads in the sand and they kept thinking they could ignore it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian people want a government that will not ignore the difficult problems and will face up to them. So across portfolios— not just mine; across others—substantial savings had to be made to fill Beazley's Bankcard. That is the reason these decisions had to be made. It is fair that, relatively speaking, everyone bears a portion of the pain that your government created. That is why you lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. The cabling of Adelaide by both Telstra and Optus is imminent. Why won't the minister use his current power to prevent Telstra from erecting aerial cabling before the roll‐out of Adelaide is commenced? Given that the Australian Democrats have already assured the government that they would support any legislation to bring about a rational solution to the wasteful and damaging practice of aerial cabling, will the minister introduce legislation to assume this power over all carriers after July 1997?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly think Senator Allison is correct in saying that there ought to be a fundamentally different regime after 1 July next year. Indeed it would be my intention that there not be any overhead cabling after that date unless it is with the agreement of the relevant state or local authority.
—What is left then?

—There is a lot of Australia that still does not have access to pay television, to lower telephone charges, to interactive broadband services, and they are still very keen to have it. Indeed if you talk to some of my country colleagues, they will say, `If only we had overhead towers and cable.'

ANSWER.PARA: But let me address the issue in more detail. The fact is that it is very important to remember that we are currently dealing with commercial arrangements that have been in place now for some five years. If you go back, you will find that on a number of occasions Labor in government had the opportunity to tighten the system, to somehow stop what was happening before it really got off the ground. But we are now about three-quarters of the way through the game and it is certainly too late in the piece to be moving the goal posts and jeopardising something like $3 billion to $4 billion worth of roll‐out by each of the two players.

We do not accept the proposition that somehow it is wasteful duplication to have facilities‐based competition, indeed nor does the OECD. There have been a number of studies done on this which show that particularly in relation to telecommunications the dead hand of having a single utility providing infrastructure facilities is about the best way possible to ensure that work practices and other very expensive cost factors make the whole service very much more expensive than it needs to be.

So what you need to do is proceed against the background of the green light that was given up until 1 July and then seek to ameliorate the impact on residents against that background. That is what we are doing. We understand that there is genuine community concern. But the answer to that is not to simply go in there with a sledgehammer and tell Telstra what to do.

Telstra is rolling out its broadband and cable television services primarily underground. It is doing it in relation to pay television on behalf of a joint venture, which involves News Corporation. So it is not simply a government monopoly rolling out money using taxpayers' dollars; it is doing it as part of a commercial consortium. Clearly you have to have regard for the implications of any heavy‐handed intervention that might adversely affect either Optus Vision or Foxtel in that regard.

So the answer is not simply to give Telstra directions which would fundamentally cripple its capacity to compete. We do want to see people have a competitive choice. We do want to see lower prices for all of these services. We do want people to get fast access to the Internet. We do want the clever country to occur here. The best way to do that is to have competition.

To the extent that there are commercial outcomes that can be negotiated between the players, we encourage that. Indeed, not only since the election but also even in our election commitment we said that we would explore all possible ways of minimising duplication. I have on a number of occasions since that time had discussions with the carriers. I have written to them. I have called them together to go through the various options. That is the extent of our capacity to intervene in something that is well down the track, unless you take the view that somehow you do not give a damn for what has already been invested—that you are not interested in the benefits that flow from that competition. We are not in that category. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response. It has been reported that Telstra has proposed that both it and Optus co-construct in Adelaide by sharing Telstra's underground ducting. Sharing resources and infrastructure would ensure not only that cables are laid underground but also that the cost of duplication, which would be passed on to consumers, would be averted. I note the minister's response in relation to competitive choice and commercial arrangements. Will the minister facilitate agreement by carriers to share resources in order to protect the interests of local communities and, I might say, the choice of consumers in the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I applaud your choice of words when you say `facilitate agreement', because that is much closer to what is not only possible but also desirable under the regime we have inherited. In other words, you are, in using that terminology, stopping far short of advocating intervention and direction. You are saying that we ought to do our best to encourage the players to get together and share facilities where it makes sense. That is precisely what we have been endeavouring to do. But, at the end of the day, I am sure you understand that to go—
—Did they turn you down on Saturday?
—No, that press report is very misleading and one‐sided and certainly does not represent any discussions that might have occurred over the weekend. I am happy to talk to you further about that.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that to go overhead is very significantly cheaper and quicker—probably of the order of three to six times cheaper—than going underground. So to simply say `Why don't you go underground,' when they have already constructed a business case and when they have already raised funds on a particular basis, is essentially telling them that you want them to go out of business. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the minister cite one example where Mr Max Moore-Wilton, having taken up a job, has failed to have his office renovated? Given that Mr Max Moore‐Wilton has had his PM&C office in Canberra renovated, has there also been any expenditure of public moneys on renovations to Sydney offices which Mr Max Moore-Wilton may use?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know but I will ask and find out and come back and tell you.

ANSWER.PARA: Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During the adjournment debate on 7 November 1996, Senator Panizza asked me to look at a speech by Senator Gibbs to see if there were any unparliamentary statements in the speech. In the course of her speech, Senator Gibbs made several allegations about the conduct of the Queensland government.

INTERJECT.PARA: In the past, a distinction has been drawn between statements about governments and statements about particular members or groups of members of Commonwealth or state parliaments. It has been ruled that remarks may be made about a government generally which would be unparliamentary if made about a particular member or group of members, although President Sibraa observed that it is a difficult distinction to make and that perhaps it is a distinction which should not be made. That is in the Hansard of 26 May 1993, page 1340.

Senator Gibbs's remarks were directed to the Queensland government in general, although she did refer to two members of the Queensland parliament in terms which could be held to be unparliamentary. I would remind all senators that members of state parliaments are protected against offensive words and imputations of improper motives by standing order 193.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to the effects of competition policy on rural and regional Australia.

Today I asked Senator Kemp a question on competition policy. I asked him that question directly because the Leader of the National Party in this place, Senator Boswell, had obviously sought to undermine the government's position on competition policy by alleging, as has been widely reported, that jobs would be lost and there would be a giant vacuum cleaner sucking jobs out of rural and regional Australia, to quote the remarks attributed to Senator Boswell.

The question I asked of Senator Kemp was: could he tell us how many jobs were lost? Senator Kemp, in his primary answer, dodged that question. He did not answer that question. In taking advantage of the supplementary question, I pointedly asked him again whether he could answer that question and, if he could not answer that question, whether he would go away, find out and come back and tell the Senate what the answer to that question was. Again, he pointedly declined to do so.

That raises a very serious consideration in this chamber. It raises a very important consideration, as well, beyond this chamber. National competition policy has been an issue in which there has been a degree of national bipartisanship. That part at least was acknowledged—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I was surprised at it too.

—I see Senator Kemp strutting the floor and, in progress, acknowledging that point again. It has been a matter of national bipartisanship. But we do know that the National Party and others have been out to try and wreck national competition policy and its implementation in the states. We do know that the National Party has a record of succeeding in changing this government's position when it wants to. It did so on the diesel fuel rebate issue for farmers; it did so on the ships capital grants scheme.
—No, that was not so.
—I hear Senator Ferguson interjecting. I understand it might do so on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) when it comes to taxes on cooperatives.
—And the reef tax; that will change.

—I have an interjection which I acknowledge from my colleague Senator Sherry. Although it has been vocal on reef tax and while it has certainly suggested that the government will change its position on reef tax, so far it has not succeeded. I hope it succeeds on the reef tax, I might add very quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that this nation knows where it goes at all levels of government in this country when it comes to the implementation of the important reforms on national competition policy. A government pursuing those reforms should be able to say where it believes there will be greater efficiencies and enhanced competitiveness in the Australian economy because of those reforms. We do not pursue change on national competition policy for the sake of national competition policy. We pursue it for the sake of economic growth for not only better income levels in the economy but also more jobs for ordinary Australians.

If this government remains silent on the point of what jobs will come from this important reform, then either the government has not given the thought necessary to carry the reform through and succeed—or it is at least opening itself and exposing its flank to be attacked by the National Party to bring those reforms down—or it is enabling the states to crawl out of the commitments that they have made.

There is a gaping hole in one of the areas of this budget the government so loudly lauds in this chamber: there are no forecasts in the budget that has been brought down this year on where the jobs growth will be. There is no forecast on what the outcome for employment for Australians will be. The government keeps telling us this is a well received budget. It is not well received by the unemployed; there is no guidance there. It is not well received by the marginally employed who look at the prospects of a slow economy with slack demand creating more unemployment in their areas.

Here the government is pushing an important reform from the foundation—strong and true—of bipartisan support. But it needs to make the case in the terms of not, `We want competition policy,' but where the jobs are. If it cannot answer the allegation made by Senator Boswell, it really ought to close up shop and hand it back to someone who can make that case and can pursue those reforms.

I particularly want to know how many jobs there will be in Western Australia. The Court government in Western Australia—which has prematurely gone to the polls just this week—for the first time since the war before Christmas wants to argue that this government cannot show what those employment figures really are. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very significant that we have heard a minor member of the coalition parties, with their leader in this place, talking about competition policy acting as a vacuum cleaner sucking jobs out of the bush.
—Oh, come on. We are being criticised for doing nothing and now we are criticised for doing something. Make up your mind.

—Senator Boswell, your comments are very valid and speak volumes about the problems the Liberal Party are experiencing. They are quite happy to argue and disagree with us when we try to tell them things, but when their own side, their own junior partner in coalition, tries to warn them about the way they are handling particular issues, they take absolutely no notice.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell has been quite correct in some of his concerns. He is voicing the concerns that his constituency out there in the bush are feeling and saying to him. We have only to look at the public comments that came out of the recent National Party conference. It was very clearly expressed that the concerns the National Party grassroots members have are that they are being treated like doormats, to use the term that has been thrown around here fairly freely today.

They are feeling very angry at what the Liberal Party of the coalition are doing, at how they are riding roughshod—one has to admit—over those who represent areas of the bush. These are people who are living out there. I am getting the same comments from the National Party grassroots when I move around my country areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they talk to you?
—Yes, they do talk to me, Senator Boswell. I know also that that is what members of the grassroots Labor Party are saying.
—Have you their names? Come on; name them.

—There are not many of them; they are reducing because of what the Liberals are doing to you. I am also getting the same feedback from my own party members out there in the bush, that the Liberal Party—not the coalition; they are very clear to make the distinction—does not care what is happening out there. The Liberal Party are the ones who are ignoring what those of us on this side are saying is affecting the bush and what their own side, from the National Party, are saying is affecting the bush.
—He wants a GST.

—Yes, a GST was another concern they raised. Let us look at what this coalition has done. The National Party—in fact, it was a National Party minister who presided over it—allowed the abolition of the department of regional development. I am told in estimates, `Oh, no, Senator, we have not abolished the department.' They only got rid of 214 staff out of 220. They have reduced their budget to $5 million, and they do not know the criteria for the distribution of that.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what this government has allowed to happen. This obviously is why members of the National Party and Senator Boswell are very concerned about what is happening. When they have their own people presiding over the abolition of regional development departments, one has to be very concerned.
They have also presided over cuts to the ABC, and we know that those cuts are going to impact on rural areas. That is of major concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what did you do to the ABC, especially in rural areas?
—Expanded it, you dope. But look what you have done to Triple J.

—We know that they are presiding over cuts to universities, and that includes regional and rural universities. We are seeing large staff cuts to those institutions. The other thing that they have done to universities and institutions is to tier HECS and increase HECS costs.

SPEECH.PARA: What they have done with the tiering of HECS is to place agriculture in the second tier. One of the prime things the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), in the finance summit earlier in this session of government, did was to point out the high priority for improving education to the agricultural sector in this community. What have they done? They have stuck agriculture in the second tier, making it more expensive for people in rural areas to gain agricultural expertise. That was done, of course, by a Liberal minister. Their National Party minister made the point that education is vitally important to agricultural areas.

I have not misunderstood it. I understand it very clearly because I understand the concerns out there. We now see the latest round of attacks on people in rural areas with the potential cuts to Medicare offices. They will not tell us under what criteria or where they will occur, or anything further about it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to get up to debate this issue but, having listened to the utter confusion which has emerged from the frontbench of the Labor Party, I felt that it was worth responding to a little bit. I was interested to note that when Senator Cook spoke he did acknowledge that there was—as I mentioned in my answer—a bipartisan approach to competition policy, which was not apparent from the question he posed to me. When I reminded him of that in my answer, he felt—quite rightly- that he had to address that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: He would be aware that there was a lot of activity in this area under the Labor Party, which I do not think you referred to, Senator West, in your remarks. I listened very carefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about some other issues, things you are doing in the bush.

—I wonder whether I should not remind you, Senator West, of your government's attitude to the national competition policy. Of course, our government is strongly committed to fostering competition in markets for goods and services. Three competition policy intergovernmental agreements were entered into by the Commonwealth, states and territories in—wait for it, Senator West—April 1995 at the Council of Australian Government's meeting. These were the conduct code agreement, the competition principles agreement and the agreement to implement the national competition policy and related reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not forget, Senator West, that not so long ago your ministers were extolling the benefits of national competition policy. Then we had the slight back‐away from Senator Cook who decided that he really could not back away. So he stood up after question time and attempted to correct the record and make it clear that it was a bipartisan approach. Then he softened once again at the end when he was worried about the jobs issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about what you are doing to the bush.

—Senator West, there are two reasons why you are worried about rural and regional Australia. One is that you barely hold a seat in this area. The electors looked at your lot after 13 years and decided what a hopeless bunch of people you are, with no interest in the interests of rural people. I know, Senator West, you are one of the few people on your side—I acknowledge this— who will get up and attempt to speak on behalf of rural and regional Australia. Regrettably, you do not do it all that well, but I acknowledge that it is an interest, unlike the shadow minister for primary industry who, as Senator Herron has reminded us, has barely asked a question in this area. I understand your concern. If I were you, Senator West, I would try to convince your own party room to take an interest in regional and rural issues. That is what I would do.

SPEECH.PARA: My final point is that there was an attempt to quote Senator Boswell. I naturally said that I am loath to accept any quotes which are forthcoming on the chance that they may be slightly selective and may leave out something important. Senator Boswell informed me that he said of the same program that there were benefits out of a national competition policy. That was actually missed in the question. It has, again, been a very poor performance by the Labor Party. They are flip flopping all over the place. Senator West, do you support national competition policy, or not? Senator Cook thinks he does. He thinks it should be bipartisan. No‐one who listened to your remarks could draw any conclusion other than that you are utterly opposed to national competition policy. If that is not the case, you should now stand up and correct the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp is correct. It was a bipartisan approach in relation to competition policy and I think that is the problem. There was almost no debate during the time. I have to say that Senator Boswell is being absolutely consistent. I sat in the hearings with Senator Boswell who asked numerous questions of those giving evidence to the inquiry, expressing the concern of rural and regional Australia. Unfortunately, in the case of the National Party it did not follow through to the point of them standing up for that position in the Senate when it was voted on, as did the Greens.

PARA.BREAK: The situation is that we are now beginning to see what governments in the states can and will do with competition policy. We are now beginning to see the huge amount of power that we have given to the Australian Competi tion and Consumer Commission. It is like a monster for which there is no real control at this stage. We are beginning to see questions of very narrow definition of public interest which go round in a circle and say, `The public interest is competition; therefore, the public interest is competition.' We end up with a situation where other human values in society do not get a guernsey.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, at the end of that committee process, short though it was for competition policy, the response from the committee was that the committee recommends that the bill be passed without amendment. That is a real pity because we are now beginning to see in state elections all throughout the country that, where there are conservative governments, you get the ALP in those states criticising the implementation of competition policy because they can see how much damage it can have and how different it can be between perceptions of public interest, the reality—outcomes for people, for services, employment—and the impact on rural and regional Australia.

It is time for us to revisit this. The fact that we are having this debate is at least a useful step, but we all have to admit that it was pushed through last year. In this chamber in July last year some of us thought that we should not have been pushing it through. Others thought it should not have been in that form, but the reality is it is a time bomb which will be ticking up until 1998 and, unless there are specific exemptions for federal, state and local government, that time bomb will go off in 1998. All of those areas of public service provisions—outsourcing, privatisation and so on—will occur by that date unless we as a Senate go back and look at the monster we have created, to see what the problems are before it is too late. My plea is now that we have more of these debates. Instead of attacking Senator Boswell for the way he did not vote, at least applaud him for having the guts to stand up and speak for what a lot of people are saying in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the value of that if he doesn't match it with a vote?
—I have to say, if you were to ask a number of people in the Labor Party, at the time that competition policy went through they were equally concerned but we didn't see them voting that way either.
—Really? Who were they?
—Who were the concerned ones?
—So there was nobody in the Australian Labor Party concerned about competition policy.
—Name them.
—I know because the ALP does not let those people speak up in those instances.
—Really?

—I will be happy to take the word of the ALP that there was absolutely nobody in their caucus who was concerned about that. I have been challenged to name them. The point is that they would not be allowed to come into this chamber and express those concerns because it would break solidarity. Let us not pretend there was absolute agreement on this. Let us now take the opportunity to have that debate and deal with the issues that are coming up so that we can deal with them before this time bomb goes off in 1998.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate was initiated by a statement that I made at the federal National Party conference. I did make the statement that Senator Cook said I made. But, when I was addressing the motion at the National Party conference, I also said that the Hilmer competition policy would deliver benefits. I want that to go clearly on the record. I have always said that competition does deliver benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that the Hilmer competition policy is a huge policy document that is almost as long as a piece of string. What I was saying to the state delegates, the state members of parliament and the state ministers was, `Watch it,' because you can take the sting out of the Hilmer competition policy.

BREAK.PARA: The implementation of the Hilmer competition policy will fall mainly on the state governments. The state governments can offer exemptions on some industries—particularly newsagents and chemists and some of the primary industries such as the dairy industry and the sugar industry. What I was saying to the state governments was, `You can take the sting out of the competition policy; it is within your power as state governments and members of state governments to do that.' That is the direction I took. I acknowledged that there were problems for the bush, but I did say that there would be benefits flowing for them as well.

Senator Cook used my statement in the campaign for the forthcoming state government election in Western Australia. Senator Cook then praised the National Party for everything we had done. The other side of the ALP then decided that we had been treated like doormats. Neither is the case. This National Party works with the Liberal Party in a position of coalition unity. I want that to go clearly on the record.

Senator Cook decided that the best way to go is to divide and rule. We have been accused by one person of being the tail that wags the dog and then by someone else of being the doormat. Let us not go down that track. The reality is that the National Party does work in a harmonious way with the Liberal Party. To show a few things that we have achieved as a coalition, only a couple of weeks ago $82 million went in to extend the drought relief package. That was of great benefit to many—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who set the program up, Ron?

—Who set the program up? I acknowledge, and I will always acknowledge, that you did. But who put the interest rates up to 23 per cent, which dragged the farmers down and sucked out all the equity in their properties so that they needed some financial handouts?
—John Howard did that in 1981‐82.

—Sure, you gave them the financial handouts, but it was you who backed them into the position that originally caused the problem. No amount of twisting or tap dancing around will take away from that. You were the people who put the interest rates of farmers up to 23 per cent. You were the ones who broke their backs and then you came along with a rescue package when all else failed.

BREAK.PARA: When the people of Australia were making contributions through television programs you were embarrassed and had to come to the party. When Channel 9 raised $18 million through its farmhand appeal, you guys had put in nothing, not one cent. When people were on charity, you were so embarrassed that Channel 9 was doing your job that you raced into the Prime Minister and said, `I can't cop it any longer.' That is how they did get some benefits. Never forget that you were the ones who broke their backs with high interest rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party has consistently been used as a doormat by the Liberals since the election. If ever I saw proof of it, it was the doorstop interview done by the Leader of the National Party, Mr Tim Fischer, the Deputy Prime Minister, on the diesel fuel rebate scheme. He rushed out to the side door of the ministerial wing entrance—to the great chagrin, I am told, of many regional members of the Liberal Party—and claimed the entire credit for the National Party. He said that it was a huge victory for the National Party to save the diesel fuel rebate scheme after five months of destabilising public debate when it was under real threat. So the great victory of the National Party was to protect against the Liberal Party a program which the Labor Party had kept in place in its whole 13 years of government. What a huge victory, Senator Boswell!

SPEECH.PARA: But have a look at what has happened since. In response to an interjection from Senator Panizza, which was responded to by Senator Schacht, about what we did to the ABC when we were in government, I say to him that we expanded the services of the ABC. Do not be such an ignoramus! To my great chagrin, as Senator Schacht said quite correctly, programs which we funded in government to expand the services of the ABC in places like the Northern Territory have since been axed by this government. Go and talk to the people in the small communities in the Northern Territory who were really looking forward to getting Triple J, which we had announced and funded, but who will now not get it because the expansion program has been axed. That is one thing the National Party should not have let the Liberals get away with.

I will tell you, Senator Boswell, the other thing the National Party should not have let them get away with—axing the BARA program, which I referred to in question time today in a question to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), who has nothing to do with this portfolio despite what he thinks.

The business advice for rural areas program was a highly successful program that this government put into place. In an assessment that was made of the last financial year alone, it created an estimated 1,400 jobs in country Australia and set up a huge number of small businesses. I saw the work the BARA office did in the town of Katherine in the Northern Territory. It delivered great value for money. But what did this government do? It abolished it in the budget. It closed it down. A service that rural Australia once got and that measurably provided benefits is now being removed from rural Australia.

Last Friday, the minister for aboriginal affairs, in what he himself described as a major speech outlining new directions for Aboriginal affairs in Australia, recommended the BARA scheme, the business advice in rural areas scheme, to Aboriginal Australians to help them start up small businesses so they would not be unemployed. And this is a minister of a government which axed it in the budget and closed it down. Then, when the minister went on Meet the Press last night and had that very proposition put to him by Paul Bongiorno—you suggested last Friday, Minister, that Aboriginal people should access the BARA scheme, but you have closed it down—he said, `Yes, but I am going to talk to ATSIC about some interim funding for it. It was a decision the ATSIC board made to close it down.' This is straight off the top of the head. This is a minister who, on every single day that passes here in the Senate, demonstrates that he knows nothing whatever about his portfolio; in fact, he is indicating not even the slightest interest in learning anything.

For three days this nonsense has been perpetuated. The BARA scheme in fact is administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It was not a decision of the ATSIC board—how could it have been?—to close it down. It was a decision of that portfolio and its minister to close it down. To suggest, as the minister did last night, that ATSIC would divert funding into the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to keep a program going that they have lost is utter nonsense!

You closed the BARA scheme down. You closed down the expansion of the ABC into rural Australia, and you closed down the entire department of regional development. And what did your minister say? He made the most astonishing statement out of Canberra that I, coming from regional Australia, have seen in 20 years in this business. He said there is `no rationale or constitutional basis for the Commonwealth's involvement in regional development in Australia'. That is in his press statement. Where does that statement leave the National Party?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza, you have about one minute.

—Yes. I will make use of that one minute to respond to Senator Bob Collins's statement about the interjection I made about cutting ABC radio services. I meant what I said about the ABC short‐wave service into the north‐west of Western Australia, and particularly the Pilbara and the Kimberley. I wish Senator Collins had listened to what I said. They left an area bigger than the size of New South Wales without basic radio services. I know it is in the towns, but in between the towns it is non‐existent and they had had that service since 1936. That service used to extend right out to sea, halfway across and beyond the Northern Territory from Western Australia, and the ships used to use it as well.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

the strong opposition of residents of the City of Burnside in South Australia to the proposed roll‐out of overhead cables within our city, based on the impact upon residential amenity, our local streetscapes and environment.

Your petitioners request that the Senate should:

The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose the cuts to Childcare Assistance available for holiday absences for families who use long day care centres.

These cuts, which both the Liberal/National Coalition and the ALP support, reduce the amount of Childcare Assistance previously paid by the Government to parents for allowable holiday absences by half.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate reverse its support for these regressive changes to Childcare Assistance.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Lees (from 20 citizens)and Senator Woodley (from 69 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Provider Numbers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the Government's intention to legislate to restrict the issuing of Medicare provider numbers to doctors.

We consider that such an action would cause serious suffering, including a severe disadvantage to women, rural communities and medical research. We believe that it is the essential right of all Australian registered doctors to have access to provider numbers that allow them to provide services to the community which attract Medicare rebates for patients. We believe that such restrictions are an attack on the most defenceless and vulnerable strata of the medical profession. We consider it to be a denial of natural justice and an attack on Medicare.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should:

undertake an inquiry into the proposed restrictions on the provision of Medicare provider numbers and alternative measures to resolve the problems facing Medicare and the Australian medical workforce; and

call upon the Federal Minister for Health, The Hon Michael Wooldridge MP, to not proceed with the proposed restrictions on the provision of Medicare provider numbers to doctors and to enter into discussions with representatives of the medical profession to identify alternative measures to resolve the problems facing Medicare and the Australian medical workforce.

Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: Statement of reasons for introduction and passage in 1996 Spring Sittings
Wool International Amendment Bill
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Wool International Act 1993 to provide for changes to the fixed schedule for disposal of stockpile wool by Wool International.
Reasons for Urgency

The proposed amendments provide for implementation of changes to the fixed disposal schedule for stockpile wool from 1 January 1997 as recommended by the August Wool Roundtable, chaired by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and with all sectors of the wool industry joining a consensus in favour of the proposal.
Effect if the Bill is not passed this sitting

The decision on the changes to the fixed schedule has been taken after extensive consultation with the wool industry both domestically and internationally. If the changes are not implemented by 1 January 1997, the industry, and woolgrowers in particular, will potentially face a more depressed market due to greater quantities of stockpile wool having to be sold by Wool International in compliance with the current legislative requirements. Because of both the industry consultation process and the Roundtable consensus being public, a failure to implement the changes on time is likely to prompt strong negative reactions, particularly from growers, but also from the majority of Australia's overseas customers.
Why the amendments were not foreseen

Amendments to the fixed schedule were initially expected to be implemented from 1 July 1997. This was the date by which Wool International had been intended to be privatised. Wool International is not now expected to be privatised but rather is to continue to manage the disposal of the stockpile.

The August Wool Roundtable recommended to the Government that the fixed disposal schedule be changed at the earliest possible date. As part of a negotiated package with a minority of processors who wanted a later implementation, a phased introduction of the changes was agreed by consensus to apply from 1 January 1997.
Circulated with the Authority of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
