SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to make three or four minutes of general comment, and then, as I have indicated on previous schedules, in order to facilitate the program, I am going to incorporate some seven or eight pages of specific comments. Schedule 7, termination of employment, proves once and for all that the government's pre-election hysteria about unfair dismissal laws was nothing but a giant beat-up. The hypocrisy of the government, which this schedule shows, is staggering.

SPEECH.PARA: The most fundamental point about the government's amendments to our unfair dismissal laws is that the substance of the law—the substantive provisions which will be applied in determining whether a dismissal was unfair—is basically unchanged. Remember the hysteria about the so-called requirement for the employer to give the employee a warning before dismissal? Well, it is still there, Senator Campbell. Why?

Section 170CG will require the commission to consider whether there was a valid reason for the termination related to the conduct of the employee, whether the employee was notified of that reason and whether the employee was given an opportunity to respond to that reason. Not only that; the commission is required to consider whether the employee was warned—yes, the word `warned' is used—about any unsatisfactory performance before the termination. I have no doubt there will be many lawyers advising employers that they must still give an employee a warning before dismissal if they are not to fall foul of these laws.

But do not get us wrong: we support these provisions. But the point is that it was this need for a warning that was the centrepiece for the then Liberal opposition's campaign of hysteria about the unfair dismissal laws. Yet it is still there, just as the substance of the unfair dismissal laws has basically been unchanged. And the government knows this.

It is interesting that the hysteria about unfair dismissal laws is no longer around, yet our laws continue in effect. Where are all the callers to talkback radio about absurd results under the unfair dismissal laws? Where are the employer groups' rantings—I use that word cautiously, but there was a lot of ranting on this issue—that terminations are being continually challenged under our unfair dismissal laws? Where are they? There are none, because in January 1996 we got the unfair dismissal laws basically right.

No wonder the government are not really changing the substance of the law. They know there is no need to. No wonder the government refused to take up the Democrats' offer in May or June this year to immediately deal with the government's amendments to the unfair dismissal laws. What is the rush when you are not really doing anything, Senator Murray? I notice that you even smiled on this point.

No wonder the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) in the other place refused to guarantee that under his unfair dismissal laws more jobs would be created in small business in the next three years than the half a million created during the last three years of the Labor government. How could he when he knows this law is not really that different?
The truth is now out, and nowhere has the truth been plainer than in the recent annual report of the Industrial Relations Court of Australia. In that report, the chief justice noted:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the controversy about the unlawful termination provisions was fuelled by a degree of deliberate misrepresentation.
On concerns about an increasing filing rate of unlawful termination claims, he said:

. . . it became apparent during 1995-96 that the filing rate would not continue to increase . . . Even taking into account termination applications made to State tribunals, it is apparent that only a tiny proportion of dismissals result in litigation.
Just under two per cent, in fact. As to the alleged effects of unfair dismissal laws on small business, the chief justice noted:
Respondents also are a cross-section of Australian employers, except that small business seems to be under‐represented.

As I have said, given this truth, it is no wonder the substance of the government's new laws is basically no different. There are going to be a lot of disappointed people out there who thought the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, was going to abolish the unfair dismissal laws.

So why won't we vote for these laws? Because, in two important ways not related to the substance of the laws, they are grossly unfair to employees. And we will be moving amendments to address this unfairness.

Firstly, the new unfair dismissal laws will apply only in the traditional federal jurisdiction. We know this was always a great concern for the Democrats—particularly to Senator Allison, and I hope she is listening up there somewhere—because they knew many employees would be thrown back to state unfair dismissal systems. In the case of Victoria, that would mean those employees would be considerably worse off.

We would be tempted to have a Senator Allison amendment, but we have made a point in the last weeks in respect of Senators Stott Despoja and Murray—and, in your case, Senator Murray, we have done that on seven or eight occasions. Having regard to the time and our manner of handling this matter, we will not be quite so harsh with the Australian Democrats this week. But we did win one vote this morning, Senator Murray.

The problem of the federal jurisdiction has now been cured by the Kennett government's decision to give its industrial relations powers, including over unfair dismissal, to the federal government. How ironic it is. This simply achieves the universal coverage that we have long been calling for and that our amendments seek to achieve. We ought to call these the Jeff Kennett amendments, but we could never name amendments of ours after Jeff Kennett.

But why confine the solution only to Victorians? Have the Democrats, particularly Senators Kernot and Woodley, considered that the Borbidge government may yet gut Queensland's unfair dismissal laws? What happens then to those employees, with no access to the federal system, and a lousy state system? We should address the problem now so that it cannot arise in the future in any jurisdiction.

Secondly, the government and the Democrats have retained the requirement for the commission to consider the viability of the employer's business before making a compensation order. We are utterly opposed to this decision. It discriminates between employees. It discriminates between employers. In fact, successful employers are penalised. If your business is a dud, you effectively get an exemption from unfair dismissal laws. But, if your business is a success, you get the unfair dismissal laws applying in full.

That the Democrats would support this fundamental unfairness is a real surprise—although, given what has been happening in the last two weeks, perhaps it is not a real surprise. We can only surmise that the Democrats no longer believe they have a constituency amongst small business, confirming something we have always known.

As I said in my introduction, there are a considerable number of comments the opposition could make on each of these amendments. Some of my colleagues will be speaking on them. I seek leave to incorporate seven or eight pages of comments about the amendments to this schedule.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

These amendments are consequential on the removal of the proposed operation of the unfair dismissal provisions in reliance on the external affairs power (see Govt/Dems (36)). For reasons that have been (will be) explained the Opposition is opposed to this removal and therefore is opposed to these amendments.

The Bill provides that, if a law of a State enacts the "termination of employment" Part as State law, the State law may give the Commission and the Court relevant functions and powers in respect of Federal award employees employed in the State. These amendments make this applicable to all employees employed in the State. This is consequential on the Opposition's extension of the Bill's unfair dismissal provisions to all employees (see Opp (68)).
This amendment is to exactly the same effect as Opp (67), which of course the Government voted against in the House of Representatives. The Opposition therefore supports this amendment.
Given Govt/Dems (33) the Opposition no longer moves this amendment.
The Opposition will support this amendment because it is an improvement on the Bill as originally drafted.

These amendments provide that an object of the "Termination of Employment" Division and of the "Unlawful Termination" Subdivision is to give effect to the Termination of Employment Convention (not just to assist in giving effect to that Convention, as provided in the Bill). The Opposition believes that the Act must be (and must state that it is) the means by which Australia's international obligations concerning termination of employment and unlawful termination are implemented.

These amendments give practical effect to this by providing that Subdivisions B, C, D and E of the Bill apply to employees for the purposes of giving effect to the Termination of Employment Convention

The Opposition does not support this amendment because it actually makes the Bill even worse then originally drafted. Originally Subdivision B (harsh, unjust or unreasonable termination) was to apply to all Federal award employees. Now, under this amendment, Subdivision B will only apply to Federal award employees who are employed by constitutional corporations or who are waterside or are employed in the course of interstate or international trade. The Opposition believes that, far from narrowing the coverage of federal unfair dismissal laws, the coverage should be widened (see Opp (69)).

These amendments provide that Subdivision B applies to all employees. As I have already explained, the Opposition believes that it is vital that the Federal unfair dismissal system be available to all employees. If not many employees will have to rely on State unfair dismissal systems. Some State systems are inferior to the Federal system. Where an existing State systems is adequate, there is no guarantee a State Government won't amend it to make it inferior.

In the event that the coverage provided by Opp (69) is found to be invalid, we provide as a fallback that Subdivisions B applies to employees employed by a constitutional corporation and by the Commonwealth, in a Territory, and as waterside workers, maritime employees and flight crew officers. We do this in case our extended coverage to all employees is held constitutionally invalid. There needs to be a fallback which is more likely to be constitutional. The coverage provided here—the traditional Federal jurisdiction—is more likely to be constitutional (and is still wider than that provided in the amended Bill).

This amendment is to the same effect as Opp (70) and (71), but it is being moved by the Government/Democrats and Opposition respectively for entirely different reasons. The Government/Democrats move the amendment to remove the provision which places reliance on the external affairs power for the operation of the unfair dismissal provisions. The Opposition moves the amendment because, as a technical matter, the provision is not necessary because Opp (73) and (74) effectively reinstates it. The Opposition's amendments as a whole continue to place reliance on the external affairs power for the operation of the unfair dismissal provisions.
The Opposition therefore only supports this amendment for the technical reason, not because it supports the removal of reliance on the external affairs power.
The reasons for these amendments has been explained at Govt/Dems (36). Given Govt/Dems (36) these amendments are no longer necessary and the Opposition will not move them.
The Bill provides that the regulations may exclude certain classes of employees from the operation of the Act. These amendments amend these classes in the following way:

(b) Employees serving a probation or qualifying period, determined in advance and of reasonable duration (the Bill excludes the latter qualification). If there is no requirement for the probationary period to be of reasonable duration an employer could put all new employees on extended probations so as to avoid the Act. This also reflects the terms of the Termination Convention.

(d) Employees who are subject to provisions which on the whole provide protection equivalent to the protection afforded under the Convention (not just employees with special arrangements providing particular protection, as provided in the Bill). The regulations should not be able to exclude employees from the Act unless those employees have through another source effectively the same protections as provided by the Act. This also reflects the terms of the Termination Convention.

(e) Employees in respect of which special problems of a substantial nature arise because of their employment conditions or because of the size or nature of their employer's undertaking (not just employees in respect of which the operation of the provisions would cause substantial problems because of these reasons, as provided in the Bill). This reflects the terms of the Termination Convention.

The Bill also provides that the regulations may exclude from the operation of the Act non‐award employees who are paid on the basis of commission or piece rates. These amendments delete this provision. It is unfair that employees may be excluded from the protections of the Act simply because they are paid on the basis of commission or piece rates.

The Bill provides that the regulations may exclude from the operation of the provisions terminations of employment relating to succession, assignment or transmission of the employer's business. These amendments delete this provision. An employee should not be deprived of the protections of the Act simply because ownership of the business that employs the person changes hands.
This amendment is consequential on Opp (69). If Opp (69) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.

The Opposition accepts that these amendments, which allow applications to be made to the Commission in relation to unlawful termination (as well as harsh, unjust or unreasonable termination), are an improvement to the original Bill. The Opposition will therefore vote in support of these amendments.

This amendment provides that the Commission can accept an application made out of time if it considers it would be reasonable to do so (not only if it would not be unfair to do so, as provided in the Bill). The Opposition believes that the requirement that it not be unfair to accept a late application (rather than it being reasonable) is too high when the consequences of refusing a late application are so serious (ie. no recourse at all).

These amendments insert a new provision which requires an employer to give written notification or confirmation of termination to an employee. Verbal notice of termination is often unsatisfactory. It can create disputes about when the termination occurred (and therefore about when an application for unfair dismissal must be brought) and about the terms of the termination. It is not too onerous to simply ask an employer to give an employee some written notice of his or her dismissal.

Consequent on this new provision these amendments also provide that an application to the Commission must be lodged within 21 days of receipt of that notice (not just within 21 days of the termination taking effect, as provided in the Bill).

On balance the Opposition believes these amendments are an improvement on the original Bill. We do have some concerns with the provisions. For example, the requirement for the Commission to give an assessment of the merits may prejudice the outcome in some circumstances. The automatic discontinuance in the absence of an election by the applicant may also be harsh in some instances. Nevertheless, the Opposition accepts the overall thrust of the provisions. The greater emphasis on a conciliated outcome is welcome, as is the choice for certain applicants to pursue arbitration rather than court proceedings. Given this, the Opposition will vote in support of these amendments.

The Opposition will not vote for this amendment. Although it is in some ways an improvement on the existing Bill, we are strongly opposed to the need for the Commission to take into account the viability of the employer's business. As I have previously explained this is an unfair provision. It discriminates against employees on the basis of the viability of their employer. It penalises successful employers. There is no area of law where this principle of compensation has been introduced.
The Opposition supports these amendments because they improve the existing Bill.

For the reasons already explained the Opposition os opposed to any provision that requires the Commission to have regard to the viability of the employer's undertaking. This amendment therefore deletes these provisions.
The Opposition supports this amendment because it is an improvement on this existing bill.

These amendments provide that, for an award employee, the maximum amount of compensation payable is the amount the employee would have received in the 6 months after the termination (not the amount the employee did receive in the 6 months before the termination, as provided in the Bill). The Opposition notes that the basic principle of compensation for wrong is that the person receives what he or she would have received but for the wrong. In the termination of employment context this means (and has always meant) that employees receive as compensation the pay they would have received had they not been terminated (not the pay they did receive before termination).

These amendments also provide that, for a non‐award employee, the maximum amount of compensation payable is $30,000 as indexed from time to time (not the lesser of this amount or the amount which would be payable if the employee was covered by s170CH(8), as provided in the Bill). The maximum amount payable should be fixed, not vary depending on the amount of pay received before termination.
The Opposition seeks to delete the costs provision in its entirety (see Opp (86)), and so we will not support these amendments to those provisions.

The Bill provides the Commission with power to order costs in certain circumstances. This amendment deletes this provision. We The Opposition accepts the existing law provides for the awarding of costs by the Court in unfair dismissal cases heard by it. But the Commission has never been a costs jurisdiction. Even though the Commission will now hear unfair dismissal cases under this Bill it should still not become a costs jurisdiction.

This amendment provides that the Court can accept an application, about an alleged contravention of a provision, lodged after this time if it considers it would be reasonable to do so (not only if it would not be unfair to do so, as provided in the Bill). I have already explained why this amendment is appropriate (see Opp (80)).

The Bill provides that the Commission may not make an order under Subdivision D (orders giving effect to the Convention) or E (orders after employer fails to consult) if an alternative remedy exists. These amendments require that alternative remedy to be adequate. The Opposition believes that before the Commission is compelled not to grant a remedy because an alternative remedy is available it should be required to ensure that the alternative remedy is adequate. Otherwise the Commission may be precluded from granting a superior remedy simply because an inferior remedy is available.

These amendments insert a provision which makes ineffective any award or order of the Commission which is inconsistent with the requirements of the Termination Convention (this provision is in the existing Act). This ensures that all employees are entitled to the protections afforded by the Act.

These amendments propose modifications consistent with the amendments under which all applications will commence in the Commission. The Opposition supported those amendments and so supports these amendments.

The amended Bill permits an application concerning or including harsh, unjust and unreasonable termination to be made either under this Act or under the law of a State or Territory, but not under both (unless one of the applications failed for want of jurisdiction). These amendments apply this also to applications under a State award. This provision should also apply to employees who make an application concerning harsh, unjust and unreasonable termination under a State award.
Given Govt/Dems (57) this amendment is no longer relevant and the Opposition does not move it.

The Bill permits an application concerning unlawful termination to be made either under this Act or under the law of a State or Territory, but not under both (unless one of the applications failed for want of jurisdiction). These amendments apply this also to applications under a State award. The same reasons as at Opp (95) and (97) apply.

The Opposition accepts these amendments as an improvement on the original Bill. Indeed this amendment is to the same effect as Opp (100) which of course the Government voted against when moved in the House of Representatives.
Given Govt/Dems (62) this amendment is no longer necessary and the Opposition does not move it.
The Opposition accepts this amendment because it improves the original Bill.
The Opposition doubts the necessity fro this amendment but will nevertheless vote in support of it.

The Bill repeals the scheduling to the Act of the ILO "Recommendation concerning discrimination in respect of employment and occupation", the ILO "Recommendation concerning termination of employment at the initiative of the employer" and the ILO "Recommendation concerning equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women workers: Workers with family responsibilities". These amendments delete this repeal. The Opposition believes that t he Act must be the means by which these international conventions are implemented. This requires, as a matter of substance and perception, that they be scheduled to the Act.
The Opposition assumes these amendments will no longer be moved.
The Opposition will not vote in support of this amendment if the Opposition's amendments to Schedule 7 have been agreed to.
The Opposition supports both of these amendments because they improve upon the original Bill even as amended.
The Opposition's preferred position is dealt with as Opp (75)—(77) and (89), and on this basis we will not vote in support of this amendment.
This amendment is to the same effect as Opp (79) and (88) and the Opposition will support it on that basis.
This amendment is to the same effect as Opp (81) and (82) and the Opposition will support it on that basis.
The Opposition supports this amendment because it improves the original Bill.
The Opposition does not support this amendment for reasons that have been previously explained.
The Opposition's preferred position on this matter is taken up by Opp (98) and (99) and we will not support these amendments on that basis.
The Opposition supports this amendment because it improves the original Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Fundamentally, the Greens are opposed to the changes in this bill which amend the `termination of employment' provision in the existing Industrial Relations Act. We will oppose the entire schedule 7. Hence, I signal that we intend to move our amendment 28. I see that that amendment is right at the end. I would have liked it to have been moved to the beginning, because we have a number of alternative amendments which can be dealt with only after we see what the outcome of the opposition to the schedule is. But, fundamentally, we are opposed to the changes to the act.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to have been a lot of rhetoric flying around about the unfair dismissal measure. Why we oppose this element of the bill is largely due to the fact that the most recent changes to these provisions did not take effect until 15 January 1996. They have not yet had a chance to be properly evaluated. The position of the Chief Justice of the Industrial Relations Court of Australia, Justice Murray Wilcox, is interesting to note. He refuted claims made during the election campaign that the unfair dismissal provisions were so onerous that people in small business were reluctant to hire people. On 27 February 1996, on ABC radio's PM program he stated:

We meet regularly in the court with representatives of both employers and employees to review the way the court administers its affairs, and business groups suggest that things are working very smoothly.
On the previous night on the 7.30 Report , Justice Wilcox made some interesting comments when asked whether the laws as they stood were at odds with good business. He stated:

They are at odds with bad business, and the problem is that there are too many bad managers who do not have enough respect for their employees and there are people that suffer awards against them. I mean, really, you would be appalled at some of the cases.
The case in Australia is a bit like some aspects of the Native Title Act, in that in some states and in some jurisdictions there might be a political interest to be able to freely sack employees.

There have been moves against allowing this model to work well, and it can work well. It is unfortunate that the ALP have some amendments to the bill, and it is also unfortunate that the opposition to a certain extent have gone along with some of the rhetoric rather than the nature of the situation. It is our belief that it has not been given a chance to work properly. It is our belief that, in some instances, there may be people who are endeavouring to make it look as if it is not working properly.

In reality, we will not suddenly get thousands of people hiring people on this basis alone. If they hire on the basis that they think they will be able to dismiss people unfairly, perhaps we will need to revisit this situation. There are certain details regarding whether or not the financial situation of a company should determine whether they need to obey the law. It has certainly never been the case with people who end up being charged with social security fraud if in some instances they have absolutely no choice except to try to survive.

PARA.BREAK: It has certainly not been the case in many other laws of which I know that the financial circumstances of the person involved determines whether or not they act lawfully. If a company is in trouble, there are ways that the company can act if they need to shed staff. They can talk with their staff. However, that should not mean that a company gets an exemption to treat their staff badly. I do not think it should be read that way. Unfortunate ly, I think that is what will be read as a result of what we are going through today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some remarks regarding the proposals in this workplace relations bill as they relate to unfair dismissal. We have all heard the saying, `There are lies, damned lies and statistics.' One of the great lies that has been perpetrated in recent years is the one put about that the unfair dismissal laws, as enacted by the previous Labor government and amended more recently, were a barrier to employment growth. This catchcry was taken up and promulgated mainly by big business, not the small business community. Small business was out there generally getting on with the job. It was taken up by large companies, by employer and business associations, by the Liberal and National parties, by conservative commentators and by talkback radio hosts.

SPEECH.PARA: It was blurted out day after day that these unfair dismissal laws were preventing employers from employing additional people. It was put that this was particularly the case in the small business sector. My recollection of what transpired during the Senate inquiry was that very little evidence was put before that committee by small business people that went to this issue. We have heard this cry for so long now that it has almost become a self‐fulfilling prophecy.

Unfortunately, people believed the perception rather than the facts. They listened to the rhetoric, to the hyperbole, that, if only you got rid of the unfair dismissal laws, if only you made it easier to sack people, you would somehow generate more employment. As a matter of logic, it does not stand up. I often listened to the talkback radio hosts, who seem to be experts at everything but particularly about the supposed ills of the industrial relations system. They proposed that what was needed in this country to enable more employment growth was to make it easier for employers to sack people. That defies any rational logic in my view.

But let us look at the facts. Let us look at some of the statistics because on this occasion the statistics tell the truth. They put the lie to the damned lies promulgated out there by those who oppose these laws which were about protecting ordinary wage and salary earners in their employment. I refer particularly to an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 February 1996 called `Fair and unfair dismissals'. This has never been a paper renowned for its great support of either the Labor Party or the labour movement, but this is what the editorial said:
Statistics released by the Industrial Relations Court in December—
that is, December 1995—

suggest that the operation of the law has not been as onerous as commonly implied. In 1994‐95, 87 per cent of the 7,749 unfair dismissal claims lodged that financial year were either settled or discontinued before determination by the court and another 4 per cent were settled or discontinued before the determination process had started. Of those determined by the court, 56 per cent were decided in the employee's favour and 44 per cent in favour of the employer. And in the 219 cases where compensation was awarded, 74 per cent involved amounts less than $10,000, about 22 per cent involved amounts between $10,000 and $20,000, and less than 4 per cent involved amounts of $20,000 or more.
This suggests that much of the criticism of the law has stemmed from perceptions of its operation rather than its practice.

The Sydney Morning Herald editorial has got it right. What we have seen over the last couple of years is a huge beat‐up by the coalition parties and their supporters in the business community. In order to undermine the rights of employees, whether they be trade unionists or not, in this country they had to attack the unfair dismissal laws. That is consistent with the whole philosophy that runs through this bill which is about depriving people of their rights, whether they be award rights, rights in regard to hiring and firing employees or whatever.

Whilst there were a few cases that were highlighted in the press where maybe some employees had been reinstated or the employer may have been hard done by because of the processes involved in the legislation, these were then blown up to suggest that the legislation in total was some overbearing onerous burden upon employers. It was argued that if only we could get rid of it then we would see nirvana, we would see this huge explosion in employment.

Let us have a look at some of the employment figures. I will seek leave to incorporate this document shortly. What do the figures actually tell us? The employment figures for the period March 1994, when the unfair dismissal laws came into effect, to March 1995 actually show a very interesting picture. The source of these figures is the Bureau of Industry Economics.

The figures show that in the small business sector—defined as private enterprises with less than 20 employees, except manufacturing, in which a small business is defined as one with less than 100 employees, and agriculture, in which a small business is defined as one with an estimated value of agricultural operations between $20,000 and $399,000—employment increased from an estimated 3,548,900 in March 1994 to 3,725,100 at the end of the March quarter 1995. That is a net growth of 176,200 employees in the small business sector in the 12 months that the unfair dismissal laws were in operation. That contrasts remarkably with the big business sector, which did not show anywhere near the same growth—and indeed with the public sector, where we saw a decline.

In the 10-year period between June 1985 and March 1995 small business grew in this country by 1.1 million—an extra 1.1 million employees in small business. In the larger business sector employment grew by approximately 410,000. In the public sector employment declined by 168,600. Everyone knows that the obligations with respect to dismissal in the public sector have generally been a lot tighter than they are in the private sector.

Those figures put the lie to this claim that underpins these proposals that somehow the unfair dismissal laws were an impediment to employment. Employment in the small business sector grew faster than in any other sector in the Australian economy. I seek leave to incorporate this document, which was provided by the Parliamentary Library. It is sourced by the Bureau of Industry Economics and sets out employment growth in small business, big business and the public sector in the period that I have referred to.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We, the Australian Democrats, wish to incorporate into Hansard our comments on the government and Democrat amendments to schedule 7, as has Senator Sherry. I seek leave to make a few brief remarks.

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support the thrust of the government's unfair dismissals legislation and the introduction of the fair go all round test. We have negotiated quite a number of amendments to make this approach fairer. In particular we have sought to ensure that unlawful dismissal will commence in the commission by way of conciliation before an election to proceed through the court.

BREAK.PARA: We have sought some changes to the cost regime to make it fairer and more rarely used. We have modified the double jeopardy provisions to broaden the grounds on which a federal application could be pursued to include not only another application failing for want of jurisdiction but also where it has been discontinued.

I wish to also indicate that the Democrats will not be moving the amendments circulated in relation to expanding the federal jurisdiction in this area. This amendment was necessary if the Victorian government did not move its jurisdiction across to the Commonwealth. Given that it has now done so, the amendment is no longer needed. I seek leave to table correspondence in relation to this matter. I have shown it to Senator Sherry and Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you wish to table or incorporate that correspondence, Senator Murray?
—I would like to incorporate my comments but table this correspondence.

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
SCHEDULE 7:
GOVT/DEM 31 & 32:
These are technical amendments necessary to give effect to the new unfair dismissal regime, and I endorse the comments made by the Minister.
OPPOS 65 & 66:

This provision is designed to allow the States to refer all of their responsibilities on unfair dismissal to the Commonwealth. This we think would create a massive burden on the AIRC. At present, the AIRC does not hear claims for states with an adequate alternative remedy. Even still, the number of claims to the Commission have risen massively in recent years. Under this proposal, the number of claims to the Commission could rise even more. The Democrats believe that the State must provide an adequate remedy, and will be moving an amendment to that effect. That is a more appropriate approach than that being pursued by the Opposition with these amendments.
GOVT/DEM 33/OPPOS 67
This is a technical amendment flowing from the High Court decision on the use of the external affairs power to underpin termination of employment. We support his amendment.
GOVT/DEM 34

This amendment seeks to change the objects of the part to reflect subsequent amendments which make it clear that claims for both unfair dismissals and unlawful dismissals (under 170CK) commence in the Commission. Under the bilI as it stood, claims for unlawful dismissal had to commence in the Court where the claim was a matter listed in 170CK. The amended bill will allow all applications to commence in the Commission, with the applicant then deciding at the end of conciliation whether to arbitrate it in the Commission under 170CE or the Court under 170CK. I am happy to jointly move this amendment.

I think these amendments have been superseded by the recent High Court decision. The simple fact is that the provisions of the fair go all round test could not rely on the external affairs power, based on ILO conventions, according to the High Court. As such, these amendments, and the attempt to base these provisions on the ILO is conditionally unsound, and we will oppose them.
GOVT/DEM 35:

These are further technical amendments flowing from the High Court decision and the decision to commence actions for unlawful dismissal in the Commission under subdivision B. I have nothing to add to what the Minister has said, other than to endorse the amendment.

These provisions seek to extend the Federal jurisdiction to all employees using external affairs. As I commented earlier, I believe that is a constitutionally unsound approach, highlighted by the recent High Court case. We will oppose these amendments.
GOVT DEM 36 (same as OPPOS 70 & 71)
This is a further technical amendment flowing on from the last amendment, and the Democrats support it.
OPPOS 75-77

I really don't think that these amendments are necessary. The bill as it stands follows very closely the wording of the ILO Convention in relation to its exemptions. We have been advised that it has the same effect, but reads a little better. As to deleting clauses (2) to (4) these clarify aspects of class (e) which might be later excluded by regulation. Obviously if those regulations go too far, we will move to disallow them. So, I think that the Opposition simply has not read the clause closely before drafting this amendment.
OPPOS 89 (delete 170CM(8)
The Democrats will not be voting for this amendment, and I have nothing to add to the comments made by the Minister.
OPPOS 78:
The Democrats are opposed to this amendment, as I indicated earlier, we have grave doubts about the constitutionality of the Opposition's amendments.

All of these provisions will allow for proceeding for unlawful dismissal to commence in the Commission rather than the Court. I think the Minister has explained the amendment adequately, and I am happy to jointly move these amendments.
OPPOS 80:

The Democrats believe that 170CE(3) adequately allows the Commission to accept late applications it would be unfair not to do so. That in our view is an adequate out for workers whose applications are late for good reason. The bill also increases the time to lodge applications from the current 14 to 21 days, providing even more scope for applicants. Therefore, we regard this amendment as unnecessary.
OPPOS 79 & 88:

The Democrats believe that written notice is good employment practice, but may not be appropriate in absolutely every case. The dismissal occurs when the employee is clearly dismissed. Obviously there must be some event, and in most cases that would be written notice. But, we believe that the requirement for written notice in every case is a little excessive, and therefore we oppose this amendment as one of the elements of the Labor system which created excessive problems for some employers and such hostility.
GOVT/DEM 39-41

These amendments cover the technical arrangements of where an employee elects at the end of conciliation whether they will take a case for unfair dismissal in the Commission for arbitration, or for unlawful dismissal in the Court. This distinction is necessary because unlawful dismissal claims must proceed along the judicial rather than the administrative stream. The provisions ensure that employees get to make the choice after conciliation, rather than at the very beginning of the process, and we think that is more appropriate.
GOVT/DEMS 42-44:

These amendments seek to place into proper perspective the matters to which the Commission must have regard before granting remedy. We think that the original bill placed too heavy an emphasis on the viability of the employer. While this might be a relevant circumstance in the very limited cases where the making of an order would actually touch on the viability—the continued viability of an employer, this is unlikely to be relevant to most cases. The longer list of matters to which the Commission would have regard we believe provides more appropriate guidance to the Commission on the various matters to which it should have regard.

As I said, the term "Viability of the employer's undertaking, establishment or service" is of very narrow application. It would be relevant only in those cases were the making of an order would have the effect of threatening that viability, that is threatening the continued existence of the business. Here we are talking about very small businesses, and I would doubt if it could be argued in very many cases at all. A business wishing to argue viability obviously would have to be one so close to the breadline that it would be prepared to open up its books for the Commission to determine whether the viability truly was effected by the order. As I said, these are very rare and narrow circumstances.
OPPOS 81 & 82:

I think it addressed the concerns reflected in this amendment about the viability of the employer in speaking to my earlier amendment. This amendment, given the amendment we have just discussed, is in my view unnecessary.
GOVT/DEMS 45:

This is a small amendment to ensure that the starting point for the bill is the same as the indexed compensation figure in the current Act. I might add the Democrats opposed the imposition of the original $30,000 cap by the ALP in 1994. We still think that a cap of $32,000 is way too low, but this is a status quo amendment, so I am prepared to support it.
OPPOS 83-85 (change 170CH(8) + (9) p.51)
We oppose these amendments, as we believe that the bill as it stands provides for adequate remedies.
GOVT/DEMS 46-51 (170CJ):

These are all amendments to the ability of the Commission to order costs. Amendment 46, 47, 48 and 50 cover the inclusion of unlawful dismissals within the Commission, allowing an order for costs against an organisation which has brought a vexatious claim or a claim without reasonable cause. I would like to point out that these terms are very narrow in their scope, and deliberately so. It would be our expectation in supporting these amendments that the power to award costs would be used sparingly, and only in exceptional cases which are clearly vexatious in its true sense, or truly without reasonable cause. Indeed, if it becomes the causes that costs are awarded by the Commission on anything other than a rare and exceptional case, the Democrats will be seeking to remove the costs jurisdiction or further narrow it.

Amendment 49 significantly tightens up the conditions under which an employee can be subject to costs for failing to discontinue a matter. New section 170CJ(3) will require the employee to have elected to continue the matter to arbitration under 170CFA, but then discontinuing it at an unreasonably late time. At that stage, the employee would have received the assessment of the Commission required at the end of conciliation as required by new section 170CF(2). So, before being liable for a costs order, they will have in hands an assessment of the merits, will have elected to continue, and then changed their mind. That is not unreasonable.

Amendment 51 allows for the Commission to establish a schedule of costs to prevent Carmen Lawrence style massive costs being awarded. The costs schedule in particular will allow unions representing their members to recover costs where an employer has unreasonably prolonged proceedings.

In all, we believe that this costs regime is very narrow and restricted but balanced, and is supportable on these limited grounds. I would point out that the Federal Court has had the powers to award costs in relation to unfair dismissals under Labor's unfair dismissal model, and that what we are proceeding to do is not inconsistent with that approach.
OPPOS 86 & 102 (to oppose 170CJ)

The Democrats are opposed to this amendment. We believe that the amended 170CJ provides a fair balance between the right to take an action with just cause and protection for employers against unreasonable action.
OPPOS 90 (change 170CP(6) p.57)

The Democrats oppose this amendment. The bill provides a clear discretion to accept applications out of time, and extends the time for making application from 14 to 21 days. We think the balance is right.
OPPOS 91 & 92

The Democrats are opposed to this amendment. The term "alternative" has created major legal minefields. The Commission will still be required to ensure under both 170FC and l70GC that the alternative remedy gives effect to our legal obligations under Article 12 and Article 13 of the ILO Termination of Employment Convention. I think that is an adequate safeguard.
OPPOS 93 & 94:

The Democrats again feel that this section is dubious constitutionally. The High Court in its recent judgement on these provisions gave the ILO Conventions a very literal interpretation, so literal that any order made under 170CH that a dismissal was harsh or unjust could still breach the Convention. This is very untidy law, and we are opposed to it. The award review process over the next 18 months will obviously review clauses that are obsolete and which fail to meet the objects of the Act, which include assisting in meeting our international obligations. This amendment, in short, is bad law.
GOVT/DEM 56-61

There are a range of technical provisions which seek to further clarify the circumstances of double jeopardy, ensuring that employers do not face two claims in respect of the one dismissal. Significantly, these provisions broaden out the grounds on which a person who has commenced another action can approach the Commission from merely want of jurisdiction, to include discontinuation of the earlier action. I commend the amendments.
OPPOS 95-99:
The Democrats oppose these amendments as unnecessary, as the additional ground of a State award is clearly subsumed by the category of State legislation in 170HB(1)(c).
GOVT/DEM 62 (Same as OPPOS 100):
These are minor technical amendments to section 170JC which deals with compliance with orders under this Part, which I am happy to jointly move
GOVT/DEM 63:
This omits item 13, which sought to make a minor change to section 170JC. Again, I am happy to jointly move this amendment.
GOVT/DEM 64:
This is a technical amendment sought by the Government for the reasons explained by the Minister, and I am happy to support it on behalf of the Democrats.
OPPOS 101:
The Democrats oppose this amendment. Whether the Convention is attached to the Act or not, that does not affect its legal standing.
GREEN 28:

The Democrats are opposed to this amendment. We have consistently supported reform of unfair dismissals law to replace the cumbersome, legalistic and procedural ludicrous old laws with something a bit more practical. This bill achieves that.
GREEN 29 & 39:

I don't believe that these amendments add anything to the Act. Their anti-discrimination provisions are there. The recognition of international obligations is clear in the objects. I just don't think this adds anything. So, the Democrats will oppose it.

This would be in breach of the ILO convention, so we oppose it.
GREEN 31 (Same as OPPOS 79)
GREEN 32 (Similar to OPPOS 82, already fixed by GOVT/DEM 42‐44)
GREEN 33 & 34:

This, while commendable, is bad law. 170CK relies on the external affairs power, which according to the High Court must literally follow the wording of the relevant ILO Convention, which does not cover this ground.
GREEN 35-37:

This has already been picked up with the amended form of our double jeopardy provisions. There would only be one remedy, but if an applicant has discontinued the other proceeding, they should have access to unfair or unlawful dismissal. And, our amendments already have provided that.

Filing fees are disallowable instruments. If we think they are inappropriate, the Senate can disallow them at the appropriate time. Personally, I believe that case can be made out for a small administrative filing fee to prevent totally vexatious, speculative claims. But, the $50 nominated by the Government, in our view is clearly too high. This is a debate for another time when we have a regulation proposal before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —It is at least gratifying to see that after 90 years of industrial arbitration at a national level there is bipartisan support for the right to reinstatement through the federal jurisdiction. For many, many years this right was not available. There was no legislative prescription which enabled employees employed under federal awards to seek reinstatement, although such a right may have existed in some states. So at least now we can say that there is bipartisan support for this right, although the amendments that Labor moves in relation to this schedule of the legislation are amendments which obviously I support as improving the legislative basis for the reinstatement power.

SPEECH.PARA: It was historically the case that the only way the federal commission could act in relation to reinstatement was where there was the consent of both the employer and obviously the employee's representative to accepting a recommendation of the commission. This amendment now enshrines in the legislation the fact that there is bipartisan support for this important right to be retained by employees Australia‐wide to the extent that this legislation will, in tandem with state legislation, maintain reinstatement rights.

I support Senator Forshaw's comments in relation to the fraud that has been perpetrated about the inadequacies of the previous legislation and those remarks that Senator Sherry has put on the record in relation to the fact that these changes were probably quite unnecessary.

I also point out that, in relation to one aspect of the provisions as I understand they will appear following the passage of this section, with the removal from the list of permissible matters of matters relating to the rights of union members to represent others, those rights no longer will be able to appear in awards following the transitional period. In proposed section 170CK the participation in trade union activities during working hours can be done only with the consent of the employer, whereas in the past that would have been done by permission of the award.

So to an extent this provision has put in jeopardy those people who seek to represent their fellow workers because they have been elected for example as a union delegate or representative. If I am wrong, perhaps the parliamentary secretary can clarify that matter so that I can allay the fears of a number of people I know who would be concerned that taking an action as a union representative during working hours in the future might place them in jeopardy of being dismissed without an obvious right of reinstatement pursuant to proposed section 170CK.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made most of my comments about our opposition to schedule 7. I want to indicate that when the Democrats withdrew their amendments 1 to 15, they tabled—and it was accepted for tabling—a letter from the Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett. It gave quite a glowing account of the Democrats' work in relation to industrial relations.
—It was one sentence.

—Well, it did not say anything bad. The letter basically approved what the Democrats were doing in relation to industrial relations. In the last state election in Western Australia previous to this there were great concerns about industrial relations and one of the slogans from the union movement was: `Kennett happen here? Only if you get Court.' The implication of that was that there were great concerns over what was happening with industrial relations in Victoria. People were concerned that industrial relations in Western Australia would get as bad as in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no need to worry any more because the federal Democrat‐government industrial relations agreement will now be the same as what is in Victoria. The fact that it does have the tick of approval from the Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, indicates just what an agreement it is. I think it is necessary to note that the concerns of workers have been carried through to the extent that we now have federal legislation that looks so appalling that the Premier of Victoria has given it his stamp of approval.

Having said that, as most of the changes the opposition have requested to termination of employment have been lost, I now seek their support in opposing this schedule in toto because I do believe that we are going to go backwards. I believe that, if we make people more scared about their workplace, make people feel more intimidated and allow people to be pushed around, often unfairly, we are not going to get better productivity but we are going to see a very big step back to the past. I hope that we will get the support of the Senate to oppose schedule 7.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill will be divided in respect of schedule 7. The question is that schedule 7, as amended, be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the proposal of Senator Margetts.

—Senator Margetts knows she has been a little provocative, and I think I must respond. The view of the Australian Democrats is that even somebody who has been pilloried as much as Premier Kennett can now and again say a nice word about his opponents. He said:

BREAK.PARA: I wish to record my appreciation of the cooperation of the Australian Democrats in securing major reforms in our industrial relations system with the positive shift towards a national unitary system.

We all know the fact is that two things have happened: firstly, as a result of Labor-Democrat amendments during Labor's term of government, the ability of Victorian employees to move to the federal system was enhanced, as a result of which Premier Kennett has very realistically accepted the impetus towards a national unitary system. There is no doubt that if you ask anyone in the Victorian industrial relations system whether the movement towards the new federal bill will be an improvement or not over Premier Kennett's environment they will say that it will be a massive improvement.
Secondly, Senator Margetts, you cannot have it both ways.

Minister Kierath has been beating me to death because of the Democrat amendments. We have been pilloried by him because we have isolated his industrial relations system and we will be forcing that system to move towards far better standards which are apparent in this bill than the Kierath bill. I do not think you can say when we are getting kissed by Kennett and punched by Court that we are in love with both. I do not think either are in love with us. Both take the views they do for their own political purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to make one point on what Senator Margetts raised. For Senator Margetts to say that because Mr Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, makes a short statement in half a sentence about the Australian Democrats' position on this bill that means that they therefore endorse the Kennett industrial relations legislation in Victoria or the legislation in Western Australia is patently absurd.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts knows that that is not only absurd but also stupid and wrong. I guess she has achieved her objective of provoking a response. But, by making quite pathetic assessments of the position of the Democrats when she knows very well that they endorse neither Mr Kennett's industrial reforms nor the Court‐Kierath reforms, she does herself no justice and she does not enhance the credibility that she should bring to these debates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —To clarify the situation: I said nothing about whether the Australian Democrats endorsed Mr Kierath's legislation or Mr Kennett's legislation. What I said was that it gives you an indication of how bad this legislation and this agreement are when Premier Kennett endorses the agreement, gives a tick to the agreement. Basically, that is what I was saying. It gives you an indication of what we are getting.

SPEECH.PARA: Irrespective of whether or not Mr Kierath does or does not like changes to the federal system or changes that might impact on the state system, there are people in Western Australia who are currently in the federal system who will have their lives changed immensely. There are people who had a choice before who have less of a choice now. The number of people who may be on awards, paid or otherwise, or in different sorts of agreements and who will have to go into different agreements will be quite a lot.

Different states had different numbers of people moving over. We know that, in Victoria, there was more ability to move over to a federal system. We also know that, in Western Australia in recent times, many people have moved to the federal system. There are many aspects of this bill which will affect a large number of workers in Western Australia and, perhaps even more so, in Victoria. It is not surprising that the loudest and clearest idea of the impacts of this bill are being felt in Victoria and people are very disappointed. I believe the Victorian Trades and Labour Council is feeling very betrayed at the moment, because of this bill and this agreement.

This amendment deletes provisions in the bill with regard to remedies on arbitration which require the commission to have regard to the effect of the order on the viability of the employer's undertaking, establishment or service. In similar vein to our amendment 30, we feel that the viability of an employer's business should not be used as an excuse for not making payment to an employee in lieu of reinstatement. Where else in legislation do we incorporate similar provisions? It is worth quoting in this context from a submission to the committee by Professor Andrew Stewart from the school of law at Flinders University. He states:

As a matter of principle, it is difficult to see why this concession should be made to an employer's financial circumstances, when that same concession is not made in so many other laws. If a firm inflicts loss through breach of contract or negligence, its obligation to pay damages is not reduced according to whether the firm can afford to pay, whatever the consequences that may ensue. So why should it be any different for an unfair dismissal claim? The message that this provision appears to send is that unfair dismissal claims are not in the end that serious. But they are. The arbitrary depravation of the opportunity to earn a living is one of the worst calamities that can befall a person. If an unfairly dismissed worker cannot quickly find another source of income, the obligation of the employer to compensate for any loss should not be set aside or reduced merely because the employer's own livelihood may be at risk. In the end, a wrong is a wrong and should be redressed.
Professor Stewart's argument is very persuasive. I commend the amendment to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments have been moved on behalf of the government and the Democrats. I seek leave to incorporate the remarks made by Senator Kernot with respect to those amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: SCHEDULE 8
I am very pleased to move these amendments.
These amendments reflect the longstanding commitment of the Australian Democrats to protecting and furthering the interests of women in the workplace.

These amendments re-insert into the bill those sections of Part VIA which give the Industrial Relations Commission jurisdiction over equal remuneration for work of equal value. They follow on from the Democrats' strong support for the insertion of these provisions in the original Act in 1994.

The Democrats continue to hold the view that this is a particularly important and significant part of the Act. We believe that, while there may be only one test case underway at the moment under these provisions, it is crucial they be retained. That test case seeks to deal with the area of over award payments (currently flowing about three to one in favour of men) and that case alone is justification for retaining and shoring-up the Commission's jurisdiction in this area.

The Democrats believe it is entirely appropriate to keep this jurisdiction to the Commission. We believe the Commission should have a role in ensuring our international obligations are capable of being enforced in relation to affording equal remuneration for work of equal value. I am very pleased that we have been able to persuade the Coalition, which is usually strident in its opposition to the use of the external affairs power, to agree to the re-instatement of this jurisdiction.
This provision allows the Commission to make an order to ensure that employees will be afforded equal remuneration for work of equal value.

The phrase `equal remuneration for work of equal value' will have the same meaning as in ILO Convention 100 and includes award rates, rates specified in agreements, over award pay and non-monetary benefits.

The importance of these provisions lies in their potential rather than in their current real practical effect. Their value will only be realised if unions follow the lead set by the ACTU and use this jurisdiction to run test cases.

In my view, it is a great credit to the current leadership of the ACTU that it was prepared to take this issue on and use these provisions to run the current test case on over award payments. That action by the ACTU represents a positive and welcome attempt to drive change in an area in which progress has been conspicuously lacking for more than 20 years—and (with these provisions now restored to the Act) it sends a strong signal to the union movement that it can—and should take up the issue of equal remuneration for work of equal value.

We are proposing one minor technical change to the provisions. This is a `double jeopardy' provision to ensure that applicants do not use the AIRC approach while pursuing another adequate alternative remedy. Where that remedy fails for want of jurisdiction or is discontinued, then the AIRC route will be open.
The re-instatement of this important jurisdiction is part of the large number of changes negotiated by the Democrats which will significantly benefit women.

As pointed out earlier in this debate, other gains for women are: the Commission will be required in exercising its award-making powers for the first time to pay particular regard to equal pay for work of equal value, and to the need to eliminate discrimination against employees;

Section 89A will also make it clear that the Commission can and should proceed to insert anti-discrimination clauses in awards. In addition, the accelerated award simplification process will be required to review award clauses which are discriminatory—a process which has been proceeding at something less than a snail's pace.

Because of the Democrats' negotiations, the Australian Workplace Agreements provisions will also be amended to require the Employment Advocate to have particular regard to the needs of women and workers with family responsibilities in exercising their powers. AWAs will also be required to include a model anti-discrimination clause.
The Certified Agreements provisions are also amended to require the Commission to have special regard to the needs of women when Agreement conditions are being explained to employees.
Finally, section 1 70LU(5) precludes the inclusion in an award of a clause which the Commission believes would be discriminatory on the grounds of gender.

What we have done in securing these changes is ensure that the issues of equal remuneration, of a fairer deal for women workers, and of a fairer deal for workers with family responsibilities, are put `up-front' and `in lights' in the Act.
And that means that these changes form a package which represents a major improvement not only on the original bill as tabled by the Government, but on the existing Act as well.

Now the Opposition has criticised the Democrats for our position on equal pay. They thought they had discovered an issue to run on. It has been a rather desperate attempt to re‐establish credibility on a range of issues by re‐writing history. Unfortunately for our Labor critics it is proving a bit difficult for them to paint themselves as the champion of working Australians with a 13 year record behind them of doing the exact opposite in government.
Look at the record. Labor cut real wages. Labor left 800,000 Australian workers unemployed. Labor made it tougher for the unemployed and for sick workers to access social security benefits.
Through its ideological obsession with `level playing fields', Labor destroyed employment in the Australian manufacturing industry.
Yes . . . government.
And as time passes, we will be able to assess this coalition government's performance on the same matter. They cannot hide behind Labor's past record forever!
I say to the Labor Party: they would be entitled to criticise the Democrats if they were doing so on the basis of a different and more credible policy record in government.

And it is rather hypocritical of Labor to expect others to now support Labor amendments which they were not prepared to move or support when they were in government. These are purely political amendments. If they were not appropriate then, why are they now? The answer: being in opposition!
So I can understand why opposition senators sought to say we were betraying the women of Australia for saying the Commission must have regard to equal remuneration for work of equal value.

And why opposition senators have spent so much time and repetition on one word of Section 88B, which sets out the things the commission must have regard to in exercising its award making jurisdiction.
Labor is clutching at straws in this debate and it knows it!

Section 88B is not inconsistent with our support for re‐insertion of Part VIA. Equal pay, as understood by the Commission in its successive equal pay cases and equal pay principles, covers payment for work. That is what awards are about. If a condition falls outside the definition of `pay', it is picked up in the general discrimination provisions. Or it is picked up under Part VIA.

It should be pointed out that the Commission takes a wide view of the 1972 Equal Pay Test Case decision, as recently as last November in the Weipa case, reaffirming that the Principles continue to apply, and that equal pay should be based on a fair assessment in the circumstances of the particular cases brought before the Commission.

The fact of the matter is that when this bill is passed, it will be the first time that an Australian parliament has directed the Commission to have particular regard to this issue, and to the complementary instruction to have particular regard to the need to eliminate discrimination.
That is a significant achievement.

What these amendments do is put up-front the requirement for the Commission to take these issues seriously and to take action on them—in its award making powers, in award simplification, in agreements and through Part VIA in over-award payments.

With these weapons at their disposal, the Commission can now start to attack the systemic discrimination which, 27 years after the first equal pay case and 10 years after the Sex Discrimination Act, still sees women earning on average 30 per cent less than men.

The Labor Party might like to explain why in the last ten years the relativity of women's full time wages to men's full time wages not risen, and is stuck at 78.3%. In fact, in the last two to three years, it has fallen, a point clearly made in the DIR report on Enterprise Bargaining released last month. No progress in ten years, if anything women were going backwards under Labor's industrial relations model. That is ten years of a Labor Government failing to make even the slightest inroads into equal pay.
(I seek to incorporate a document which is an extract from ABS statistics in relation to male and female full time earnings).

Interestingly enough, that inequality in both pay and access to work‐related benefits did not stop the Labor Government from raising the pension age for women a couple of years' back—to the distress and detriment of a great many Australian women workers in their 40s and 50s. And that decision was taken even though under the Labor government's superannuation polices, three quarters of the $7 billion of tax concessions flowed to men, even though men make up just 45 per cent of Australia's post age 60 population.

I remind you that the Democrats voted against the move on women's pensions, and have constantly criticised Labor's failure to deliver a superannuation regime fairer to women—so don't come in here and try to pretend that 13 years of a Labor Government did anything wonderful for women workers in this country.

So Labor should not come in here and condemn us for negotiating amendments which will provide an important tool in commencing the hard work of closing that stubborn gender pay gap—a gap they so conspicuously failed to close in more than a decade in government.
AVERAGE WEEKLY EARNING—FULL TIME ADULTS (ABS 6302.0)

The Democrats are opposed to this amendment. The amendment would have the effect of maintaining the equal remuneration provisions without any provision on double jeopardy. In addition, the other aspects of Schedule 8, the Minimum Conditions provisions, would also be retained. Unlike the equal remuneration provisions, we don't have a particularly strong view on the retention of the minimum wages provisions. The AIRC has retained its power to run national wages cases, and the objects of the Act and of the award provisions provide clear guidance to the AIRC on how those national wage outcomes are to take into account fairness, community living standards and assisting to give effect to ILO conventions, which include the Minimum Wage provisions. As the provisions have not been used since being inserted in 1993, I think the other provisions of the bill are adequate to deal with the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —We welcome the fact that the government and the Democrats have agreed to reinstate into the act the provisions concerning equal remuneration for work of equal value. We welcome it because, on a practical level, the provisions give the commissioner general power to ensure equal remuneration in over‐award matters—a power the commission or any other body does not otherwise have. We also welcome it because it enables Australia to give proper effect to international obligations which we have entered into, particularly the anti-discrimination conventions and equal remuneration recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: I am curious that the Democrats have not been able to convince the government of the force of these same arguments as applied to the minimum wage provisions. On a practical level, the minimum wage provisions give the commission a general power to ensure that all Australian workers—not just federal award workers—receive adequate minimum wages. This has the potential to be an important safety net for all of the community.

Repeal of this power would, of course, be contrary to the Democrats' pre‐election commitment that they would oppose any attempt to reduce the powers or jurisdiction of the commission. Perhaps the Democrats regard these minimum wage provisions as non‐core powers and jurisdiction of the commission! The minimum wage provisions are also important in giving effect to Australia's international obligations under the minimum wages convention. Perhaps the Democrats and the government have embarked on a process of determining which of our international obligations are core ones that must be preserved, and which are non‐core obligations that can be jettisoned at will.

BREAK.PARA: I would urge the Democrats to reconsider their ambiguous position on these matters, lest it be thought that the otherwise pure Democrats may be acting on the basis that there are move votes in equal remuneration than there are in minimum wages. BREAK.PARA: For the reasons I have already explained the Opposition supports the preservation in the Act of the Commission's general power to make orders for equal remuneration for work of equal value. Because these amendments achieve this effect we will vote in support of them.
The effect of this amendment is to oppose Schedule 8 as amended.

Insofar as Schedule 8 as amended deletes Division 1 of Part VIA (minimum wages) the Opposition is opposed to the Schedule. For the reasons I have already stated, we believe the Commission should not be deprived of this potentially important jurisdiction.

Insofar as Schedule 8 as amended amends Division 2 of Part VIA (equal remuneration for work of equal value), whilst the Opposition voted in support of these amendments we still believe the Act as it presently stands is superior. Insofar as Schedule 8 as amended repeals the annexure of various international conventions to the Act the Opposition is opposed to the Schedule.
