TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Because I will table for incorporation in Hansard a detailed document explaining the opposition's response to the various government‐Democrat and Green amendments, and detailing our own amendments, I will confine my comments to just a few key issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps most fundamentally, the opposition opposes the creation of yet another stream of workplace agreement, non‐union certified agreements. The opposition will be moving therefore to delete division 2 of schedule 9. We believe there is simply no justification for the creation of a non‐union stream of certified agreements, particularly as these just make a complicated bill and a complicated industrial relations system even more complicated.

It is simpler and more efficient to create just one stream for non‐union agreements. Although we object to them, the government has done this by creating AWAs. AWAs are able to be made on a multi‐employee basis and will be tested by reference to the same `no disadvantage test' as certified agreements. If the government really has faith in its new AWAs, why not rely on these as the preferred non‐union agreements?

There are three other areas to which I want to draw attention—in the main because the opposition will be moving amendments to deal with the problems we see. The first is an amendment which has been recommended to us by the Association of Professional Engineers, Scientists and Managers, Australia. They are concerned that the new arrangements for certified agreements will allow the interests of their members at a workplace—and invariably their members are well and truly in the minority—to be swamped by the interests of the other majority workforce. This is most likely to occur because of the requirement that there be majority approval for a certified agreement at a particular workforce. In these circumstances, the votes of the inevitable employees minority of APESMA members are likely to be swamped.

To address this concern, we will be moving an amendment which permits employers to enter into a certified agreement with a distinct category of employees in their workforce where the employer chooses to do so. We can see no valid argument against giving employers their freedom to choose.

Secondly, we will be moving another `Murray amendment'—we are not letting you get off too lightly, Senator Murray—in relation to youth wages, although I am just as happy to call it a `Stott Despoja amendment' if you want her to take responsibility.

This bill, as agreed by the Democrats, will permit junior rates to continue in certified agreements until at least the year 2000, with the commission having the power to extend them beyond that on a case by case basis. I remind the government and the Democrats that junior rates are discriminatory. They permit discrimination between two workers simply on the basis of age, even though they are doing the same work and have the same experience. We are opposed to junior rates and we thought the Democrats were, too.

However, we are not going to win on our preferred position, so we will accept the fall‐back provision recommended by Senator Murray in his report. He recommended at page 353—I offer it as commended reading to the nation that is listening—that:

. . . age‐based discrimination in relation to wages ceases as from 1 July 1997 as set out in the current Act. However, the parties may be able to approach the Commission on an award or agreement basis to seek an extension of up to two years at a time provided that they can demonstrate special circumstances and that they intend and are making progress in replacing age‐based wages with wages based on skill.
Well, Senator Murray, that is the precise effect of the amendment we will be moving and we will look forward to you voting with us for a change.

The third amendment that we will be moving is in relation to the termination of certified agreements. The original proposal in the bill to permit unilateral termination after the expiry date was very unfair as it would have given the employer disproportionate bargaining power. It would have enabled an employer to threaten the workforce with significant reductions in existing entitlements—for example, going back to the basic award entitlements—if they did not agree to proposals for a new agreement by the time of expiry of the old one. It would have effectively required employees to take industrial action just to retain their existing conditions.

We accept that these concerns have been ameliorated to some extent by the new requirement for review by the commission before termination can be approved. Because this provision is an improvement, the opposition will vote in support of it. But the opposition's preferred position is that the termination of a certified agreement should only be permitted if a valid majority of persons employed at the time, whose employment is subject to the agreement, had genuinely agreed to the termination. We believe that whilst an agreement is in effect it should only be terminated with the agreement of the parties. An employer should not at any time have the capacity to effectively remove existing conditions of employment from employees.

The opposition also believes that the commission should be required to determine that it is in the public interest for a certified agreement to be terminated. The requirement proposed by the government‐Democrats amendment that the commission is required to determine that that termination is not contrary to the public interest is not good enough. It is an example of a subtle change in the onus of proof that the government has apparently been able to sell to the Democrats. But it would be wise for the Democrats to appreciate that termination of a certified agreement under this new regime will usually have very dire consequences because employees will fall back to mere safety net conditions of employment. The strictest public interest requirement should be insisted upon before employees are faced with this appalling outcome. The amendment we will move will ensure this is the case.

As I indicated in my earlier comments, we have some 14 or 15 pages of comment on each of the various amendments—government, Democrat, Greens and our own. I seek leave to have those comments incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CAMPBELL

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted, subject to the vetting arrangements we have got in place.

INTERJECT.PARA: The provisions concerning the establishment, role and organisation of the Bargaining Division of the Commission are included in Division 5 of Part VIB of the existing Act, which is repealed by item 19 of Schedule 9. The Opposition supports the retention of the Bargaining Division and so these amendments re‐enact the relevant provisions.

We believe it is unnecessary and inappropriate to abolish the Bargaining Division because it has much needed expertise in supervising enterprise bargaining. This expertise will be particularly important under this Bill given that the Bill places great emphasis on enterprise bargaining and on Commission supervision of that bargaining.

The Bill provides for an additional operation of the Act in relation to the new provisions in Division 2 of Part VIB which permit certified agreements between employees and constitutional corporations or the Commonwealth. Consequent on the Opposition's proposed deletion of these provisions we also delete this application provision.

The Opposition accepts that this amendment is an improvement on the original form of the Bill and, for this reason, will vote in support of the amendment. But we believe the provision as amended is still inadequate, and so we propose that it be deleted and replaced with an alternative provision (see Opp (107)).

This amendment inserts a new provision which requires the Commission to grant a person or organisation leave to appear at any Commission hearing (including approval of certified agreements and AWA) if that is necessary to ensure that all facts and issues are disclosed or that the interests of all persons potentially affected by the matter are protected. In Commission hearings unions can play an important role in ensuring that all relevant facts and issues are disclosed and that the interests of all persons potentially affected by the determination (including future employees) are represented and protected. Unions should be permitted to play this role.

The Bill removes the right of appeal from a decision to certify an agreement applicable to a single business. This amendment deletes this repeal. The parties to an agreement applicable to a single business should have the right to appeal against a decision to certify. The decision will probably have been made by a single Commissioner and it is possible for that Commissioner to get the decision wrong.

The Bill provides that, where the Commission is required by the Act to be satisfied that a valid majority of employees approve a decision (for example, to make a certified agreement), the Commission may order a vote if it is not so satisfied. This amendment deletes this and inserts a new section which provides that, where the Commission is required by the Act to be satisfied that a valid majority of employees approve a decision, and an organisation advises the Commission that a valid majority did approve the decision, the Commission must accept this advice unless it has reason to believe otherwise, in which case the Commission may order a vote. The Commission should be able to rely on evidence by an organisation that there is majority approval. This is administratively less complex, and potentially saves time and money. Where the Commission believes it should nevertheless order a ballot it can still do so.
The Bill defines what constitutes a valid majority. Because of Opp (106) this is unnecessary and we delete it.
The Opposition supports this amendment because it is an improvement to the original Bill.

Consequent on the Opposition's proposed deletion of the new provisions in Division 2 of Part VIB (which permit certified agreements between employees and constitutional corporations or the Commonwealth) we delete this consequential amendment.

The opposition accepts that this is provision is an improvement on the Bill in its original from, and will vote in support of it on that basis. But the Opposition believes that the provision even as amended is flawed and therefore propose that it be deleted (see Opp (113)).

The Bill inserts new objects of Part VIB (certified agreements). This amendment amends those new objects by requiring the facilitation of certified agreements whether it be at a single business or multi‐business level (not particularly at the single business level, as provided in the Bill). There is no basis for inequality of treatment as between single‐business certified agreements and multi‐employer certified agreements. Multi‐employer agreements may be preferred by the parties in some circumstances, particularly as they tend to remove labour costs from competition between businesses within an industry.

The Bill as amended provides that multi‐business agreements can only be certified by a Full Bench, and then only if it is in the public interest having regard to whether the subject matter can be more appropriately dealt with in a single business agreement and to any other relevant considerations. We delete these provisions. For the reasons previously stated, there is no basis for this inequality of treatment as between single‐business and multi‐employer certified agreements.

The Bill provides that a multi‐business certified agreement is overridden by a single business certified agreement, whether made before or after. This amendment delete this provision and provides that the latter agreement in time prevails. Again, for the reasons previously stated, there is no basis for this inequality of treatment as between single‐business and multi‐employer certified agreements. The parties to a single‐business agreement should be free to subsequently enter into a multi‐employer agreement which will then take effect.

The Bill provides that the protected bargaining provisions (ie. the right to strike when negotiating a certified agreement) do not apply to multi‐business agreements. We delete this provision. Again, for the reasons previously stated, there is no basis for this inequality of treatment as between single‐business and multi‐employer certified agreements. This is particularly so where the right to strike is concerned—parties wishing to bargain for a multi‐employer agreement (which is recognised by the Act) should be entitled to strike in support of that bargaining.

This amendment inserts a further definition of a part of a single business so that it also incudes a distinct category of employees. The category must be agreed by the employer and the organisation representing the employees and must be approved by the Commission. I have already explained the reasons for this amendment.

The Bill provides that an agreement must be approved by a valid majority. This requirement is also, properly, incorporated in the provisions dealing with certification of agreements. This provision is therefore otiose and we delete it.

The Opposition accepts that the new provisions relating to paid rates awards are an improvement. We also accept that this definition of paid rates awards is appropriate. The Opposition will therefore support this amendment.
Given that Govt/Dems (78) now omits section 170LG in its original form, and given that Opp (117) was intended to do the same thing, this amendment is no longer necessary and will not be moved.

The Opposition supports each of these amendments on the basis that they improve the existing provisions in the Bill. Despite these amendments the Opposition is still opposed to the proposed Division 2 of Part VIB in its entirety (see Opp (118)).
This amendment is not as advantageous to employees as Govt/Dems (80) and (81). If it is moved the Opposition will oppose it.

The Opposition supports this amendment on the basis that it is an improvement to the Bill. But despite this amendment the Opposition is still opposed to the proposed Division 2 of Part VIB in its entirety (see Opp (118)).

The Bill makes provisions permitting and governing certified agreements between employers and employees (non‐union certified agreements). We delete these provisions. There is no justification for the creation of a non‐union stream of certified agreements. I have previously explained why the Opposition believes this is the case.
These amendments are consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move these amendments.
This amendment is consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.
The Opposition accepts that this amendment improves the Bill and will vote in support on that basis.

The Opposition supports these amendments. We note that they are to the same effect and for the same purpose as the amendments the Opposition proposes to move to Schedule 11 of the Bill concerning the `right to bargain collectively' (see Opp (201)). For the reasons explained there the Opposition believes these amendments are necessary and appropriate.

The Opposition accepts that if an offence under proposed section 170LRC is created the offence should be a penalty provision for the purposes of section 170VV of the Bill. The Opposition proposes the same process in respect of our proposed sections 170VCA and 170VCB (see Opp (232)). The Opposition therefore supports this amendment.

The Opposition accepts that this amendment improves the provisions in the Bill concerning the requirements for certification of a certified agreement. On this basis the Opposition will vote in support of the amendment. But the Opposition's preferred provisions concerning the requirements for certification are those set out in Opp (123). The rationale for those provisions is explained there.
The Opposition supports this amendment because it is an improvement to the original Bill.

The Opposition supports this amendment insofar as it omits proposed subsection (8). We accept the proposed removal of the distinction between greenfields and non‐greenfields agreements for the purposes of termination of an agreement (see Govt/Dems (99)).

Insofar as the amendment inserts a new subsection (8) the Opposition supports the amendment because it is an improvement on the existing Bill. But we should note that the amendment affects agreements made under proposed Division 2 of Part VIB and the Opposition is opposed to those agreements in their entirety (see Opp (118)).

For the reasons I have already explained the Opposition is opposed to the proposals concerning junior rates in certified agreements inserted by subsection 170LU(7) of this amendment. As I have also explained before the Opposition intends to move a fallback amendment which precisely reflects the Senator Murray's recommendation in relation to junior rates (see Opp (1) Sheet 235).
In relation to proposed subsection 170LU(8) inserted by this amendment the Opposition supports this subsection because it does improve the Bill.
This amendment gives effect to the recommendations by Senator Murray in relation to junior rates. I have already explained the reasons for this amendment.

The Bill as amended by Govt/Dems (86) provides that an agreement cannot be certified unless it passes the `no disadvantage test' in Schedule 13. If the agreement does not pass the `no disadvantage test' it can nevertheless by certified if this is not contrary to the public interest. An example of the latter is if the agreement is part of a strategy to deal with a short‐term crisis in the business.

The Opposition believes that these new provisions suffer from some important inadequacies. First, the new test requires an assessment of `no disadvantage' by reference to overall terms and conditions rather specific terms and conditions. This opens up the possibility of employees `trading off' important terms and conditions like sick leave in return for perhaps one‐off pay increases. Second, the new test permits exemptions from the `no disadvantage' requirement in the case of trainees, apprentices and employees on the supported wage system. Third, there is no reason why the public interest should necessarily be equated to strategies to deal with short‐term crises in business.

For these reasons the Opposition believes the `no disadvantage test' as it is presently in the Act is the fairest and most comprehensive test of `no disadvantage'. The effect of this amendment is therefore to restore this existing test.

The Bill requires that a valid majority of employees subject to the agreement have genuinely approved it. This amendment requires the Commission to be satisfied that a valid majority have genuinely made the agreement. As a matter of abundant caution, it should be stressed that the Employment Advocate or Commission (as the case may be) must, before certifying an agreement, consider and determine whether the agreement is genuinely made (ie. not the product of threats, failures to inform etc).
This amendment is consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.
Because the Opposition support amendment (88) insofar as it omits proposed subsection (8) we no longer move this amendment.

This amendment gives further effect to the Opposition's position that the existing arrangements in relation to junior rates should not be repealed. The amendment seeks to reinstate the existing provision that requires that after 22 June 1997 an agreement cannot be certified if it discriminates by providing for junior rates of pay.

This amendment deals with the requirements for certification of agreements. The Opposition's preferred position on this issue is given effect by our own amendments (eg Opp (123), (124) and (128)). Nevertheless we believe that this amendment is an improvement on requirements for certification that are provided by Bill as amended by the various Govt/Dems amendments. On this basis if the relevant Opposition amendments are not agreed to we will vote in support of this amendment.
The Opposition does not support these amendments. We have previously given our reasons for this position.

The Bill allows a single agreement to deal with 2 or more industrial disputes. This amendment adds that a single agreement, including a multi‐business agreement, may also deal with 2 or more employers. This is to emphasise that an agreement dealing with 2 or more industrial disputes can be of the multi‐employer type.
These amendments are consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move these amendments.

The right of organisations of employees to intervene on certification of agreements is dealt with by the Opposition in Opp (107). That provision is the Opposition's preferred position. Nevertheless section 170LWA is an improvement on the provisions of the Bill as amended. We will therefore support this part of the amendment if Opp (107) is not agreed to.As to the proposed section 170LWB of this amendment the Opposition has concerns about the proposal for possible disadvantage to be rectified by undertakings. We believe in such a case the agreement should simply not be certified. The Opposition therefore does not support this aspect of this amendment.
The Opposition supports these amendments on the basis that they are an improvement to the Bill.
This amendment is consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.
The Opposition supports these amendments because they improve the Bill.

Insofar as this amendment deals with the relationship between certified agreements and AWAs the Opposition has always accepted the provisions as originally (and still) drafted in the Bill (ie proposed subsection 170VQ(4)). We therefore do not support this aspect of this amendment.

Insofar as this amendment deals with the relationship between certified agreements and Sate employment agreements the Opposition's position is provided by Opp (227). We therefore will not support this aspect of this amendment.

The Bill provides that a certified agreement operates subject to any provisions in a State law dealing with occupational health and safety, workers' compensation, apprenticeship or other prescribed matters. This amendment adds that a certified agreement will not operate subject to a State law in the listed matters if the provisions of the State law are less favourable to the employees than the certified agreement. Employers and employees should not be able to contract out of entitlements provided by State law in such important matters as OH & S, workers' compensation and apprenticeship arrangements. But they should be able to contract for better entitlements.

The Bill provides that any provisions in a certified agreement concerning termination of employment do not prevail over such provisions in any State law, award or agreement to the extent the provisions can operate concurrently. This amendment deletes the application of this provision to a State agreement. Whilst we accept that the parties to a Federal certified agreement should be able to take advantage of superior termination of employment provisions in a State law or award, we do not accept this in relation to State enterprise agreements. This is a matter of principle—as has always been the case Federal agreements should always over State agreements.
The new definition of State employment agreement has been agreed previously as part of section 4(1) and so there is now no need to move this amendment.
This amendment is consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.
The Opposition supports this technical amendment.
This amendment is consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.

The Opposition accepts the new provision providing for agreement variation where there has been discrimination between unionists and non‐unionists or between members of particular unions. We will therefore support Govt/Dems (97) and (98). We note however that the Bill as amended still does not provide remedies in the case of discrimination between employees wanting to bargain collectively and those wanting to bargain individually. The Opposition addresses this in Opp (232).

The Opposition also accepts the removal of the distinction between greenfields and non‐greenfields agreements for the purposes of termination of an agreement. We will therefore support Govt/Dems (99).

The Opposition's preferred position is to substantially amend proposed section 170MG (see Opp (142), (143) and (144)) and, as a consequence, to repeal section 170MH (see Opp (145)). We will support these amendments on the basis that they improve upon the original Bill. But we will nevertheless be moving on our preferred position.
This amendment is consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.
Because we accept the repeal of section 170MF we no longer move these amendments to that section.

The Bill provides that on or before the nominal expiry date the parties may agree to terminate a certified agreement, and that the Commission must approve such a termination if a valid majority approves it. This amendment deletes this and provides that at any time (both before and after the nominal expiry date) the parties may agree to terminate a certified agreement. The Commission must approve such a termination if a valid majority approves it and it is in the public interest for the agreement to be terminated. We believe that the Commission should be entitled to exercise a public interest discretion in deciding whether to approve termination of a certified agreement.

The Opposition accepts that this amendment is an improvement on the provision as originally proposed. I have already explained how seriously flawed the original proposal in the Bill was. These flaws have been ameliorated to an extent by the new requirement for Commission review before termination can be approved. Because this provision is an improvement the Opposition will vote in support of it.

But the Opposition's preferred position is that termination of a certified agreement should only be permitted if a valid majority of persons employed at the time whose employment is subject to the agreement has genuinely terminated the agreement and it would be in the public interest for the agreement to be terminated (see Opp (144) and Opp (2) Sheet (235)). I have also previously explained why we have adopted this position.

This amendment effectively reverses the onus for the Commission in its consideration of the public interest in terminating a certified agreement. The amendment provides that it must be in the public interest for a certified agreement to be terminated before the Commission can consent to the termination.
This amendment is consequential on Opp (144). If Opp (144) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.
These amendments are consequential on Opp (144). If Opp (144) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move these amendments.

The Opposition supports these amendments. We have previously attempted to preserve the existing provisions concerning paid rates awards. This attempt was defeated by the joint vote of the Government and Democrats. We are nevertheless prepared to support these provisions as a very much second best option which will at least provide some basis for employees to obtain awards in the nature of paid rates awards.
These amendments are consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move these amendments.

The Bill notes that the entitlement to protected industrial action does not affect any common law right of the employer to refuse to pay the employee. Consequent of our removal of this right (see Opp (164)) this amendment deletes this note.
These amendments are consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move these amendments.

The Bill provides that whilst an employer is not to prejudice an employee for engaging in protected industrial action, this does not apply to an employer standing‐down an employee or refusing to pay an employee pursuant to a common law right. This amendment amends the first exception applying it only where the employer has sought, and the Commission has approved, a stand down. The amendment deletes the second exception. The Opposition believes that an employee's right to engage in protected action is fundamentally undermined by these proposals. An unfettered capacity for the employer to stand‐down or to refuse to pay an employee during industrial action gives the employer disproportionate bargaining power. The employer can "starve the employees into submission".

The Bill provides that one circumstance in which the Commission can terminate a bargaining period is if the organisation is taking industrial action in support of employees who will be subject to the agreement but who are neither members, nor eligible to become members, of the organisation. This amendment deletes this. We believe that an organisation that will become a party to a certified agreement should be able to effectively bargain (including by taking industrial action) in the interests of all employees who will be subject to the agreement. Otherwise those employees will have their bargaining power severely weakened.

The Bill says that after the Commission has terminated a bargaining period it must, as soon as practicable, begin to exercise its conciliation powers. This amendment provides that the Commission must exercise the powers immediately (unless the Commission determines to exercise its arbitration powers immediately (see Opp (171)—(173)). The Opposition believes that given that the circumstances in which the Commission can terminate a bargaining period are drastic (eg endangering life, health or safety; causing significant damage to the economy) it is in the public interest for the Commission to exercise its conciliation powers immediately these circumstances arise.

The Bill says that if, after the Commission has exercised its conciliation powers, it determines that agreement is unlikely to be reached, the Commission must, if it considers it appropriate, exercise its arbitration powers. This amendment provides that if, before the Commission exercises its conciliation powers, it determines that agreement is unlikely to be reached, the Commission must immediately exercise its arbitration powers. In the drastic circumstances in which the Commission can terminate a bargaining period the Commission should not "waste its time" conciliating when it knows an agreement is not likely to be reached. The Commission should be able to arbitrate immediately.
Because Govt/Dems (102)—(117) deal with this matter there is no need for the Opposition to move this amendment.

The Bill requires the Full Bench to exercise the arbitration powers under these provisions. This amendment deletes this requirement. A requirement for a Full Bench can cause potentially damaging delays.
Because Govt/Dems (102)—(117) deal with this matter there is no need for the Opposition to move this amendment.
This amendment gives effect to the Opposition's preferred position in relation to termination of a section 170MX award. This position is discussed at Govt/Dems (118) below.
This amendment is consequential on Opp (118). If Opp (118) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.
The Opposition accepts that this amendment is an improvement on the provision as originally proposed. On this basis the Opposition will vote in support of the amendment.

But the Opposition's preferred position is that termination of a section 170MX award after the nominated expiry date should only be permitted if the parties agree to the termination and it would be in the public interest for the award to be terminated. The Opposition believes that whilst a section 170MX award is in effect it should only be terminated with the agreement of the parties. The employer should not at any time have the capacity to effectively remove existing conditions of employment from employees.

This is precisely the position proposed by the Bill in relation to termination of a section 170MX award before its nominated expiry date. The Opposition can see no valid reason for different requirements for termination depending on whether a nominal date has passed or not.
The Opposition's preferred position is given effect by Opp (178) and (181).
I have previously explained the reasons for this amendment (see Govt/Dems (118)).
The Opposition supports these amendments for the reasons set out at Govt/Dems (102)—(117).

The Bill prohibits the Commission from arbitrating during the bargaining period. This amendment deletes this prohibition. It is in the public interest for the Commission to have the capacity to arbitrate a resolution of an industrial dispute before the dispute becomes so serious that the bargaining period may be terminated (eg endangering life, health or safety; causing significant damage to the economy). Why require the Commission to wait until these consequences are occurring?

The Bill provides that an employer negotiating a certified agreement must not discriminate between unionists and non‐unionists. The Opposition accepts this, but this amendment adds an exception which permits the inclusion of a union preference clause. We believe that the parties to a certified agreement should be entitled to agree to a preference clause if that is what they wish. Often preference clauses are desired by employers, unions and employees in order to give order and certainty to the conduct of industrial relations.

If Opp (184) is not agreed to, this amendment adds a different exception which permits the inclusion of a clause requiring or permitting the employer to promote or encourage union membership and to recognise one or more unions as exclusive bargaining agent for all employees. The `next best thing' to union preference clauses are clauses providing for union encouragement and for unions as exclusive bargaining agents. This will enable employees to at least be informed about the benefits of unionism and to gain the benefits of union representation.
The Opposition will vote in support of this amendment because it does improve the Bill.
The Opposition does not support this deletion of the prohibition against coercion in relation to agreements.

The Bill lists the sections which are penalty provisions for the purposes of the "certified agreements" Part. The Opposition accepts inclusion of s170MDA and s170NB as a penalty provision and will therefore vote in support of these amendments. We note that the inclusion of s170NB was originally proposed by us in the House of Representatives (it is now Opp (187)) but not supported by the Government.
Given Govt/Dems (124) this amendment is no longer necessary and we will not move it.

The Bill prescribes a maximum penalty of $10,000 for corporations and $2,000 for others for breach of provisions in this Part. The amendment amends these maximum amounts to $1,000 and $500 respectively. We believe that penalties of the amount proposed simply show that the focus of this Bill is on punishment (not on achieving cooperative outcomes).
The Opposition does not object to these provisions as they are a necessary corollary of Govt/Dems (123) and (124).

The Bill provides an injunction power for breach of provisions in this Part. We delete this power. The Opposition believes that injunction powers under this Part are most likely to be used against unions (eg breaching the prohibition on industrial action during the life of a certified agreement). In industrial relations injunctions are very blunt instruments. In particular, interim injunctions effectively terminate industrial action without at any time permitting the parties to argue the merits of the dispute. Breach of an injunction is also very serious, exposing unions to unlimited financial penalties for contempt of court.
If Opp (189) is not agreed to, this amendment qualifies the injunction power by providing that:

i. an injunction (whether interim or final) cannot be granted in the absence of the other party unless the Court is satisfied that the applicant has given notice of the application to the other person;
ii. an interim injunction cannot be granted unless the Court is satisfied that:
(a) the applicant is likely to succeed at the trial of the action; and
(b) not granting the injunction will inevitably expose the applicant to loss or harm for which an award of damages is a wholly inadequate remedy.

The Opposition moves this alternative amendment because the `next best thing' to removal of injunctions is to modify the injunction power so as to considerably reduce its destructive potential against unions. This can be done in two ways—ensuring that an employer cannot "rush off to court behind the union's back" to get an interim injunction; providing very strict requirements before an interim injunction will ordered. This ensures at least that the merits of the dispute will be heard by the Court before an injunction will be ordered.

The Bill repeals the existing section providing that employees are not to be dismissed etc. for engaging in industrial action. We delete this repeal because although there are provisions in the Bill dealing with dismissal etc. for engaging in industrial action (Schedule 16 freedom of Association), these are not as strong as the existing provisions, nor do they apply as widely as the existing provisions (eg they only apply to employers that are corporations). In a recent High Court decision (Vic. v Cth.) the Court expressly found these existing provisions valid on the basis that they gave effect to Australia's international obligations concerning the right to strike. For these reasons they should be retained.

The Bill also repeals the scheduling to the Act of the "International covenant on economic, social and cultural rights", the ILO "Convention concerning freedom of association and protection of the right to organise" and the ILO "Convention concerning the application of the principles of the right to organise and to bargain collectively. We delete this repeal because we believe that the Act must be the means by which these international conventions are implemented. This requires, as a matter of substance and perception, that they be scheduled to the Act.
The Opposition accepts both of these amendments and will vote in support of them.

—I seek leave to move opposition amendments 104, 105, 191 and 192 together.

(105) Schedule 9, item 2, page 68 (line 9), omit "Repeal the definition", substitute. "Omit 170QB(1), substitute 170NJ(1)."

(2) The President may determine in writing that specified members of the Bargaining Division are to perform specified functions, and exercise specified powers, as members of the Commission, either generally or as otherwise specified in the determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Labor amendment No. 107, I think the question has to be asked: what have the government and the Democrats got to hide in relation to these agreements? Presumably having established minimum conditions tests, what is the problem with those legislative aspects being tested against a particular agreement? The environment that the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, as it is proposed to be amended, will establish is an environment where potentially there will be no critical determination of a particular agreement against those tests, given that the only parties potentially to proceedings will be supporting the approval of an agreement, and potentially will not want that agreement tested rigorously against the minimum conditions tests which are laid down, I think, in other parts of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have said that they only wish, for example, employee organisations to have a right to appear in those matters when a member has authorised them in writing to appear. Presumably that is a member who is party to or affected by the agreement in accordance with the provisions of the legislation. I think it is 170LK(4). That begs a couple of questions. Firstly, in a seasonal industry, the potential remains—I think we have seen these sorts of circumstances in the past—where an agreement can be made with a work force at a particular time without having regard to the fact that the agreement will bind other people who are not employed at that time, but are normally employed on a seasonal basis. For example, in the fruit picking industry certain employers would be able to establish a certified agreement with a small number of employees which would bind a large number of casuals who were later employed under the terms of that agreement although they had no say in the matter. There would be no person or authority able to represent the interests of those employees; they would have no say in the matter and they would be bound.

So there is clearly one type of case where employees can be bound and where they have no say. They clearly have no right to representation because they are not employed at the time the agreement is made. As I understand 170LK(4), they would have no right to ask that a union represent them in the bargaining process, because at that particular time they are not employed even though, from year to year, they might regularly return to the employment, for example, of a particular grower.

That is just one example. You can also talk about certain fish processing industries where employment is seasonal and casual and where the same circumstances can arise. Again, those employees would have no right whatsoever in relation to the matter.

That brings me to the second point. Traditionally—and I think this has been recognised by the High Court, and I referred to this in the second reading debate—employee organisations have been taken to represent the class of employees that their rules cover. That is, it covers present and future employees. Those organisations have a role in the coverage of people who are not currently employed in a particular occupation but who might be employed in the future.

Certified agreements, when made, do not simply bind those people who are a party to their making. On the one hand, an employer may sell a business or transmit the business in some way, and another employer would pick up the benefits or obligations of that certified agreement.

On the other hand, employees are a changing group. The employees who agreed to the certified agreement at the point it was made may depart and a new group of employees may arrive. Those employees would have had no say in the document, and their only choice as to the terms of condition is whether or not they accept the job and whether or not the government believes it is a good employment environment. I think the reality is that there is still a fairly high level of unemployment.

Those people who are seeking employment, particularly in some of the regional areas of Australia where employment is difficult to obtain, have no ability to intervene. The only bodies that have been established and which appear to represent the rights of future employees are registered employee organisations. Yet the provisions in relation to certified agreements would exclude those organisations from appearing.

I have heard the arguments about uninvited parties appearing in proceedings in relation to certified agreements in the past. Frankly, those arguments do not stand up when you consider that the certified agreement will cover a group of people—employer and employee potentially—who would have had no say in relation to the process of making the document and would have had no say as to the testing of the document against the minimum criteria established in the legislation.

The government and the Democrats are not satisfied that those minimum criteria will stand the test in each case. If they were satisfied that they would stand up to the test, why would there be concern about scrutiny—about their actually being tested? Someone who wants to represent a point of view as to what those conditions might mean cannot have a say.

There are many instances at law where organisations appear as so-called friends of the court to put a view on a particular matter. Why is this different, given that we are talking about documents which have the potential to bind people, other than the parties to their making, to them?

It seems to me that the Democrats ought to give serious consideration to this matter. They may not think it is serious but, on the other hand, what is there to hide by the testing of certified agreements by registered employee organisations? I would be interested to hear the views of Senator Campbell and Senator Murray on this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Brien, I think you really hit the nail on the head when you said that you have heard the arguments in relation to uninvited parties. You believe they do not stand up. We believe they do.

BREAK.PARA: The government, through its legislation as it is being amended as we go along, wants to create a different system to what we have. Basically, employees will have the choice as to whether or not they seek the involvement of a union. We believe they should have that choice. You believe that unions or employee representatives should be able to go there without being invited by employees. We believe amendment 107, which we are debating at the moment, provides rights for intervention by unions that are far too open-ended and vague. We would prefer the employees to have the choice.

As for your argument that we are scared of allowing these agreements to be tested, that is simply not the case. If there is any doubt as to whether they meet the criteria, nothing stands in the way of any of the employees seeking representation. Furthermore, the Industrial Relations Commission itself will test the agreements against the award standards for all employees, present and future.

So it is not a matter of our being worried about having them tested because we want to ensure that individuals in Australia have a choice as to whether they are represented by unions or some other organisation. It is a matter of giving them that choice and ensuring that that choice is freely exercised. I do not expect that we will resolve our difference on that issue here or for many years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether, in the 13 years of Labor government, the number of union members who were senators declined. But I do know that, under 13 years of Labor government, the number of union members in Australia declined enormously. That is part of a world trend, and I accept that. It was probably not the fault of the Labor senators or the then Labor government. It is a fact that two‐thirds of employees are not union members. We as a parliament are not here to defend the privileges of unions; we are here to defend their proper role in society.

SPEECH.PARA: We, as honourable senators know, agree with the government on this matter. Opposition amendment 107 would allow unions to intervene in hearings about agreements where the employees frankly do not want to be represented by them. The rights of employees who do want to be represented by a union are firmly entrenched in these provisions, particularly with amendments from the Democrats to prohibit employers from attempting to coerce employees not to be represented by unions.

Given these protections, we believe there is no argument for unions intervening where the employees do not want them to, as much as the union senators might like that. Unions should confine their activities to representing the 33 per cent of workers who are their members and seeking to persuade the 67 per cent who are not to join, rather than deigning to claim to represent them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make the position very clear that unions in Australia have never just represented the people for whom they have membership. The benefits of unions pass to all workers in Australia year after year. To realise the difference, we only have to look at those countries where unions are illegal or where it is extremely difficult for people to freely organise unions in order to bargain collectively.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a misrepresentation of the situation in Australia to say that the proper role of unions is only to represent their members. I do not believe that has ever been the case, and I would like to think it never will be, because I believe that collective bargaining is essential in Australia and elsewhere. It is for all people in Australia, and it makes for a better work force and better productivity if that ability is maintained. Unionists and unions should not be isolated as being at times, in some industries, pariahs, which I think is a very dangerous thing to have happening in Australia in 1996.
Amendment negatived.

GOVT/DEM 105-121:

These provisions modify section 170MX to add an additional ground where the Commission can arbitrate after a failed bargaining period in respect of paid rates employees. The provisions also are amended to make it clear that determinations under 170MX will be awards rather than orders, adding to their stature.

The additional ground for arbitration is found in 170MW(6A). These provisions establish three conditions for access to the paid rates arbitration. Paragraph (a) established the category of employees generally covered by the provision as the kind of employees who, prior to the commencement of the section, were the kind of employees whose wages and conditions would be covered by a paid rates award, or would have been if an employment agreement had not prevailed over the award. The term "kind of employees" is particularly significant. This refers to the general category of employees rather than to the specific employees themselves. For example, government employees are in all states but Victoria, covered by paid rates awards. And, up until the abolition of their paid rates award in 1992, Victorian workers were also governed by paid rates awards. So clearly, government employees generally, including Victorian workers currently award free, are the "kind of employees" covered by paid rates awards. Similarly, future statutory authorities or Government departments set up within the Government sector would also fall within the category of the "kind of employees" covered by paid rates
awards.

Paragraph (b) adds the further requirement that where that kind of employees were customarily covered by a state or Federal award, they were determined by paid rates award. Again, this clearly picks up the situation of Victorian workers as they were covered by a paid rates award when they had award coverage. But, it would not pick up the situation where the former paid rates award was converted to a minimum rates award as has happened for example, in the building industry.

Paragraph (c) requires the Commission to consider if there is no reasonable prospect of the parties reaching an agreement during the bargaining period. The paid rates provisions, unlike the ground in subsections (2) to (6) does not require the organising or taking of industrial action as a pre-condition to arbitration.

Upon terminating the bargaining period under 170MW, the Commission is required to try to exercise its arbitration powers under 170MX(2) unless it has already attempted conciliation during the bargaining period.

The Commission can then proceed to arbitrate a settlement under 170MX(3), which will take the form of an award. An award under section 170MX(3) will, as made clear in 170MY(2) not be limited by section 89A to allowable matters, or to be a minimum rates awards. Indeed, the intention in moving the new ground 170MW(6A) for paid rates employees is to ensure that they continue to have access to paid rates arrangements, as made clear in paragraph 2.18 of the signed Government/Democrat amendments.

These provisions will ensure that the unequal bargaining relationship for government workers faced with the full legal, political and financial might of a Government employer cannot be used to force them into sub-standard agreements. The access to arbitration of paid rates awards is a vital protection for such employees to ensure that consistent and comprehensive conditions of employment are available right across the area of employment.

It should be pointed out that these provisions are not limited to Government employment, but extent to any categories of employees who, prior to the commencement of this section, were the kind of employees customarily covered by paid rates awards.

The criteria for access to arbitration in 170MW(6A) are not as tough as the "special case" provisions that currently exist. These provisions represent an important protection and a real advance for paid rates employees. I commend them to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: (1) Employees have the right to bargain collectively with their employer in relation to certified agreements through their organisation of employees and to enter into a certified agreement upon a collective basis rather than an AWA if they so choose.
(2) Employees cannot be required to bargain individually in relation to an AWA if they wish to bargain collectively in relation to a certified agreement through their organisation of employees.

(3) An organisation of employees which is entitled to represent the industrial interests of the employee is deemed to represent an employee of an employer in relation to negotiations for a certified agreement unless an employee notifies the employer in writing to the contrary and the employer must duly recognise that organisation as the legitimate bargaining representative of that employee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170LRB Organisation of employees to be notified of intention to negotiate certified agreement with employees

PARA.TAB: An employer who intends to try to negotiate an agreement in accordance with Part VIB or Part VIC of this Act with his or her employees must notify any organisation of employees that is bound by an award that binds that employer in relation to work performed at that enterprise of that intention.

(1) Where more than one employee is prepared to enter into a certified agreement with an employer upon the same or substantially the same terms as the employer is prepared to accept in relation to employees who are prepared to enter into an AWA with that employer, the employer must not refuse to enter into a certified agreement with those employees on those terms.

(2) Where the Commission is satisfied that an employer has refused to enter into a certified agreement with a number of employees in the circumstances referred to in subsection (1), the Commission must, on the application of the employees or an organisation of employees which is entitled to represent the industrial interests of any of the employees, make an award or vary any existing award so as to afford to the employees the same, or substantially the same, wages and conditions as are set out in the AWA.

SPEECH.PARA: I am now asking the chamber to consider our amendment 15 on sheet 217 which originally stood as amendment 43. This amendment inserts new proposed sections 170LRA, 170LRB and 170LRC.

Proposed section 170LRA deals with the right to bargain collectively and ensures that Australia's international obligations to encourage and promote collective bargaining is translated into a substantive provision. This is achieved first by ensuring that employees have the right to collectively bargain and to have their organisations represent them in the bargaining process. Secondly, employees are assured that they cannot be required to bargain individually if they prefer to bargain collectively through their organisation. Finally, an organisation of employees is deemed to represent their members unless a contrary intention appears.

Section 170LRB places a positive obligation upon an employer to notify a union with coverage if they wish to negotiate an Australian workplace agreement or certified agreement. Without this provision, the range of bargaining options available to the potential parties are not fully explored. Section 170LRC ensures that an employer cannot discriminate against an employee who prefers to bargain collectively. Without this provision, collective bargaining is a process entirely at the discretion of the employer. It would become, in many circumstances, a case of `take the individual contract on my terms, or no job'. Already state governments like Victoria and various employers like CRA have adopted such an approach.

Special full benches of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission have spelt out that the legislation is based on the need for collective bargaining with the elevation of individual agreement making and a substantial rewriting of the act. This needs to be expressly stated right now or it could be lost in totality. In short, you have the right to support. If you choose not to have support, that is your right as well. It is extremely difficult for many people in many workplaces in Australia to ensure that right to gain support. So we think it should be there as part of Australia's obligation and, obviously, it is the right of employees to choose not to utilise that support.

We now come to what was Greens (WA) amendment No. 44. It has been replaced by amendments 12 and 13 on revised sheet 217. SPEECH.PARA: (13) Schedule 9, item 19, page 83 (after line 10), after subsection (5), insert:

PARA.TAB: (5A) Without otherwise limiting the generality of subsection (5), provisions relating to discrimination must include provisions to prevent and eliminate discrimination against people on the basis of their sexuality or transgender identity, including provisions to provide non‐discriminatory access to parental leave and carer's leave.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [(12) and (13) are alternative amendments to amendment (44) in document 183]

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment adds a new clause immediately after the anti-discrimination clause in the section relating to when the commission is to refuse to certify an agreement. This new clause specifically states:

. . . provisions relating to discrimination must include provisions to prevent and eliminate discrimination against people on the basis of their sexuality or transgender identity, including provisions to provide non-discriminatory access to parental leave and carer's leave.
It is outrageous that as we head towards the year 2000, lesbians, gay men and people with a transgender identity are still discriminated against in the workplace.

One of the key aspects of this discrimination relates to employment conditions, such as compassionate and bereavement leave, parental leave, carer's leave and superannuation and workers compensation benefits. This amendment addresses two of these crucial areas as a means of raising the need for addressing these issues in industrial relations law.

The reality is that discrimination is happening now and will continue to happen until we address these issues of discrimination. Lesbians, gays and transgenders are not asking for special rights; they are asking for equal rights. I would like honourable senators to put themselves in the position of a gay or lesbian worker whose long‐term partner becomes serious ill and requires home care. Can you imagine the anger and frustration when leave to care for that partner is denied because there is no recognition of the relationship, when a fellow worker who may have been married for only a matter of weeks or months is unquestionably granted such leave. I am not saying that they should not be granted leave; I am saying that this is not a special exemption for a minority group but a question of basic human rights.

I had a request for an interview on this particular section on Western Australian radio. At the end of some questions and answers the interviewer, Liam Bartlett, said, `Don't you think this is a bit odd for a Green senator to be moving this, you know?' I said, `Excuse me? Could you explain what you mean?' He said, `For a Green senator to be involved with gay and lesbian issues and transgender identity.' I said, `Isn't it interesting that you haven't asked me why the Greens are involved with industrial relations?' He assumed that Greens senators only deal with the environment, but he did not assume that it was odd that we should be involved in basic human rights or basic participatory democracy issues.

I then explained that the four pillars of green politics are environmental sustainability, human rights, participatory democracy and peace and disarmament. There was no question as to why we are involved in industrial relations. Perhaps they understood that over the years we have been involved in those issues, but the funny thing is he said that it is odd that we should be involved in fighting for basic human rights for people in the workplace. I thought the question was odd but at least I detected an embarrassed silence—that is what I would like to think—as a result of that response.

If you were a person who had gone through the process of changing your gender identity and you had children, why should you be picked out from amongst all the workers in your workplace as the one person who is not allowed carers leave, whether it is for children or for a partner? Why should you be picked out as a person who does not have a right when other people do? I commend this amendment to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.

BREAK.PARA: On an application to the Commission to certify, vary, extend, terminate or otherwise deal with a certified agreement between an employer and employees, an organisation of employees is entitled to be heard if the organisation is bound by an award that binds that employer in relation to work performed at the enterprise or is entitled to represent the industrial interests of any of the employees covered by the agreement.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170LWB Possible disadvantage may be rectified by undertakings

BREAK.PARA: (1) Where the Commission forms the view that the effect of an agreement made under this Division would be to disadvantage employees who, for any reason, may not have had their interests sufficiently considered in the making of the agreement, the Commission may make an award to rectify such disadvantage.

(2) For the purposes of subsection (1), and without limiting its generality, an employee may not have had his or her interests sufficiently considered because they fall into one or more of the following classes of employee:

PARA.TAB: (a) women;
(b) persons whose first language is not English;
(c) young persons;
(d) part‐time or casual employees;
(e) persons with disabilities.

BREAK.PARA: (3) If under this section, the Commission forms the view that the effect of an agreement made under this Act is to disadvantage employees, the Commission may accept an undertaking from one or more persons who made the agreement in relation to the operation of the agreement and, if satisfied that the undertaking has the effect of removing the disadvantage identified by the Commission, may refuse to make an order under subsection (1).
(4) The Commission's powers and jurisdiction are unrestrained by any other provision of this Act when acting pursuant to this section.

This amendment inserts two new clauses, clause 170LWA and clause 170LWB after clause 170LW. Clause 170LWA seeks substantively to maintain the right of unions to intervene at the commission approval stage when they are bound by an award or have coverage of the employees concerned. The role of unions in the certification process is a critical check and balance in the system of approval which ensures that legislative safeguards are being substantially delivered. The average person does not walk around with a copy of the industrial relations legislation in their pocket or even have it close handy at the workplace.

Clause 170LWB ensures that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has a broad capacity to accept undertakings to rectify disadvantage in circumstances where such action is warranted. As the amendment states, examples of such disadvantaged groups include women, persons whose first language is not English, young workers, part‐time or casual employees and persons with disabilities. This is an important backstop provision and highlights the importance that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission can play in industrial relations issues.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of schedule 10, enterprise flexibility agreements, the opposition accepts the repeal of the existing EFA provisions. We accept that given the introduction of AWAs and of non‐union certified agreements, it would be too complex and confusing to maintain EFAs as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I do just want to use this as an occasion to note the hypocrisy of this government and of Mr Reith on their new industrial relations regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Excuse me, Senator Sherry, I would ask you to withdraw that.

—Yes, I withdraw that. I just want to highlight the conflicting positions of Mr Reith. Mr Reith has always been a great critic of the EFA provisions. He always trumpeted the fact that since their introduction EFAs had not been picked up in anything like significant numbers. This vindicated Mr Reith—it showed that EFAs were a failure. Now I find that Mr Reith, in a speech to CEDA just last Monday, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We will not for example be measuring the success of the legislation by simply counting the number of employees covered by Australian Workplace Agreements.

What an amazing comment, given his previous comments. A total flip in his position. It was good enough to measure the success of our legislation by counting the number of employees covered by EFAs; but he will not be applying the same measure to his own legislation. An amazing position. I will leave it to the Senate to determine whether that is hypocrisy or not.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a page on our remaining comments in respect of schedule 10.
Leave granted.
The comments read as follows—

I have already explained why the Opposition accepts the repeal of the EFA provisions. These specific amendments provide various provisions in relation to existing EFAs that are commensurate with those to be introduced by this Bill in relation to certified agreements. The Opposition accepts that this is appropriate. Any criticisms that we have already made about the various provisions as they apply to certified agreement will of course apply equally in the case of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments and then incorporate some further comments on this schedule. As in the case of the certified agreement schedule, I will again table for incorporation in Hansard a detailed document explaining the opposition's response to the various government‐Democrat and Green amendments and detailing our own amendments on schedule 11.

SPEECH.PARA: In these brief comments, I would like to focus primarily on the substance of the government‐Democrat deal in relation to AWAs. At the outset, I should say that the opposition recognises that the amendments to be introduced as part of this deal do represent an improvement on the bill as it was originally drafted. In particular, the introduction of the pre‐agreement review is welcomed. So too is the application of a no disadvantage test.

For this reason, we will vote in support of those amendments that give effect to the deal. But it should not be thought for one moment that the opposition believes these amendments go far enough. Far from it, we believe the bill, as amended, will still have some significant flaws. I just want to highlight some of the more important ones. First and foremost, we are disappointed that the bill will still allow AWAs to be entered into before employment commences. Blind Freddy can see that this creates the potential for AWAs to be offered to prospective employees as a condition of employment. In fact, not only could blind Freddy see this; so could Senator Murray. In his Senate report at page 342, he had this to say:

BREAK.PARA: The Democrats endorse the views of the Majority report that the ability to enter into individual AWAs with new and prospective employees is a matter of concern.

Of course it is, Senator Murray. And, as you know, it is a concern because prospective employees in a weak bargaining period will have no choice but to accept the AWA. How can they possibly be expected to stoically insist on commencing employment on an agreement or under the award? It is this more than anything that will open the floodgates to a wave of individual contracts in the work force; this more than anything will see the downfall of collective bargaining.
Again, I remind Senator Murray that, in one of his recommendations in his Senate report on page 339, he said:

It is recommended that the bill seek to expressly encourage collective over individual bargaining, but allow for individual bargaining of AWAs where the conditions of the AWA as a whole are superior to the award, and that the employee genuinely and freely agrees to the AWA.

Anyone who believes that an employee who accepts an AWA as a condition of employment `genuinely and freely agrees' to it is showing his naivety. No‐one could ever accuse Mr Reith of this. He knows all too well the effects of this provision. Little wonder that he must have pressed very hard for its retention. It is a pity that the Democrats have wilted.

The opposition is also very disappointed that the review of AWAs will largely be carried out by the Employment Advocate and not by the commission. Worse still, the process will be a bureaucratic one conducted in secret without knowledge or intervention by unions.
This was, of course, one of the issues on which the Democrats have some form. Their pre‐election form was certainly impressive. They said:

The Commission must maintain a central role in vetting all enterprise agreements. Its powers to review enterprise agreements should if anything, be increased, to ensure the balance between work and family does not further decline.
The small business Employment Advocate would complement, but not replace, the AIRC and all agreements would still need to be ratified by the AIRC.

We support unions having the right to be heard on matters before the AIRC which have the potential to impact on their members, including test cases and the registration of enterprise agreements with significant flow‐on potential.
The Democrats' Senate report form was also impressive. At page 340, Senator Murray said:
The Democrats endorse the recommendation of the Majority Report that AWAs must be vetted by the AIRC before approval.
Now it seems that the Democrats have been nobbled. The minister has been slipping downers into the numerous cups of coffee that he must have proffered to the Democrats during their negotiations—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you write this stuff, Nick?
—Put your heart into it.
—Senator Abetz, if you had to be here until midnight with the odd cigarette and water break, as Senator Campbell and I have had to enjoy!

BREAK.PARA: The Democrats are now going to struggle to get to the post. Senator Murray, we are going to give you a hand. We will move amendments that put into place your pre‐election commitment and your Senate report recommendation that AWAs must be vetted by the commission. Now that you are free from the minister's coffee, you can join with us in voting for these amendments. You can help us put into effect your own beliefs. If you do not have the courage to do this, at least have the decency not to stop us from doing so.

There are some 10 or 11 pages of further comment that I would love to make about the Australian Democrats, but I will follow our procedure, given the time, to enhance the consideration of the bill. I will seek leave to incorporate these comments in Hansard.
Leave granted.
