For reasons that have already been explained, the Opposition supports those amendments on the basis that they represent an improvement to the original Bill. We will therefore vote in support of this amendment.

But the Opposition is still committed to the alternative proposals to which we have given effect by our various amendments. The Opposition will therefore still move those amendments to this definition section that remain relevant to our alternative proposals (see Opp (1)—(6) Sheet 229).
Given Govt/Dems (134) this amendment is no longer relevant and we will therefore no longer move it.

In our alternative proposal the Opposition deletes the amended Bill's provisions concerning pre‐employment AWAs (see Opp (9)). This amendment therefore deletes the definitions of "employee" and "employer".

In our alternative proposal the Opposition requires all documents to be filed with the Commission rather than the Employment Advocate (see, for eg, Opp (202)). This amendment therefore deletes reference to the Employment Advocate in the definition of "file" and insert reference to the Commission.
Given Govt/Dems (134) this amendment is no longer relevant and we will therefore no longer move it.
In our alternative proposal the opposition transfers the expiry date provisions from s170VH to s170VG(6). This amendment is a consequential amendment to the definition of "nominal expiry date".
In our alternative proposal the Opposition deletes the amended Bill's provisions concerning termination notices. This amendment therefore deletes the definition of "termination notice".

The Bill provides that a reference to an AWA in the Act includes a reference to a proposed AWA. In our alternative proposals the Opposition deletes the Bill's provisions concerning pre‐employment AWAs. This amendment therefore deletes this provision.
The Opposition supports this amendment on the basis that it is a necessary part of the amendment introduced by the Government/Democrats, particularly by Govt/Dems (134).
This amendment inserts a new division which deals with the right to bargain collectively (s170VCA) and non discrimination against collective bargaining (s170VCB).

Proposed section 170VCA prohibits an employer from requiring an employee to bargain for an AWA, or from coercing an employee to enter into an AWA, if the employee has indicated that he or she would prefer to bargain collectively (through their union) for a certified agreement.
Proposed section 170VCB prohibits an employer from discriminating against employees who prefer to enter into a certified agreement where there are other employees who prefer to enter into an AWA.

The Opposition believes that the Bill cannot and should not ignore the ability of an employer to promote individual contracts in order to undermine employees' access to the protection of collective bargaining. These provisions ensure that there can be no discrimination against those who choose to bargain collectively (for eg, through certified agreements) rather than individually (for eg, through AWAs). They also ensure that collective bargaining is promoted and encouraged.
I have already explained the reasons why the Opposition is prepared to support this amendment as a whole. The Opposition will therefore vote in support of these provisions.

But the Opposition is still committed to the alternative proposals to which we have given effect by our various amendments. These alternative proposals address a number of the deficiencies that are still evident in the Bill even after amendment by Govt/Dems (134). The Opposition will therefore still move those amendments.
The Opposition will vote for this amendment because it improves the amended Bill.
The Opposition will not vote for this amendment for reasons that have been previously explained.
The Opposition does not support these amendments because we have doubts about the practical operation of the proposals.
The Opposition will vote for these amendments because they improve the amended Bill.
The Opposition will not vote for this amendment for reasons that have been previously explained.
The Opposition will vote for these amendments because they improve the amended Bill.

This amendment provides that an AWA or ancillary document has no effect before it has been filed (with the Commission), reviewed and approved by the Commission. The amended Bill is deficient in the case of new employees by providing that an AWA has no effect before a filing receipt is issued. This means that an AWA can become effective before it is approved by the Employment Advocate, in which case the new employee must bring civil court proceedings in order to recover any subsequently discovered shortfalls in entitlements. This is a entirely unfair position for new employees. It can only be addressed by ensuring that an AWA cannot become effective at least until the approval process is complete.

In a section headed "Collective AWAs" it is provided that 2 or more agreements negotiated collectively can be included in the one document if the one employer is a party. This amendment amends the heading to label these agreements "Common document AWAs" and deletes reference to agreements being negotiated collectively. These changes more accurately reflect the true nature of these AWAs. It stresses that they are not collective instruments and are not the outcome of collective bargaining. AWAs are intrinsically individual contracts, and this should not be camouflaged by reference to collective terminology.

The Bill provides that an AWA may be made before the commencement of employment. This amendment deletes this. As has already been stated the proposal to permit employees to enter into AWAs before employment commences creates the potential for AWAs to be proffered on a "take it or leave it" basis. This will permit pressure to be applied to vulnerable employees seeking work to accept lower wages and conditions.

This amendment also inserts a new provision which requires the employer or employee to file the AWA with the Commission and to make an application for approval by the Commission within 21 days of the AWA being made. This provides the procedural mechanism to give effect to pre‐agreement review of AWAs by the Commission.

This amendment inserts new provisions headed "Requirements for AWAs". It provides that the Commission must subject AWAs to public review for the purposes of approving or not approving them. It provides that an AWA must not, in relation to the terms and conditions of employment, disadvantage the subject employee. This means an AWA cannot be approved if:

i. there is a reduction in the employees' entitlements and protections under any applicable Federal award (including any award the Commission determines is appropriate for establishing the entitlements and protections of the employee), certified agreement or State award or under any Federal or State law; and
ii. that reduction is contrary to the public interest.

The amendment also provides that the Commission must also be satisfied that the employee has genuinely made the AWA. Further, the Commission must not approve the AWA if the employer has breached, or caused a breach, of the right to bargain collectively or of the prohibition on discrimination against collective bargaining (see Opp (201)). The Commission also must not approve the AWA if it discriminates on any ground, and in particular, if after 22 June 1997 it discriminates by providing for junior rates of pay.

The Opposition is moving this amendment because it believes there is an overwhelming case for independent review of AWAs by the Commission before they come into force. This is the only effective way to ensure that employees, particularly the more vulnerable, have genuinely made the agreement (free from any coercion) and have been provided with the requisite terms and conditions of employment. The Commission is best‐suited to this task. It has the knowledge and experience to properly assess the AWA. Further, because the Commission (as we have seen) plays the reviewing role in the case of certified agreements and applies the same `no disadvantage test', it makes sense to give the same body the task reviewing role in the case of AWAs.

As to the requirement that the AWA be genuinely made, it is important that the Commission consider and determine this to ensure the AWA is not the product of, for eg, threats, failures to inform etc. In relation to the required non‐approval for breach of the various prohibitions the Opposition believes this is the most effective means of giving effect to these prohibitions (ie ensuring that an agreement which was entered into in breach of the prohibitions will never be effective). As to junior wage rates, these should not be introduced into AWAs for the same reasons—already sated—that they should be removed from certified agreements.
This amendment deletes the provisions which require an expiry date (we re‐enact them in s170VG(6)). An appropriate change is made to the heading of this section.

This amendment provides that an extension has no effect unless it is filed with the Commission and approved by the Commission. The Commission must be satisfied that the employee has genuinely approved the extension. The Opposition believes that it is important that the Commission review and approve any agreement to extend an AWA to ensure that employees, particularly the more vulnerable, have genuinely agreed to the extension (free from any coercion).
This amendment provides that an extension has effect from the date of approval by the Commission or the date nominated in the AWA.
This amendment provides that an AWA operates from the date of approval by the Commission or the date nominated in the AWA until the date the AWA is terminated or replaced by another AWA.

This amendment permits an employer or employee to appoint a person (eg. a union) to be his or her agent in relation to any proceedings concerning AWAs. The Opposition believes it is important for an employee to have the option of representation in legal proceedings (as a party principal) by an agent. Unions have traditionally had the capacity to represent employees in this capacity in legal proceedings. It also means that the one agent can bring one proceeding on behalf of a number of employees who are all alleging the same breaches (ie no need for each employee to bring a separate proceeding).

This amendment inserts a new provision which requires an employer to ensure that the employee has reasonable access to information about persons able to act as a bargaining agent. In order for the bargaining agent provision to be effective, an employer must be obliged to advise employees about the right to a bargaining agent, and about who may act in that capacity. Otherwise, an employer mat set out to negotiate with the employee even though the employee is not even aware that he or she can be represented in the negotiations.

The amended Bill requires an employer and employee to recognise the other party's bargaining agent. Whilst accepting this, this amendment also requires the employer and employee to bargain with the other party's bargaining agent. The right to a bargaining agent is totally undermined if the employer is required to recognise the bargaining agent but can refuse to bargain with it. The employer could refuse to bargain until the "right" bargaining agent was appointed by the employee.

This amendment provides that a variation of an AWA must be approved by the Commission; further, that the Commission can only approve the variation if it is satisfied that the employee genuinely approves the variation and that the Commission would be required to approve the AWA as varied if it were a new AWA whose approval was applied for. The Opposition moves this amendment because the arguments in support of review of AWAs in the first instance apply equally to variations to AWAs. The arguments as to genuine approval of AWAs in the first instance also apply equally to variations to AWAs. The same "no disadvantage" test must also be applied.

This amendment requires that a termination of an AWA must be approved by the Commission; further, that the Commission can only approve the termination if it is satisfied that the employee genuinely approves the termination and it would be in the public interest for the AWA to be terminated. The Commission should be entitled to exercise a public interest discretion in deciding whether to approve termination of an AWA. Termination may cause drastic consequences for the employee (if there is no new agreement and the employee will return to basic award entitlements) and so the Commission should be entitled to hear why these consequences are being agreed to, and if it thinks necessary, prevent these consequences from occurring. The proposal to permit unilaterally termination after the expiry date is very unfair as it gives the employer disproportionate bargaining power. It will enable an employer to threaten the employee with significant reductions to existing entitlements (ie back to the basic award entitlements) if he or she doesn't agree to proposals for a new agreement by the time of expiry of the old agreement.
The amended Bill says that AWAs and ancillary documents may be filed with the Employment advocate. We provide that they must be filed with the Commission
The amended Bill provides for the issuing of a filing receipt by the Employment Advocate. We delete this.
In the procedural provisions for filing this amendment deletes reference to the Employment Advocate and insert reference to the Commission.
Given Govt/Dems (134) this amendment is no longer necessary and the Opposition will not move it.
In the provisions requiring an accurate declaration by the employer to the Employment Advocate this amendment deletes reference to the Employment Advocate and inserts reference to the Commission.
Given that Govt/Dems (134) is to the same effect as this amendment it is redundant and the Opposition no longer moves it.
The Opposition will vote for this amendment on the basis that it is an improvement on the original Bill. But the provision is still inadequate, and these inadequacies are addressed by Opp (227)

The amended Bill provides that during the period of operation of an AWA it operates to the exclusion of any otherwise applicable Federal award or State award or agreement. This amendment provides that this is the case only to the extent of any inconsistency between the AWA and award or agreement. This is necessary because if this exclusion provision was unfettered it would mean that a Federal award or State award or agreement (dealing with say 50 employment conditions) would be wholly excluded by an AWA (even though the AWA may only deal with say 5 employment conditions). Our amendment means that insofar as the AWA deals with an employment condition (and because of the "no disadvantage" test it will generally provide a superior condition) that will apply, but otherwise the existing award or agreement will apply.

The Bill provides that an AWA operates subject to any provisions in a State law dealing with occupational health and safety, workers' compensation, apprenticeship or other prescribed matters. This amendment adds that this is not the case if the provisions of the State law are less favourable to the employee than the certified agreement. Employers and employees should not be able to contract out of entitlements provided by State law in such important matters as OH & S, workers' compensation and apprenticeship arrangements. But they should be able to contract for better entitlements.

The Bill provides for a delay in proceedings taken to check compliance with the statutory minimum conditions. This amendment deletes this provision because it is unfair that an employee who has legitimated started proceedings (and incurred expense) can have the proceedings stopped for reasons beyond his or her knowledge.

The Bill prescribes a maximum penalty of $10,000 for corporations and $2,000 for others for breach of provisions in this Part. This amendment amends these maximum amounts to $1,000 and $500 respectively. Penalties of the amount proposed simply show that the focus of this Bill is on punishment (not on achieving cooperative outcomes).

The Bill provides that enforcement proceedings may be brought by a party to an AWA. This amendment provides that such proceedings may also be brought by an agent of the party (appointed under section 170VK(1)).

In the penalty provisions this amendment adds a reference to new ss170VCA and 170VCB and to new s170VK(1A). In order to enforce the requirements we introduce to provide bargaining agent information to an employee and not to discriminate against collective bargaining these need to be included as penalty provisions.
The Opposition supports this amendment because it is an improvement on the original Bill.

The Opposition notes that Govt/Dems (136) achieves the effect that these amendments were intended to achieve. On that basis these amendments are no longer necessary and the Opposition will not move them.
The Bill provides an injunction power for breach of provisions in this Part. We qualify the injunction power by providing that:

i. an injunction (whether interim or final) cannot be granted in the absence of the other party unless the Court is satisfied that the applicant has given notice of the application to the other person;
ii. an interim injunction cannot be granted unless the Court is satisfied that:
(a) the applicant is likely to succeed at the trial of the action; and

PARA.TAB: (b) not granting the injunction will inevitably expose the applicant to loss or harm for which an award of damages is a wholly inadequate remedy.

BREAK.PARA: The Opposition moves this amendment to modify the injunction power so as to considerably reduce its destructive potential against unions. This is done in two ways—ensuring that an employer cannot "rush off to court behind the union's back" to get an interim injunction; providing very strict requirements before an interim injunction will ordered. This ensures at least that the merits of the dispute will be heard by the Court before an injunction will be ordered.

The Bill provides that whilst an employer is not to prejudice an employee for engaging in protected industrial action, this does not apply to an employer standing‐down an employee or refusing to pay an employee pursuant to a common law right. This amendment amends the first exception applying it only where the employer has sought, and the Commission has approved, a stand down. We delete the second exception. The Opposition moves these amendments because an employee's right to engage in protected action is fundamentally undermined by these proposals. An unfettered capacity for the employer to stand‐down or to refuse to pay an employee during industrial action gives the employer disproportionate bargaining power. The employer can "starve the employees into submission".
The Opposition supports this amendment because it is to the same effect as Opp (238), which of course the Government voted against in the House of Representatives.
Given Govt/Dems (137) this amendment is no longer necessary and we will not be moving it.

The Bill provides a regulation‐making power in respect of AWAs. This amendment deletes the power to make regulations concerning the qualifications and appointment of bargaining agents. It is inappropriate for regulations to determine who can be a bargaining agent (eg by this method unions could be excluded as bargaining agents).

The Bill prohibits a person from using duress or making a misleading statement in connection with an AWA. Whilst accepting this, this amendment adds a further prohibition against a person using improper influence (including statements to the effect that if the person is not willing to sign an AWA the person will not be employed or will not continue to be employed). The Opposition believes that the concepts the duress and misleading statement are not broad enough to cover all conduct which should be prohibited in relation to an employee entering into an AWA. Any improper influence, including "gun at the head" statements should also be prohibited.

The Opposition is opposed to this amendment. This amendment ensures that AWAs effectively remain secret; it confines the right to a hearing to just the parties and their bargaining agent; it provides that Commission hearings must be held in private. Each of these proposals is flawed. The public at large have a legitimate interest in knowing that the Employment Advocate and Commission are performing their functions—that are essentially public functions—appropriately. Organisations such as unions have a legitimate interest in ensuring that to the extent that AWAs affect their interests in awards they are able to be heard before that interest is affected.
This amendment is no longer relevant and will not be moved.
The Bill provides that regulations may prescribe the fees for the issue by the Employment Advocate of certificates and verified copies of documents. this is an inappropriate matter for regulations.
The Opposition supports this amendment if no Opposition amendments have been agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have a fundamental problem with this move to individual contracts and, as a consequence, I flag that our amendment opposes the entire schedule 11. Looking at the list, I can see that will be moved much later. The Brotherhood of St Laurence highlighted their concerns about this move to individual contracts in their submission to the committee. They stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The rationale for placing the primary responsibility for industrial relations with employers and employees at the workplace is `to provide more effective choice and flexibility for parties in reaching agreements' according to the guide in the bill. But those most disadvantage in the labour market bring little power to the bargaining relationship judging by the experiences of the participants in our focus groups. For those workers with little bargaining power, collective representation ensured some protection of their rights.

The social responsibility and justice committee of the Uniting Church pointed to similar concerns in their submission to the Senate committee. They highlighted the push to an individualistic understanding of life and stated that this ignores the fact that human beings are essentially communal. They went on to say:

BREAK.PARA: Labour is a social act. No‐one labours alone. Labour demands cooperation and social organisation and thus is one of the actions which both encourages and helps develop language, social values and symbols that hold society together. Work is an activity which maintains human existence. It is important that we understand work to be not just for the maintenance of our personal life but for our social existence. It is also through labour that one is socialised into the values of the community. As such, labour affects family, political organisation, religious life and one's sense of community.

Obviously there have been lots of comments by workers, employee associations and unions during committee hearings and in their submissions, but it is important that those people in the community who are seeing the outcomes of the current workplace environment and have serious and real concerns for the future are saying these things as well. So I think we should be listening.

Given that the Democrats accept the move to individual contracts, our amendment 48 will, presumably, be defeated. But that will not stop us from putting it. We have, therefore, proposed a number of amendments which, in conjunction with the ALP amendments, attempt to ameliorate the worst of the impacts of this move to individual contracts, and I will explain those as we go along.

In relation to the definition of `sure', are you sure that you want the definition of `sure' to read like that, because it is a very high onus indeed?

This amendment inserts a new provision which requires an employer to ensure that the employee has reasonable access to information about persons able to act as a bargaining agent. In order for the bargaining agent provision to be effective, an employer must be obliged to advise employees about the right to a bargaining agent, and about who may act in that capacity. Otherwise, an employer mat set out to negotiate with the employee even though the employee is not even aware that he or she can be represented in the negotiations.

The amended Bill requires an employer and employee to recognise the other party's bargaining agent. Whilst accepting this, this amendment also requires the employer and employee to bargain with the other party's bargaining agent. The right to a bargaining agent is totally undermined if the employer is required to recognise the bargaining agent but can refuse to bargain with it. The employer could refuse to bargain until the "right" bargaining agent was appointed by the employee.

This amendment provides that a variation of an AWA must be approved by the Commission; further, that the Commission can only approve the variation if it is satisfied that the employee genuinely approves the variation and that the Commission would be required to approve the AWA as varied if it were a new AWA whose approval was applied for. The Opposition moves this amendment because the arguments in support of review of AWAs in the first instance apply equally to variations to AWAs. The arguments as to genuine approval of AWAs in the first instance also apply equally to variations to AWAs. The same "no disadvantage" test must also be applied.

This amendment requires that a termination of an AWA must be approved by the Commission; further, that the Commission can only approve the termination if it is satisfied that the employee genuinely approves the termination and it would be in the public interest for the AWA to be terminated. The Commission should be entitled to exercise a public interest discretion in deciding whether to approve termination of an AWA. Termination may cause drastic consequences for the employee (if there is no new agreement and the employee will return to basic award entitlements) and so the Commission should be entitled to hear why these consequences are being agreed to, and if it thinks necessary, prevent these consequences from occurring. The proposal to permit unilaterally termination after the expiry date is very unfair as it gives the employer disproportionate bargaining power. It will enable an employer to threaten the employee with significant reductions to existing entitlements (ie back to the basic award entitlements) if he or she doesn't agree to proposals for a new agreement by the time of expiry of the old agreement.
The amended Bill says that AWAs and ancillary documents may be filed with the Employment advocate. We provide that they must be filed with the Commission
The amended Bill provides for the issuing of a filing receipt by the Employment Advocate. We delete this.
In the procedural provisions for filing this amendment deletes reference to the Employment Advocate and insert reference to the Commission.
Given Govt/Dems (134) this amendment is no longer necessary and the Opposition will not move it.
In the provisions requiring an accurate declaration by the employer to the Employment Advocate this amendment deletes reference to the Employment Advocate and inserts reference to the Commission.
Given that Govt/Dems (134) is to the same effect as this amendment it is redundant and the Opposition no longer moves it.
The Opposition will vote for this amendment on the basis that it is an improvement on the original Bill. But the provision is still inadequate, and these inadequacies are addressed by Opp (227)

The amended Bill provides that during the period of operation of an AWA it operates to the exclusion of any otherwise applicable Federal award or State award or agreement. This amendment provides that this is the case only to the extent of any inconsistency between the AWA and award or agreement. This is necessary because if this exclusion provision was unfettered it would mean that a Federal award or State award or agreement (dealing with say 50 employment conditions) would be wholly excluded by an AWA (even though the AWA may only deal with say 5 employment conditions). Our amendment means that insofar as the AWA deals with an employment condition (and because of the "no disadvantage" test it will generally provide a superior condition) that will apply, but otherwise the existing award or agreement will apply.

The Bill provides that an AWA operates subject to any provisions in a State law dealing with occupational health and safety, workers' compensation, apprenticeship or other prescribed matters. This amendment adds that this is not the case if the provisions of the State law are less favourable to the employee than the certified agreement. Employers and employees should not be able to contract out of entitlements provided by State law in such important matters as OH & S, workers' compensation and apprenticeship arrangements. But they should be able to contract for better entitlements.

The Bill provides for a delay in proceedings taken to check compliance with the statutory minimum conditions. This amendment deletes this provision because it is unfair that an employee who has legitimated started proceedings (and incurred expense) can have the proceedings stopped for reasons beyond his or her knowledge.

The Bill prescribes a maximum penalty of $10,000 for corporations and $2,000 for others for breach of provisions in this Part. This amendment amends these maximum amounts to $1,000 and $500 respectively. Penalties of the amount proposed simply show that the focus of this Bill is on punishment (not on achieving cooperative outcomes).

The Bill provides that enforcement proceedings may be brought by a party to an AWA. This amendment provides that such proceedings may also be brought by an agent of the party (appointed under section 170VK(1)).

In the penalty provisions this amendment adds a reference to new ss170VCA and 170VCB and to new s170VK(1A). In order to enforce the requirements we introduce to provide bargaining agent information to an employee and not to discriminate against collective bargaining these need to be included as penalty provisions.
The Opposition supports this amendment because it is an improvement on the original Bill.

The Opposition notes that Govt/Dems (136) achieves the effect that these amendments were intended to achieve. On that basis these amendments are no longer necessary and the Opposition will not move them.
The Bill provides an injunction power for breach of provisions in this Part. We qualify the injunction power by providing that:

i. an injunction (whether interim or final) cannot be granted in the absence of the other party unless the Court is satisfied that the applicant has given notice of the application to the other person;
ii. an interim injunction cannot be granted unless the Court is satisfied that:
(a) the applicant is likely to succeed at the trial of the action; and

PARA.TAB: (b) not granting the injunction will inevitably expose the applicant to loss or harm for which an award of damages is a wholly inadequate remedy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition moves this amendment to modify the injunction power so as to considerably reduce its destructive potential against unions. This is done in two ways—ensuring that an employer cannot "rush off to court behind the union's back" to get an interim injunction; providing very strict requirements before an interim injunction will ordered. This ensures at least that the merits of the dispute will be heard by the Court before an injunction will be ordered.

The Bill provides that whilst an employer is not to prejudice an employee for engaging in protected industrial action, this does not apply to an employer standing‐down an employee or refusing to pay an employee pursuant to a common law right. This amendment amends the first exception applying it only where the employer has sought, and the Commission has approved, a stand down. We delete the second exception. The Opposition moves these amendments because an employee's right to engage in protected action is fundamentally under mined by these proposals. An unfettered capacity for the employer to stand‐down or to refuse to pay an employee during industrial action gives the employer disproportionate bargaining power. The employer can "starve the employees into submission".
The Opposition supports this amendment because it is to the same effect as Opp (238), which of course the Government voted against in the House of Representatives.
Given Govt/Dems (137) this amendment is no longer necessary and we will not be moving it.

The Bill provides a regulation‐making power in respect of AWAs. This amendment deletes the power to make regulations concerning the qualifications and appointment of bargaining agents. It is inappropriate for regulations to determine who can be a bargaining agent (eg by this method unions could be excluded as bargaining agents).

The Bill prohibits a person from using duress or making a misleading statement in connection with an AWA. Whilst accepting this, this amendment adds a further prohibition against a person using improper influence (including statements to the effect that if the person is not willing to sign an AWA the person will not be employed or will not continue to be employed). The Opposition believes that the concepts the duress and misleading statement are not broad enough to cover all conduct which should be prohibited in relation to an employee entering into an AWA. Any improper influence, including "gun at the head" statements should also be prohibited.

The Opposition is opposed to this amendment. This amendment ensures that AWAs effectively remain secret; it confines the right to a hearing to just the parties and their bargaining agent; it provides that Commission hearings must be held in private. Each of these proposals is flawed. The public at large have a legitimate interest in knowing that the Employment Advocate and Commission are performing their functions—that are essentially public functions—appropriately. Organisations such as unions have a legitimate interest in ensuring that to the extent that AWAs affect their interests in awards they are able to be heard before that interest is affected.
This amendment is no longer relevant and will not be moved.
The Bill provides that regulations may prescribe the fees for the issue by the Employment Advocate of certificates and verified copies of documents. this is an inappropriate matter for regulations.
The Opposition supports this amendment if no Opposition amendments have been agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
(133) Schedule 11, item 3, page 120 (after line 28), at the end of Division 1, add:
(1) The Commission must, as far as practicable, perform its functions under this Part in a way that furthers the objects of this Act.
(2) Section 90 does not apply to the performance of functions of the Commission under this Part.
(3) In performing its functions under this Part, the Commission may not act under paragraph 111(1)(g) on the grounds specified in subparagraph (i), (ii) or (iii) of that paragraph.
Amendment (by Senator Sherry) negatived:
(201) Schedule 11, item 3, page 119 (after line 28), after section 170VC insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) Employees have the right:

TAB.TAB: (a) to bargain collectively with their employer, through the organisation of employees to which they belong; and
(b) to enter into a certified agreement rather than an AWA if they choose.

PARA.TAB: (2) Where an employee indicates that he or she wishes to bargain collectively for a certified agreement, rather than bargain for an AWA, an employer must not require the employee to bargain for an AWA.

(3) Where an employee indicates that he or she wishes to bargain collectively for a certified agreement, rather than bargain for an AWA, an employer must not coerce or otherwise attempt to induce the employee to enter into an AWA.

TAB.TAB: 170VCB No discrimination against collective bargaining

PARA.TAB: An employer must not discriminate between employees of the employer because some of the employees prefer to enter into a certified agreement or otherwise bargain collectively with the employer while others prefer to enter into an AWA.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Campbell) proposed:
(134) Schedule 11, item 3, page 120 (line 29) to page 127 (line 9), omit Divisions 2 to 5, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division 2—General rules about AWAs and ancillary documents
170VD AWAs and ancillary documents only have effect as provided by this Part

SPEECH.PARA: An AWA or ancillary document has effect as provided by this Part, and not otherwise. In particular:

PARA.TAB: (a) an AWA for a new employee has no effect before a filing receipt is issued for the AWA; and
(b) an AWA for an existing employee has no effect before an approval notice is issued for the AWA.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) For the purposes of this Part, 2 or more agreements that have been negotiated collectively may be included in the same document if the same employer is a party to all the agreements. The agreements need not be in the same terms.
(2) An AWA for a new employee cannot be included in the same document as an AWA for an existing employee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division 3—Making, varying or terminating an AWA
170VF Employer and employee may make an AWA

SPEECH.PARA: (1) An employer and employee may make a written agreement, called an Australian workplace agreement, that deals with matters pertaining to the relationship between an employer and employee.
(2) The AWA may be made before commencement of the employment.

(1) The employer must ensure that the AWA includes the provisions relating to discrimination that are prescribed by the regulations. If the AWA does not in fact include those provisions, the AWA is taken to include those provisions.
(2) The employer must ensure that the AWA does not include any provisions that prohibit or restrict disclosure of details of the AWA by either party to another person.

(3) The employer must ensure that the AWA includes a dispute resolution procedure. If the AWA does not in fact include a dispute resolution procedure, the AWA is taken to include the model procedure that is prescribed by the regulations.

(4) A dispute resolution procedure that is included in an AWA under subsection (3), or prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of subsection (3), may confer powers on the Commission to settle disputes between the parties to the AWA about the application or interpretation of the AWA. The Commission may exercise those powers.
(1) An AWA may specify a date as its nominal expiry date. The date cannot be more than 3 years after the AWA date.
(2) If no date is specified, then the nominal expiry date is the 3rd anniversary of the AWA date.
(3) An employer and employee may make a written agreement that extends the nominal expiry date. The extended date cannot be more than 3 years after the AWA date.
(4) The extension agreement has no effect unless a filing receipt is issued for the extension agreement at least 21 days before the nominal expiry date that is to be extended.
(5) The extension agreement takes effect on the day after an approval notice is issued for the extension agreement.
(1) An AWA for a new employee starts operating on the later of:

PARA.TAB: (a) the day after a filing receipt is issued for the AWA; or
(b) the day specified in the AWA as the starting day; or
(c) the day the employment commences;
and stops operating at the earlier of the following times:
(d) the end of the day when a refusal notice is issued in relation to the AWA;
(e) the time when a termination under section 170VM takes effect;
(f) the time when another AWA between the employer and employee starts to operate.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) An AWA for an existing employee starts operating on the later of:

PARA.TAB: (a) the day after an approval notice is issued for the AWA; or
(b) the day specified in the AWA as the starting day.
and stops operating at the earlier of the following times:
(c) the time when a termination under section 170VM takes effect;
(d) the time when another AWA between the employer and employee starts to operate.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) An employer or employee may appoint a person to be his or her bargaining agent in relation to the making, approval, variation or termination of an AWA. The appointment must be made in writing.
(2) Subject to subsection (3), an employer or employee must not refuse to recognise a bargaining agent duly appointed by the other party for the purposes of subsection (1).
(3) Subsection (2) does not apply if the person refusing has not been given a copy of the bargaining agent's instrument of appointment before the refusal.
(4) An employer or employee must not coerce, or attempt to coerce, the other party:

PARA.TAB: (a) to appoint, or not to appoint, a particular person as an authorised bargaining agent; or
(b) to terminate the appointment of an authorised bargaining agent.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) In this section:

PARA.TAB: person includes a group of persons.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VL Varying the terms of an AWA

SPEECH.PARA: (1) An employer and employee may make a written agreement varying an AWA.
(2) The variation takes effect on the later of:

PARA.TAB: (a) the day after an approval notice is issued for the variation agreement; or
(b) the day specified in the variation agreement as the date of effect.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Section 170VG applies to the AWA as varied in the same way as that section applies to the original AWA.
(1) The employer and employee may at any time make a written agreement to terminate the AWA.

(2) A termination under subsection (1) takes effect at the end of the day on which an approval notice is issued for the termination agreement or at such later time as is specified in the termination agreement.
(3) After the nominal expiry date of an AWA, the Commission may, on application by either party, terminate the AWA if the Commission considers that it is not contrary to the public interest to do so.
(4) The Commission must issue a copy of its determination to the parties and to the Employment Advocate.
(5) A termination under subsection (3) takes effect at the end of the day on which the Commission issues copies of its determination, or at such later time as is specified in the determination.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Termination in accordance with the AWA

SPEECH.PARA: (6) After the nominal expiry date of an AWA, the employer or the employee may file a termination notice, stating that the AWA is to be terminated in a manner provided for in the AWA.
(7) A termination under subsection (6) takes effect at the end of the day on which an approval notice is issued for the termination notice, or at a later time specified in the termination notice.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division 4—Filing AWAs and ancillary documents with Employment Advocate
170VN Filing AWAs and ancillary documents with Employment Advocate

SPEECH.PARA: (1) An AWA or ancillary document may be filed with the Employment Advocate.
(2) If the Employment Advocate is satisfied that the filing requirements for the document have been met, the Employment Advocate must issue a receipt to the person who filed the document.
(3) The Employment Advocate must not issue a filing receipt for an AWA unless the AWA was filed within 14 days after the AWA date.
(1) The filing requirements for an AWA are:

PARA.TAB: (a) the AWA must be signed and dated by each of the parties, and the signatures must be witnessed; and
(b) the AWA must be accompanied by a declaration by the employer:

TAB.TAB: (i) declaring that the AWA complies with section 170VG; and
(ii) declaring that, before the employee signed the AWA, the employer gave the employee a copy of an information statement prepared by the Employment Advocate; and
(iii) declaring whether or not the employer has offered an AWA in the same terms to all comparable employees; and

PARA.TAB: (c) the employer must have provided any other information that the Employment Advocate requires, by notice published in the Gazette, for the purpose of performing his or her functions.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The information statement prepared by the Employment Advocate for the purposes of subsection (1) must include information about the following matters, but may include other information:

PARA.TAB: (a) Commonwealth statutory entitlements;
(b) occupational health and safety law;
(c) services provided by the Employment Advocate;
(d) bargaining agents.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) The filing requirements for a variation agreement are:

PARA.TAB: (a) the variation agreement must be signed and dated by each of the parties, and the signatures must be witnessed; and
(b) the variation agreement must be accompanied by a declaration by the employer:

TAB.TAB: (i) declaring that the AWA, as varied, complies with section 170VG; and
(ii) declaring whether or not the employer has offered a variation agreement in the same terms to all comparable employees who also have an AWA in the same terms with the employer; and

PARA.TAB: (c) the employer must have provided any other information that the Employment Advocate requires, by notice published in the Gazette, for the purpose of performing his or her functions.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) The filing requirements for an extension agreement are:

PARA.TAB: (a) the extension agreement must be signed and dated by each of the parties, and the signatures must be witnessed; and
(b) the employer must have provided any other information that the Employment Advocate requires, by notice published in the Gazette, for the purpose of performing his or her functions.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) The filing requirements for a termination agreement are:

PARA.TAB: (a) the termination agreement must be signed and dated by each of the parties, and the signatures must be witnessed; and
(b) the employer must have provided any other information that the Employment Advocate requires, by notice published in the Gazette, for the purpose of performing his or her functions.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) The filing requirements for a termination notice are:

PARA.TAB: (a) the termination notice must be signed and dated by the party or parties filing the notice, and each signature must be witnessed; and

(b) the party or parties filing the termination notice must have provided any other information that the Employment Advocate requires, by notice published in the Gazette, for the purpose of performing his or her functions.

SPEECH.PARA: An employer must not, in a declaration filed with the Employment Advocate for the purposes of this Part, make a statement that the employer knows, or ought reasonably to know, is false or misleading.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division 5—Approval of AWAs and ancillary documents
170VPA Additional approval requirements for AWA and ancillary documents

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The additional approval requirements for an AWA are:

PARA.TAB: (a) the AWA complies with section 170VG; and
(b) the employee received a copy of the AWA at least the required number of days before signing the AWA; and
(c) the employer explained the effect of the AWA to the employee between:

TAB.TAB: (i) the time the employee first received a copy of the AWA; and
(ii) the time when the employee signed the AWA; and

PARA.TAB: (d) the employee genuinely consented to making the AWA; and
(e) in a case where the employer failed to offer an AWA in the same terms to all comparable employees—the employer did not act unfairly or unreasonably in failing to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: An employer might have valid reasons for not offering an AWA in the same terms to all comparable employees.
For the purposes of this subsection, the required number of days is 5 for a new employee and 14 for an existing employee.
(2) The additional approval requirements for a variation agreement are:

PARA.TAB: (a) the AWA, as varied, complies with section 170VG; and
(b) the employee received a copy of the variation agreement at least 14 days before signing the variation agreement; and
(c) the employer explained the effect of the variation agreement to the employee between:

TAB.TAB: (i) the time the employee first received a copy of the variation agreement; and
(ii) the time when the employee signed the variation agreement; and

PARA.TAB: (d) the employee genuinely consented to making the variation agreement; and

(e) in a case where the employer did not offer a variation agreement in the same terms to all comparable employees who also have an AWA in the same terms—the employer did not act unfairly or unreasonably in not doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: Note:An employer might have valid reasons for not offering a variation agreement in the same terms to all comparable employees.
(3) The additional approval requirement for an extension agreement is that the employee genuinely consented to making the extension agreement.
(4) The additional approval requirement for a termination agreement is that the employee genuinely consented to making the termination agreement.
(5) The additional approval requirement for a termination notice is that the termination is in accordance with the AWA.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPB Approval of AWA by Employment Advocate

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Employment Advocate must approve an AWA for which a filing receipt has been issued if:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Employment Advocate is sure that the AWA passes the no-disadvantage test; and
(b) the Employment Advocate is satisfied that the AWA meets the additional approval requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Note:The additional approval requirements are in section 170VPA.
(2) If the Employment Advocate has concerns about whether the AWA passes the no-disadvantage test, but those concerns are resolved by:

PARA.TAB: (a) a written undertaking given by the employer and accepted by the Employment Advocate; or
(b) other action by the parties;
the Employment Advocate must approve the AWA.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) If the Employment Advocate has concerns about whether the AWA passes the no-disadvantage test and those concerns are not resolved under subsection (2), the Employment Advocate must refer the AWA to the Commission.
(4) If the Employment Advocate is not satisfied that the AWA meets the additional approval requirements, the Employment Advocate must refuse to approve the AWA.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPC Approval of variation agreement by Employment Advocate

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Employment Advocate must approve a variation agreement for which a filing receipt has been issued if:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Employment Advocate is sure that the AWA, as varied, passes the no-disadvantage test; and
(b) the Employment Advocate is satisfied that the variation agreement meets the additional approval requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Note:The additional approval requirements are in section 170VPA.
(2) If the Employment Advocate has concerns about whether the AWA, as varied, passes the no-disadvantage test, but those concerns are resolved by:

PARA.TAB: (a) a written undertaking given by the employer and accepted by the Employment Advocate; or
(b) other action by the parties;
the Employment Advocate must approve the variation agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) If the Employment Advocate has concerns about whether the AWA, as varied, passes the no-disadvantage test and those concerns are not resolved under subsection (2), the Employment Advocate must refer the variation agreement to the Commission.
(4) If the Employment Advocate is not satisfied that the variation agreement meets the additional approval requirements, the Employment Advocate must refuse to approve the variation agreement.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPD Approval of other ancillary documents by Employment Advocate

SPEECH.PARA: (1) This section applies to the following ancillary documents:

PARA.TAB: (a) an extension agreement;
(b) a termination agreement;
(c) a termination notice.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Employment Advocate must approve the ancillary document if the Employment Advocate is satisfied that the ancillary document meets the additional approval requirements for the document concerned. Otherwise, the Employment Advocate must refuse to approve the ancillary document.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPE Protocol for referring AWAs and variation agreements to the Commission

SPEECH.PARA: (1) As soon as practicable after the commencement of this section, the President must establish a protocol to provide general guidance to the Employment Advocate concerning the referral of AWAs or variation agreements to the Commission. The terms of the protocol must have the concurrence of the Employment Advocate.
(2) In deciding whether to refer an AWA or variation agreement to the Commission, the Employment Advocate must apply the protocol.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPF Employment Advocate must issue approval, refusal or referral notice

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If the Employment Advocate approves an AWA or ancillary document, the Employment Advocate must issue an approval notice to the employer.
(2) If the Employment Advocate refuses to approve an AWA or ancillary document, the Employment Advocate must issue a refusal notice to the employer.
(3) If the Employment Advocate refers an AWA or variation agreement to the Commission, the Employment Advocate must issue a referral notice to the employer, advising of the referral.

(4) In each approval notice, refusal notice or referral notice issued under this section, the Employment Advocate must identify the relevant or designated award that applies to the AWA to which the notice relates.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPFA Withdrawal of AWA or variation agreement

SPEECH.PARA: Either party to an AWA (other than an AWA for a new employee) or variation agreement that has been referred to the Commission by the Employment Advocate may withdraw the AWA or variation agreement by notice in writing lodged with the Commission.
(1) This section applies to an AWA that is referred to the Commission by the Employment Advocate.
(2) The Commission must approve the AWA if the Commission is satisfied that the AWA passes the no-disadvantage test.
(3) If the Commission has concerns about whether the AWA passes the no-disadvantage test, but those concerns are resolved by:

PARA.TAB: (a) a written undertaking given by the employer and accepted by the Commission; or
(b) other action by the parties;
the Commission must approve the AWA.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) If the Commission considers that it is not contrary to the public interest to approve the AWA, it must approve the AWA (whether or not subsection (2) or (3) requires the Commission to approve the AWA).

Note: An example of a case where the Commission may be satisfied that approving the AWA is not contrary to the public interest is where making the AWA is part of a reasonable strategy to deal with a short-term crisis in, and to assist in the revival of, a business or part of a business.
(5) In any case where the Commission is not required to approve the AWA, the Commission must refuse to approve the AWA.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPH Approval of variation agreement by Commission

SPEECH.PARA: (1) This section applies to a variation agreement that is referred to the Commission by the Employment Advocate.
(2) The Commission must approve the variation agreement if the Commission is satisfied that the AWA, as varied, passes the no-disadvantage test.
(3) If the Commission has concerns about whether the AWA, as varied, passes the no-disadvantage test, but those concerns are resolved by:

PARA.TAB: (a) a written undertaking given by the employer and accepted by the Commission; or
(b) other action by the parties;
the Commission must approve the variation agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) If the Commission considers that it is not contrary to the public interest to approve the variation agreement, it must approve the variation agreement (whether or not subsection (2) or (3) requires the Commission to approve the variation agreement).

Note: An example of a case where the Commission may be satisfied that approving the variation agreement is not contrary to the public interest is where making the variation agreement is part of a reasonable strategy to deal with a short-term crisis in, and to assist in the revival of, a business or part of a business.
(5) In any case where the Commission is not required to approve the variation agreement, the Commission must refuse to approve the variation agreement.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPI Commission must issue approval or refusal notice etc.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If the Commission approves an AWA or a variation agreement, the Commission must:

PARA.TAB: (a) issue an approval notice to the employer; and
(b) send a copy of the approval notice to the Employment Advocate; and
(c) send the Employment Advocate a copy of the AWA or variation agreement that was approved.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: An undertaking accepted in connection with an AWA is deemed to form part of the AWA. Therefore a copy of the undertaking will be sent to the Employment Advocate under this section.
(2) If the Commission refuses to approve an AWA or a variation agreement, the Commission must:

PARA.TAB: (a) issue an refusal notice to the employer; and
(b) send a copy of the refusal notice to the Employment Advocate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPJ Undertakings deemed to be included in AWA

SPEECH.PARA: An undertaking accepted by the Employment Advocate or Commission under this Division is taken to be included in the AWA.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VPK Employment Advocate to issue copies of approved AWAs and ancillary documents

SPEECH.PARA: (1) After an AWA or ancillary document is approved by the Employment Advocate, the Employment Advocate must issue to the employer a copy of the AWA or ancillary document, as approved.
(2) After an AWA or variation agreement is approved by the Commission, the Employment Advocate must issue to the employer a copy of the AWA or variation agreement, as approved.
Note: An undertaking accepted in connection with an AWA is deemed to form part of the AWA. Therefore a copy of the undertaking will be issued to the employer under this section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure why the running sheet says that 16 to 28 will be moved together. Given that I am not sure why the running sheet says 16 to 28 are to be moved together, I will be moving them separately. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Omit section 170VG, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170VG Matters to be included in AWA

PARA.TAB: (1) Subject to subsection (2), the AWA, in combination with one or more awards (if any) that are applicable, must not provide for terms and conditions of employment for employees whose employment will at any time be subject to the AWA, that are less favourable than each equivalent condition in the applicable award, including, if applicable, conditions relating to minimum and regular working hours, pro rata entitlements and non‐discrimination in entitlements for part‐time workers, or, if no award is applicable, the award determined by the Commission under section 170AD.

TAB.TAB: (a) the only reason why the Commission must not approve an AWA is that the requirements of subsection (1) are not met; and
(b) the Commission is satisfied that in the context of their terms and conditions of employment considered as a whole, the reduction in entitlement is not contrary to the public interest;
the Commission must approve the AWA.

PARA.TAB: (3) The employer must ensure that the AWA includes a dispute resolution procedure which stipulates as the final stage the decision of the Commission. If the AWA does not include such a procedure the AWA is taken to include the model procedure prescribed by the Commission for the purposes of this subsection.

(4) An AWA must not discriminate against an employee, whose employment will be subject to the agreement, because of, or for reasons including, race, colour, sex, sexual preference, transgender identity, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin.
(5) An AWA must include provisions that facilitate the prevention and elimination of workplace harassment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 16 on revised sheet 217 replaces amendment 49 on sheet 183. This amendment incorporates some of the issues that we raised earlier in relation to the incorporation of transgender identity into the anti-discrimination provisions and their extension to include workplace harassment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 17 on revised sheet 217 is a repeat of Greens' amendment 13 on sheet 217 in relation to non-discrimination against gays, lesbians and transgender people with respect to parental leave and carers leave. Amendment 13 attempted to incorporate a requirement that certified agreements not be accepted if they discriminate in this manner. This amendment attempts to do the same thing with respect to Australian workplace agreements.

It is interesting to note in this regard that only last Friday the New South Wales Supreme Court upheld the decision by the New South Wales equal opportunity commission that NIB Health Funds Ltd had discriminated against two gay men who had applied for family membership for themselves and for the child of one of the men. This is an important decision and comes at a critical time for law reform in relation to gay and lesbian issues. I trust that senators will acknowledge this further confirmation of common law rights in this area and support a very reasonable amendment to avoid discrimination against gays, lesbians and transgenders in relation to parental and carers leave.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 18 on revised sheet 217 replaces amendment 50 on sheet 183, and amendment 19 on revised sheet 217 replaces amendment 51. These amend clause 170VJ, the period of operation of Australian workplace agreements, to incorporate a cooling off period of 14 days at the commencement of a contract. It should be acknowledged that the signing of these contracts is one of the most important transactions that can be undertaken in a person's life. There should be the opportunity for some form of cooling off period before this contract, the AWA, takes effect. It does not mean that people cannot start work, but it is before the contract takes effect. I think for less important things, for small commercial transactions, there are cooling off periods. For more important transactions like working agreements I do not see why this should not be the case as well.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20) At the end of subsection 170VK(1), add "and any costs to employees associated with the bargaining process must be specified at the time the appointment is made.".

This amendment adds a proviso to the clause dealing with bargaining agents to say that `any cost to the employees associated with the bargaining process must be specified at the time the appointment was made'. Whilst subclause (4) of this section covers the issue of coercion, the reality is that, in the context of a contract negotiation, an employee may be encouraged to use a particular bargaining agent and that may incur costs for the employee. If that is the case, the Greens feel it is appropriate that those costs be specified at the time the appointment is made.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) After subsection 170VK(1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) For the purposes of this section, an organisation of employees registered under this Act is deemed to be a bargaining agent, unless the contrary intention appears.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment follows from our amendments in relation to collective bargaining. This amendment states clearly that `an organisation of employees registered under this act'—in most cases a union—`is deemed to be a bargaining agent, unless the contrary intention appears'.

This is an important amendment as it effectively creates a right for employees to be represented by a union unless the employer and employee agree to the contrary. Many workers may not be aware that they have the right to be represented by a union in negotiations for Australian workplace agreements. This amendment changes the onus to the employer to argue that a union is not the most appropriate body to represent the employee's interests. For many of the categories of workers who lack proper bargaining power in the workplace, this amendment may provide a protection against exploitation.

The Greens strongly believe that unions are the most appropriate body to represent the interests of employees in the workplace and that collective bargaining is the most appropriate way to partially counter the enormous power differential in the bargaining process between the employer and the employee.
This is a default provision. We believe it is sensible. This amendment reflects the belief that there is that gap and is one way of helping to address it.

TAB.TAB: (a) women;

(c) young persons;
(d) part‐time or casual employees;
(e) persons with disabilities.

PARA.TAB: (3) If under this section, the Commission forms the view that the effect of an agreement made under this Act is to disadvantage employees, the Commission may accept an undertaking from one or more persons who made the agreement in relation to the operation of the agreement and, if satisfied that the undertaking has the effect of removing the disadvantage identified by the Commission, may refuse to make an order under subsection (1).
(4) The Commission's powers and jurisdiction are unrestrained by any other provision of this Act when acting pursuant to this section.

SPEECH.PARA: The inclusion of the clause 170VMA empowers the commission to make an award to rectify any disadvantage it considers may be occasioned to employees as a consequence of making an agreement. Subclause (2) identifies by way of example those employees who have proven to have their interests insufficiently taken account of in bargaining.

Subclause (3) enables the commission to accept an undertaking to rectify the identified disadvantage rather than require it to make an award or order. Subclause (4) makes it clear that the commission's power to rectify the disadvantage is not limited by prohibitions on the commission's powers elsewhere in the act, most notably but not exclusively at section 89A.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment strengthens the role of the Employment Advocate with respect to the filing of Australian workplace agreements. The current provisions have two shortcomings. Firstly, the filing of Australian workplace agreements with the Employment Advocate is apparently not a compulsory requirement as clause 170VN merely states that `an AWA or ancillary document may be filed with the Employment Advocate'.

Secondly, the filing requirements that must be met before the Employment Advocate issues a receipt are largely reliant on an employer's statement that certain conditions have been met. There appears to be no requirement for the Employment Advocate to actually scrutinise Australian workplace agreements.

Our amendment incorporates a requirement that the Employment Advocate must not issue a filing receipt unless the Employment Advocate has checked whether the Australian workplace agreement complies with the minimum conditions set out in this act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —It is curious that there is agreement in the original bill and the government‐Democrat amendment in regard to section 170VF to categorise a non‐employee as an employee for the purpose of making an agreement about employment. Essentially, that is the position that is being put. There is no way that that position could be justified under what is generally termed the industrial relations power of the constitution, because there is no way that, prior to actual engagement, there is an employee‐employer relationship. Therefore, there is no way that the High Court would have allowed an agreement made under the constitutional power—which I will term industrial relations—for that to succeed. Obviously, the qualification of the provision for the making of AWAs in section 170VC is designed to get at this contrived arrangement through every other constitutional means possible than the industrial relations power. I suppose that subject to, at some stage, some legislation being passed in the Victorian parliament, there will be an amendment to section 170VC or some other legislation to permit the general application of this provision to employees in Victoria, given the statement by the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett, with regard to handing over that state's industrial relations power to the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: It is extremely interesting that this arrangement is being arrived at by constitutional means that are not the traditional constitutional basis of the industrial relations legislation of the Commonwealth. I would have to concede that it is not the first time that that has occurred. But in this case I think the only way it is possible for this to be a legitimate prescription is by means of other constitutional provisions than what I will term the industrial relations provision—the power of the Commonwealth in relation to conciliation and arbitration to prevent and settle industrial disputes. Of course, on many occasions the High Court has held that you cannot have an industrial dispute unless there is an employer‐employee relationship. It is just impossible to imagine the circumstances in which the High Court would find that prior to actual engagement such circumstances existed.

We are trying to get through this bill rather expeditiously in the committee stage at the moment, so there is not much point in my going to the particular High Court tests which I think would justify the statement that I have made. What we have is a provision which I would suggest is contrived to justify what we would say is not justifiable: that is, to say that prior to an employee being in any bargaining position at all, the employee can enter into an agreement—no doubt proffered by the employer.

The employee has no bargaining power if they want the job, unless they are in a very special skills situation, so we are talking about the majority of employees in this country. Young people and casuals are all being placed in the situation of having no bargaining power at all when they change jobs. I believe that this particular provision in the legislation is a particularly unfortunate and even immoral provision in relation to the so‐called questions of choice that this government is pursuing with this legislation. Choice in this case will be the choice of the employer only.

The Democrats' position is that such agreements can be made prior to entering into the employment relationship, provided the matter is dealt with by the industrial commission rather than just by the Employment Advocate. I suppose there is a rationale which suggests that at least there is a further testing of the arrangement to ensure that what arises out of the agreement is something which satisfies the minimum conditions test. What that does not satisfy is the question of a freely reached agreement—a genuine agreement. A genuine agreement is reached between bargaining equals.

This legislation now establishes provisions for an agreement to be made between unequal parties in unfair circumstances and circumstances which will be prejudicial to many employees, young and old, whose particular skills do not give them enhanced bargaining power. The opposition amendments would delete that peculiar provision which, although it has been changed by the government‐Democrat amendment 134, retains the position of pre-employment agreement by employees. The Labor Party amendment removes this but requires that the AWA be filed with the commission.

In terms of the way that agreements are dealt with, I indicated in the second reading stage the difficulty with allowing a test of agreements simply by a member of the Public Service employed under the Public Service Act 1922. There is the question of training, the level at which the employee is engaged within service and, therefore, their level of skill and responsibility. We are looking at a fairly significant test, a test that relates to one of the most fundamental contracts which any person makes and which almost every person in this country, if they make no other agreement, makes to enter into an employment relationship.

That is why I think this is fundamentally flawed legislation. The amendment now before the committee ought to have the support of thinking members of this chamber. Although I do not expect that the Democrats will waver from the agreement, I think they will regret the fact that they have entered into an agreement which establishes such prejudicial conditions for employees, for potential employees, for the disadvantaged and for the powerless within the working community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the contribution of Senator O'Brien, I would like to ask the minister a question. I believe that the AWAs will introduce a massive shift of industrial matters from the federal tribunals to the state ones and, in particular, I would have thought, to the magistrates court. Is that intended by the government and the Democrats? If it is, has any communication been made with the states to make available their courts with this increased work? TALK.START.PARA: —This is the schedule dealing with consequential amendments, so I will not take a great deal of time. We have already canvassed the issues with respect to the matters covered in this schedule. The only matter I wish to refer to in relation to this schedule is the requirement for reports about developments in making agreements.

BREAK.PARA: The original proposal in the bill was that the report should be prepared every three years. We can only assume from this ridiculously long reporting period that the government is worried that the reports will be an embarrassment to it. This is proof that it has good reason to be worried.

More fundamentally, this proposal makes a mockery of the government's much vaunted claim that the parliament would regain its sovereignty over the executive—the government would have to answer to the parliament and would be more open to it. That has gone the way of the ministerial guidelines of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). They are not worth the paper they are printed on.

This cynicism by the government does not come as a surprise, but support of it by the Australian Democrats did. What has been achieved as a result of this deal is that, instead of a three‐year reporting period, we will have a two‐year reporting period. More importantly, this will mean that there will be only one report before the next election.

Given the Democrats' justified concern about government accountability to the parliament, I can only assume that they are worried that a second report before they have to face the people at the next election would reveal the inadequacies in the system that the Democrats have helped to create. I have some further comments on this schedule that I seek leave to incorporate.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 12—Consequential amendments relating to certified agreements, AWAs and enterprise flexibility agreements.

BREAK.PARA: The Bill repeals the existing definition of "award" (which included an award, certified agreement or enterprise flexibility agreement) and inserts a new definition which is confined to just awards. These amendments (particularly Opp (243)), amend the definition so that it again includes a certified agreement (but not an enterprise flexibility agree ment or AWA). This amendment by the Bill, and our subsequent amendment, has 2 consequences:

1. If the Bill seeks to make a particular provision applicable to a certified agreement (which we accept) the Bill must, and does, amend any reference to "award" by adding a reference to "certified agreement". Because we include certified agreements in the definition of awards—see Opp (243)—the additional reference to certified agreements is unnecessary and we delete it. (This is the effect of Opp (244)—(253), (255) and (256), (260)—(262), (264)—(273) and (276)).

2. If we seek to make a particular provision applicable to an AWA we must, and do, amend any reference to "award" by adding a reference to "AWAs". (This is the effect of Opp (246)—(250), (252)—(264), (267), (270) and (271), (274)—(277)).
The Opposition supports these amendments because they are an improvement on the original Bill.
The Opposition does not support this amendment for the reasons which I have already stated. The Opposition's preferred position is given effect by Opp (279)—(283)

The amendment was consequential on our opposition to the original provisions in the Bill concerning non‐union certified agreements and concerning right of entry. Because the latter will be deleted by Government/Democrat amendments, and because (we assume) our opposition to the former has not been successful, this amendment is no longer relevant and the Opposition does not press it.

The Bill requires a report about developments in certified agreements and AWAs every 3 years. This amendment requires such a report every year. Presently the requirement is every year. Three years is simply too long a reporting period for the report to be any use. The existing annual reports are widely referred to and utilised, and are an invaluable source of information about the effects of bargaining.
This amendment is to the same effect as Opp (279) and the Opposition supports it on that basis.

The Bill makes provision for the report to be given by its maker to the Minister, and for the Minister to table it. These amendments require the report and a document containing prescribed statistical details of certified agreements and AWAs to be so given and tabled. It is important that the statistical information behind the report be tabled so that the conclusions in the report can be checked for their objectivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to amendments 139 to 141 now, if I may, in view of Senator Sherry's remarks. The Australian Democrats do endorse the government‐Democrat amendments. I particularly want to speak to amendment 141 at this time and it is apposite to the remarks that Senator Sherry has made.

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 358A, as amended, the department will be required to report biennially on developments in relation to enterprise bargaining and the making of certified agreements and AWAs. The reports must particularly look at the effect of bargaining on women, part-time employees, persons from a non-English speaking background and young people. This section continues the reporting which the Democrats insisted be included in the Labor act in 1993, which they resisted, but on a biennial rather than annual basis.

Two reports have already been issued in respect of 1994 and 1995, and the next, Senator Sherry, will be due in respect of 1996 and 1997—in other words, two reports before the next election—building on the base provided by the two current reports. We believe that the reporting process ensures that a close eye is kept on the industrial reform process and its effect on disadvantaged workers. With the basic data now established and given the cost of creating these reports, we have been persuaded that it is appropriate to now move to biennial reporting. However, we did reject the government's original proposal of triennial reporting as simply involving too long a period between reports.
