PARA.EMPHASIS: 170XA When does an agreement pass the no-disadvantage test?

SPEECH.PARA: (1) An agreement passes the no-disadvantage test if it does not disadvantage employees in relation to their terms and conditions of employment.

(2) Subject to sections 170XB, 170XC and 170XD, an agreement disadvantages employees in relation to their terms and conditions of employment only if its approval or certification would result, on balance, in a reduction in the overall terms and conditions of employment of those employees under:

PARA.TAB: (a) relevant awards or designated awards; and
(b) any other law of the Commonwealth, or of a State or Territory, that the Employment Advocate or the Commission (as the case may be) considers relevant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 170XB Special case—employee eligible for the Supported Wage System

SPEECH.PARA: If an agreement provides for the payment of wages to an employee who is eligible for the Supported Wage System at a rate that is not less than the rate set in accordance with that System for the employee, the approval or certification of the agreement is not to be taken to result in a reduction of the employee's wages.
Note: The Supported Wage System was endorsed by the Commission in the Full Bench decision dated 10 October 1994 (print L5723).

(1) If an agreement provides for the payment of wages to an employee undertaking an approved traineeship at a rate that is not less than the appropriate percentage of the rate ( benchmark rate ) that would be applicable to the employee under the relevant award or designated award (as the case may be) if:

PARA.TAB: (a) that award applied to him or her; and
(b) he or she were not undertaking the traineeship;
the approval or certification of the agreement is not to be taken to result in a reduction of the employee's wages.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) For the purposes of subsection (1), the appropriate percentage of the benchmark rate is such percentage of that rate as is determined in writing by the approving authority having regard to the reduction in the productive time of an employee undertaking the approved traineeship due to time spent in training.

(3) If the agreement adopts, as the qualification for a wage level, a criterion determined by the approving authority instead of the criterion applying under the relevant award or designated award (as the case may be), that award is taken, for the purposes of this section, to have effect as if the criterion determined by the approving authority were substituted for the last-mentioned criterion.
(1) This section applies if:

PARA.TAB: (a) an agreement provides for the payment of wages to an employee undertaking an approved apprenticeship in a particular trade, occupation or kind of work; and

(b) there is a relevant award or designated award regulating the payment of wages to employees undertaking an apprenticeship ( benchmark apprenticeship ) in the same trade, occupation or kind of work.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The approval or certification of the agreement is to be taken to result in a reduction of the employee's wages only if the agreement provides for the payment of wages to employees undertaking the approved apprenticeship at a rate that is less than the rate applicable under the relevant award or designated award (as the case may be) to employees undertaking the benchmark apprenticeship adjusted (if necessary) as provided in subsection (3).

(3) For the purposes of subsection (2), the rate that is applicable to an employee undertaking the benchmark apprenticeship is to be adjusted to take into account the proportionate difference, as determined by the approving authority, between the productive time of an employee under the approved apprenticeship and the productive time of an employee under the benchmark apprenticeship.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

I would like to make a few remarks on this schedule. There is only one principal issue I wish to address. I and my colleagues have previously addressed the rest or it will be covered in the document I will incorporate. The issue I want to address is one that is vitally important for the future of the country—arrangements for trainees and apprentices. Everyone should understand that, regrettably, trainees and apprentices have been sold out by these provisions. This is confirmed by the amendments which the Democrats have agreed to.

It is interesting to see that the government and Democrats amendments have made special provision for trainees and apprentices. Trainees and apprentices will be delighted to know that they are to be treated differently; they will not be so delighted when they learn that they are being treated worse. For everyone else, the new no disadvantage test will effectively ensure their take-home pay cannot be reduced under a workplace agreement. Not so for trainees and apprentices. Their guarantee is that their award wage rate cannot be reduced under a workplace agreement.

What does this mean in practical terms? Trainees and apprentices in the future may, under a workplace agreement, be paid only for the hours spent in productive employment. Any time spent in training, whether on the job or not, can be regarded as unproductive. Trainees and apprentices will not be paid for this time. In other words, trainees and apprentices can have their take‐home pay cut under these provisions.

This is a clear and unambiguous breach by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of the rock solid guarantee that no worker would be worse off under this industrial relations policy. If you are a trainee or an apprentice, there is no doubt that you can be worse off. This regrettably does not surprise me, given that the government has been in the business of redefining its election promises as core and non-core commitments. I can only assume that the government's election commitment that the take‐home pay of trainees and apprentices would not be cut is now regarded as a non-core promise. It is regrettable and a great pity that Mr Howard did not tell this to kids on traineeships and apprenticeships before the election.

What staggers me is the Democrats say they will support this breach of promise. I am reminded—I do not like to be—of Senator Stott Despoja's plaintive speech in the second reading debate on the subject. She said:
Only paying young people for the time they spend in productive work as opposed to training means that in many cases wages under MAATS will be lower than they are currently.
She certainly got that part right. She went on to say:

The government has promised that it will pay a top‐up . . . to young people who undertake the MAATS apprenticeships and traineeships, but I am yet to be convinced that this payment will go anywhere near towards providing young people with the means to sustain a reasonable living standard.
I can only assume that the Senate has now been convinced because, if one thing is for certain, the Democrats have agreed to a provision that will cut wages for trainees and apprentices.

Senator Stott Despoja showed in her speech in the second reading debate that a metal trades apprentice with one year's training could lose $34 per week in take‐home pay under these proposals. The opposition has demonstrated that a second year, 17‐year‐old metal trades apprentice could lose as much as $70 per week in take‐home pay under these proposals. Senator Stott Despoja cannot have it both ways. She cannot come into the chamber criticising the inadequacies of government proposals only to vote for them. She certainly cannot wander around the country claiming she represents the interests of young people only to come into this chamber and vote against those interests.

We are moving amendments that repeal the provisions which allow trainee and apprenticeship wages to be cut. We want the same no disadvantage test to apply to them as applies to everyone else. I firmly believe that, if the Democrats can only vote with us on one amendment, this is it. Trainees and apprentices are too important to be sacrificed in the interests of this deal. I seek leave to incorporate some further comments in regard to this.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought there might have been a response to Senator Sherry's comments because this is a very important matter. These issues were fought for in the late 1950s and early 1960s, that is to say that training for apprentices, particularly by 1967 in any event, was recognised and paid for. A considerable amount of work was done at that stage. I can only speak from personal experience from 1959 onwards. I can certainly recall the discussions that took place over payment of apprentices for their time off either during the week or their block time off for training at tech schools. All of this was worked for and it was difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation was that, obviously, trainees were gainfully employed or engaged in productive employment prior to then because they were training on the job, but new training techniques developed. As those new training techniques developed, employers required that training be absorbed by the apprentices by dint of time off for training. I do not think the block training system came in at that particular stage but it certainly came in not long after—I wish my memory was a bit clearer than it is tonight. At that particular stage, the apprentices were not about to lose pay as the trade union movement did not think they ought to be losing pay by reason of a demand by employers that they should be receiving training, and much of it block training.

So now we have a situation whereby new skills and new ways of dealing with the training of apprentices will be required and it seems odd that, in such a situation where there will be further demand for apprentices, young apprentice technicians will be required to absorb more and more skills. They will be required to undertake education at times when they are not working on the job. It is very significant, I think, and regrettable that at this time we have what Senator Sherry has described, that is, a situation whereby we are being asked to treat those people differently. In other words, we are being asked to vote for a provision which will not give the apprentices and technical trainees that rock solid guarantee that their pay will not be cut.

As Senator Sherry said, it will be cut if the decision is made that they will only be paid for time spent in productive employment. I agree with what Senator Sherry said. This is a very crucial issue in this piece of legislation and I appeal to the committee to oppose the provision that the government and the Democrats are putting forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak about amendment 142 to schedule 13 of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. This amendment does two things: first, it establishes the no disadvantage test for certified agreements and AWAs in preference to the government's originally proposed seven minimum conditions; and, second, it outlines special case conditions for persons engaged in apprenticeships and traineeships.

SPEECH.PARA: The no disadvantage test will seek to determine where the terms and conditions of employment of an agreement would result on balance in a reduction of the overall terms and conditions of employment of employees under the relevant awards and any other Commonwealth or state law. The establishment of the no disadvantage test is, in our view, a major advance on the original seven minimum conditions proposed by the government. The test does not just provide a broad protection in comparison to the entire award for unions and employees but also provides a higher level of flexibility for employers in packaging the overall mix of employment conditions.

I want to speak briefly on sections 170XC and 170XD—the special cases in relation to employees undertaking traineeships and apprenticeships. It is a hard choice at times to identify which provisions of this bill have been most misrepresented by the ALP, but I think these sections would be a close favourite. Let us start with the argument that this will lead to a 20 per cent reduction in apprentices' wages because current award rates will be discounted for non-productive time. This is clearly not the case.

PARA.BREAK: Sections 170XC(1) and 170XD(3) make it quite clear that the special case exercise involves the approved training authority determining the amount of training time in the current apprenticeships or traineeships and setting this as the benchmark. The approved training authority is then required to determine what the proportion is in the new training arrangements and to establish a percent age between the two which then forms the discount for the wages.

SPEECH.PARA: Thus, for example, if the award provides for a second-year apprenticeship of $300 a week—and to get that you have to spend a day a week in training—the non-productive percentage is 20 per cent. If the apprentice then agrees to an AWA—and he has to agree—including an approved accelerated training regime of two days a week, the percentage becomes 40 per cent. That would mean that the apprentice's salary, instead of being $300 for four days work would be $225 for three days work. But he has to agree.

The Australian Democrats have insisted on a number of additional protections for apprentices and trainees. In particular, we have included a new definition of an approved training authority in section 170X, which covers state training authorities that exercise approval powers in relation to traineeships or apprenticeships, industry training bodies or bodies which meet the criteria on disallowable regulations. This precludes the approval function being given to local chambers of commerce or employer groups as some have suggested.

The exchange of letters between the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, and Senator Kernot, which have been read into the transcript, make it clear that apprenticeships and traineeships will be approved only if they comply with the national training framework and lead to a nationally recognised accreditation. The letter also restates the government's commitment to move towards a competency based—not an aged based—wage system for trainees and apprentices and, consistent with this, to offer a fourth $220 a week income support pay point, which the Democrats achieved in addition, for employees who have already completed the equivalent of AQF2‐level training.

The no disadvantage test provides further protection for these workers in that an AWA or CA can only be approved if on balance it provides no reduction in award conditions. Section 83BB(2) will require the Employment Advocate to pay particular regard to the needs of trainees and apprentices in exercising their powers, including their powers of vetting and approval of AWAs. Combined, this is a tight package of protections which allows the flexibility of the government's MAATS apprenticeship system to get off the ground while ensuring that the system operates with the interests of trainees and apprentices at the forefront and adequately protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to schedule 14, which deals with the definition of industrial action, I will be making some detailed comments and will incorporate some further comments.

SPEECH.PARA: The one issue that I want to address is the use of injunctions in industrial relations. One of the features of this bill is the increased use of injunctions in dealing with industrial disputes. We see it here in this schedule: injunctions to enforce commission orders; injunctions against people paying strike pay; and, later, when we deal with secondary boycotts, we will find injunctions being introduced to enforce the most draconian provisions in this bill.

The problem is that injunctions in the industrial relations context are a very blunt instrument. They can be awarded without the court giving any consideration to the merits of the dispute. They do not act to resolve the dispute but merely to stamp out its manifestations. Injunctions also expose unions and unionists to great jeopardy. Breach of an injunction is a serious matter and can expose the union or unionist to unlimited financial penalties for contempt of court.

BREAK.PARA: The government knows all this. That is why they are making injunctions available, and in far wider circumstances. What is extraordinary is that the Democrats also understand this. Senator Murray in his report said at page 360:
The use of injunctions against workers and unions is a very blunt and effective `weapon' in the armoury of employers.

Why then, Senator Murray, do you facilitate them? Why be a party to increasing their use in industrial relations? I can remember Senator Murray in Melbourne during the Senate committee hearings telling the members of the International Centre for Trade Union Rights that he understood the inherent problems in ex parte injunctions—he did not even need their advice at that stage. Now he is going to vote in favour of them.

We want to do something about injunctions in this schedule. If we cannot delete the injunction power, we at least want to modify it to considerably reduce its destructive potential against unions and their members. Our amendments propose two things. Firstly, we propose that an injunction, whether interim or final, cannot be granted in the absence of the other party unless the court is satisfied that the applicant has been given notice of the application to the other person. This ensures that an employer cannot rush off to the court behind the union's back to get an interim injunction.

Secondly, we propose that an interim injunction cannot be granted unless the court is satisfied that, first, the applicant is likely to succeed at the trial of the action and that, second, not granting the injunction will inevitably expose the applicant to loss or harm for which an award of damages is a wholly inadequate remedy. These strict requirements before an interim injunction will be ordered will at least ensure that the merits of the dispute will be heard by the court before an injunction will be ordered.

The Democrats know and understand that these amendments are modest, but will remove the worst excesses on injunctions in industrial relations. They should act on the basis of their knowledge and vote in support of these amendments. I move:

The Bill defines "industrial action" to not include action by an employee based on a reasonable concern about an imminent risk to health or safety provided the employee did not unreasonably fail to comply with a direction to work elsewhere. This amendment removes the necessity for the risk to be imminent. It also deletes the proviso. The Opposition moves this amendment because the requirement that the risk be imminent is onerous and unnecessary, especially in such an important area as health and safety. The requirement concerning directions will simply create uncertainty and confusion. The judgement about what is "reasonable" will differ from person to person and circumstance to circumstance.

This amendment amends the section providing for stand‐down applications so that it provides that an application to the Commission to stand down an employee can be made in respect of an AWA (as well as an award and certified agreement). This is consequential on Opp (236) and (237) (which require a stand down order by the Commission before an employee on an AWA can be stood down for taking industrial action).
The Opposition is completely opposed to the proposed s127 (see Opp (287)), and this amendment does nothing to improve it. The Opposition will therefore vote against this amendment.

The Bill provides that the Commission can order industrial action to stop or not occur. Such an order is enforceable by an injunction, including an interim injunction. This amendment deletes this provision. The Opposition believes the Commission presently has sufficient capacity to stop industrial action by use of bans clauses in awards. There is no need for additional power in the Commission to make orders stopping industrial action. Enforcement by injunctions is also a problem as injunctions, in an industrial relations context, will be a very blunt instrument. Breach of an injunction is also very serious, exposing unions to unlimited financial penalties for contempt of court.

If Opp (287) is not agreed to, this amendment amends proposed s127 by removing the injunctions provisions (and by deleting a reference to non‐union certified agreements). If s127 is not deleted the "next best" fallback is to retain the Commission's new power to make orders stopping industrial action, but to remove their enforceability by injunctions.

i. an injunction (whether interim or final) cannot be granted in the absence of the other party unless the Court is satisfied that the applicant has given notice of the application to the other person;

(a) the applicant is likely to succeed at the trial of the action; and

PARA.TAB: (b) not granting the injunction will inevitably expose the applicant to loss or harm for which an award of damages is a wholly inadequate remedy.

BREAK.PARA: If there is to be an injunction power the "next best thing" is to modify the injunction power so as to considerably reduce its destructive potential against unions. This can be done in two ways—ensuring that an employer cannot "rush off to court behind the union's back" to get an interim injunction; providing very strict requirements before an interim injunction will ordered. This ensures at least that the merits of the dispute will be heard by the Court before an injunction will be ordered.

The Opposition welcomes this amendment, in particular, the retention of section 166A. This was one of the effects of Opp (292) which the Opposition was committed to in the House of Representatives. The Opposition will vote in support of the amendment on that basis. We note however that the amendment does not go far enough, and our concerns are addressed at Opp (292).

The amended Bill repeals the provisions which prohibit actions under State or Territory law in relation to industrial action involving public sector employment and in relation to breaches of bans clause. This amendment accepts the repeal concerning bans clauses (because we accept the deletion of the bans clause provisions—the Bill repeals s125 and we accept that). The amendment deletes the repeal concerning public sector employment

The Opposition supports this amendment because it is an improvement on the existing Bill.

The Bill provides a maximum penalty of $10,000 for payment or acceptance of strike pay. This amendment reduces this maximum to $1,000. The Opposition again believes that the large amount of this penalty provision shows the Bill is "all about punishments and penalties".

The Bill provides for the payment of compensation and for injunctions relating to payment or acceptance of strike pay. These amendments delete these provisions. In relation to the injunction provision the Opposition is concerned that injunctions, in an industrial relations context, will be a very blunt instrument. Breach of an injunction is also very serious, exposing unions to unlimited financial penalties for contempt of court. In relation to the compensation provision the Opposition is concerned that these could lead to unlimited compensation awards. Such compensation awards have the potential to prevent an organisation from properly representing the interests of its members because of fear of being "sued out of existence".

If Opp (295) is not agreed to, these amendments qualify the remedies that can be obtained against unions (and officers, members and employees of unions) relating to payment or acceptance of strike pay. Firstly, we qualify the compensation remedy by capping the damages which can be awarded as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1. for a union with less than 5,000 members—$20,000;
2. for a union with 5,000 or more members but less than 25,000—$100,000;
3. for a union with 25,000 or more members but less than 100,000—$250,000;
4. for a union with 100,000 or more members—$500,000.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, these amendments qualify the injunction remedy by providing that:

i. an injunction (whether interim or final) cannot be granted in the absence of the other party unless the Court is satisfied that the applicant has given notice of the application to the other person;
ii. an interim injunction cannot be granted unless the Court is satisfied that:
(a) the applicant is likely to succeed at the trial of the action; and

PARA.TAB: (b) not granting the injunction will inevitably expose the applicant to loss or harm for which an award of damages is a wholly inadequate remedy.

BREAK.PARA: The Opposition moves these amendments because the "next best thing" is to removing the injunction power is to considerably reduce its destructive potential against unions. Similarly, the "next best thing" to removing the unlimited compensation provisions is to place a cap on damages to considerably reduce the destructive potential of unlimited damages. Indeed, when Margaret Thatcher reintroduced common law actions against trade unions she also introduced a cap on the damages that could be recovered. The cap we recommend reflects the amounts introduced by Thatcher.

The Bill provides that an organisation can be deregistered if it or its members fail to comply with an injunction restraining industrial action or the payment or acceptance of strike pay. This amendment deletes this provision. The Opposition believes this provision is too drastic. There is no suggestion that companies should be deregistered if they fail to comply with these provisions.

SCHEDULE 14 (AMENDMENTS 143-145):
I seek leave to move these amendments together.

Amendment 143 is a small evidentiary change to section 127 to require the Commission to hear and determine applications for directions orders as quickly as possible. While it is expected that use of section 127 directions will be few and far between, and that the Commission has an absolute discretion not to grant such relief, the amendment recognises that where inappropriate industrial action is causing significant damage, then obviously there must be a duty clearly on the Commission to act quickly.

The Democrats will support the amended section 127 because we believe that it is incumbent on defenders of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to ensure that the Commission as the powers to enforce its orders. The current procedures of fines and bans clauses simply has not been effective and it is not unusual to find unions defying orders and recommendations of the Commission. As a result, the Commission has at times become almost reluctant to make an order or recommendation that it knows will be ignored. We believe that if the unions wish to have broader access to arbitration in the Commission, the quid pro quo must be that they respect the Commission and its decisions. And section 127, with directions orders, and with access to injunctions if those directions orders are defied, is, in our view an appropriate means of achieving that.

The provisions are very similar to the provision of the draft Industrial Relations Bill put up by Labor in 1987, in turn based on recommendation of the comprehensive Hancock Inquiry, but was subsequently withdrawn under represser from the union movement in 1988. I commend the provisions to the Senate.

Amendments 144 and 145 re-instate section 166A into the Industrial Relations Act. This section provides for a compulsory period of conciliation to a maximum of 72 days before an employer can commence common law action against a union or employee in relation to a dispute. The provision reflects the current act, but with a few technical changes to ensure that unions do not engage in stop-start action to legally avoid the provisions, and to make it clear that it also contains a provision making it clear that action in breach of a direction of a State industrial authority is not protected by the section.

Combined with the exclusion of primary boycotts from the Trade Practices Act, other than the narrow category of primary boycotts involving the movement of goods in and out of Australia, this provision will ensure that primary boycotts are dealt with in a very similar way to how they are now by the AIRC, with the added enforcement provisions by the directions orders process.

PARA.TAB: (d) the other conduct is taken to be part of the first-mentioned conduct; and
(e) the period of the first-mentioned conduct is taken to include the period of the other conduct.
Repeal the section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (77) Schedule 14, item 9, page 178 (after line 15), before section 187AA, insert:
In this part, industrial action means action of a kind referred to in paragraphs (d), (e), (f) and (g) of the definition of industrial action in subsection 4(1).
(78) Schedule 14, item 9, page 179 (lines 1 to 3), omit paragraph (e).

It is quite a difficult debate to be involved with sometimes tonight, because if people have incorporated comments about entire areas, including Greens (WA) amendments, there may well be comments that have been made about my amendments which I will not have had the opportunity to know about or respond to. That is something I would like put on the record tonight. It should be noted that, in the outcome, if there are comments about what we have done or said, it makes it extremely difficult and very unfair if those comments are incorporated without anybody having a chance to respond to the particular issues that we are putting up.

Having said that, amendments Nos 77 and 78 amend the clause on payments in relation to periods of industrial action to avoid a potentially outrageous implication. It is possible—I am sure this was purely unintentional—that, as the clause currently stands, an employer must not make a payment to a worker who is engaged in industrial action, such as a work to rules campaign or a ban on administering dole diaries, which is a contemporary example. It might also include employees engaged in a campaign of, as we mentioned before in relation to workers' health and safety, avoiding a dangerous situation or unsafe industrial equipment that their employer is failing to acknowledge. It could be a case of supporting another employee who is in that situation.

These two amendments seek to limit the definition of industrial action for the purposes of the new part VIIIA. If these changes are not made, employers would have the capacity, and probably the requirement, to avoid their obligations to pay employees for industrial action, such as work to rule arrangements, even though the employees were gainfully, productively and fully employed. The current definition of industrial action applies to a wide range of action. The idea that workers could be not just made but prohibited under the law from receiving payment in circumstances where their action falls short of the withdrawal of labour is fundamentally inequitable and unjust. The bill as currently structured actually prohibits an employer from paying an employee for any period of industrial action, regardless of its nature or effect.

These amendments would not be necessary if the new part VIIIA, which deals with payments in relation to periods of industrial action, was not inserted into the legislation. The government is using a pre‐existing broad definition of industrial action, which was inserted to increase the commission's powers to intervene in a wide range of disputes, to pervert the intention of that original use. The concept is perverted in this new part VIIIA by ensuring that workers must be docked pay even when the industrial action being undertaken not only is short of strike action but, in many cases, causes little or no damage to the employer.

I am sure that, now this unintended consequence has been drawn to their attention, the government and the Democrats will support this very sensible redraft of the clause. I looked for the definition, and it is under the existing definition of industrial relations. Before I sit down, I would like to clarify with the parliamentary secretary whether his interpretation of industrial action does include work to rules campaigns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it does.

—Therefore, industrial action involving dole diaries and situa tions where workers may be asked to do work that is patently impossible or for which they have not been trained, for which the technology is unsuitable or for which there is no getting through to the person who is giving those orders, will mean that employees will have to have their pay docked. This will occur even if what they are being asked to do is stupid and if there has been no other way of getting through to the employer that the employees have been asked to do a dumb thing.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many examples where work to rules campaigns or even some other minor industrial action has brought about beneficial changes in the workplace. Perhaps people think that, if they are going to be killed for a sheep, they might as well be killed for a lamb. That means that, instead of taking sensible, low key industrial action, they may well choose to take strike action. That is what it says. You get the same penalty for strike action; you get your pay docked as you would for limited industrial action. It says `must'. It does not say `may'. Perhaps the minister could clarify whether that is not the case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —While the minister is seeking clarification, I indicate that we will be supporting these two amendments moved by Senator Margetts. They are consistent with our overall concerns for the schedule. She has made a very good point in drawing it to the attention of the Senate. We could talk about some other examples, but she has illustrated the issue well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The position is as Senator Margetts has said it. The answer is yes to her question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the spokesperson for the Democrats might comment on the points that Senator Margetts has brought up. I will re-encapsulate it. People in the workplace who invoke a work to rules campaign because of a matter that is very serious to them may have their pay docked because of it. Senator Margetts points out that it is not a case of may; the employer must dock them pay for taking part in industrial action on those grounds. That is incredible and quite unbelievable.

SPEECH.PARA: I will talk a little longer to allow Senator Murray to consult with the government, as he is doing at the moment. It would be remarkable to hear, from what I know of the Democrats' excellent commitment to social justice, that the right of people in whatever circumstances to stand up for something that is going patently wrong in the community without being penalised for it is being eroded by a law that says they must be penalised. This proposed section says that if there is a work to rules campaign, the employees must be penalised by the employer. What a remarkable situation. The disputants would not go to court and have a hearing at which the matter would be adjudicated. The law says that employees who take part in such an action must be penalised.

I think Senator Margetts deserves to have a response. She has got none from the government, except to say, `Yes, that's the case.' Senator Margetts deserves to have a clearer response from the Democrats, who support this motion, as to how they could possibly be doing so; how they could possibly be supporting summary penalties for people in the workplace who take part in a work to rules campaign over a matter like the dole diary. I would presume that silence means there is no explanation—that the inexplicable is being supported by the Democrats on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (9.32 p.m.)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to two points. Firstly, Senator Brown, you said you have had no response. I was asked two quite specific and direct questions by Senator Margetts, which I answered absolutely directly. That, of course, provoked you to speak, because you disagree with the bill and with this amendment. You say you have had no response, but you actually had quite specific, direct and accurate responses.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, Senator Margetts made a point earlier in relation to the incorporation of speeches. In conversations I have had with Senator Sherry in recent days to enable the bill to come to a vote on the third reading as early as possible after close to 30 hours of committee stage debate, Senator Sherry indicated that he intended seeking leave to incorporate speeches. Senator Murray has done the same thing. He did not suggest he was going to do that. But it is open to any senator—not that I encourage it—who has fears about something in a document to refuse leave for it to be incorporated.

As a matter of course and through the courtesy shown to me, particularly by Senator Sherry, I have checked all the documents that he has sought leave to incorporate. That remains open to any senator. Certainly, if Senator Sherry had made any remarks in those incorporated documents that I wanted to respond to, I would have done so. That remains open to any senator to do. So I think it is not a fear that you need to have, because you can refuse leave or you can do what I am doing—that is, check any documents prior to that.

In relation to the substantive issues, the government opposes amendments 77 and 78 that apply to item 9. The amendments appear to be based on what we see as a misunderstanding of the relevant provisions of the bill. It is not clear what the amendments are intended to achieve. They apply to item 9 of the schedule, which seeks to insert new provisions prohibiting the payment or acceptance of strike pay, that is, payments for periods when the employees concerned were engaged in industrial action.

You have asked me on a couple of occasions what our definitions of industrial action are. On the face of it, your amendments would have the result that the prohibition would not apply to industrial action falling short of a complete stoppage of work but it would apply to action which is excluded from the statutory definition of industrial action. It would apply to action which was authorised or agreed to by the employer and to action which was based on a reasonable concern about an imminent risk to health and safety.

If the amendments are intended to ensure that the prohibition on strike pay does not apply to action which is excluded from the definition of industrial action, they are therefore unnecessary. That is already the effect of this bill. To the extent that the amendments seek to exclude from the prohibition on strike pay industrial action which falls short of a full stoppage of work, the government does not accept them. Bans and limitations on work leading right up to a definition of industrial action can be just as costly and disruptive.
To summarise the point that I have just read into Hansard, there are already exclusions in relation to those matters. If they are your concern, then you need have no concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point that the parliamentary secretary just made is fairly telling. He said `can be' just as disruptive and just as costly. This part of the bill leaves no discretion to the employer. The employer may actually think in hindsight that the action was quite reasonable. They might come to their senses if they were doing something that might actually cost them money in the long run. They might not be listening.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly this applies to a number of safety issues. I have mentioned before that under section 14(2) there are very great limitations in relation to industrial action over workers health and safety issues. We have had that debate already. It is very limiting to an individual who is feeling under imminent threat. Also, that person can be moved on to another job. Therefore, even that small area is not already covered in the bill. There are lots of other areas which are not covered under the scope of industrial action in the bill.

I do not think you have actually clearly said what the rationale is, except to say that industrial action and even work to rules can be just as costly. But you did not say it must be, and you still have not explained it. I will be very happy to hear you explain.

I will also be very happy to hear if the Democrats have had a chance to rethink their position. I have noticed that Senator Murray has been on the phone. I hope that what I have said has got through. I would like to know if there is any real explanation as to why there is no discretion left to the employer, who must not pay people—it is not just a penalty—during the course of industrial action. That means not pay them at all. You have not explained—except to say that it can be costly to employers—why there is no discretion there at all in relation to this provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Brown was speaking, I was reminded of the absurd consequences of the government-Democrat amendment 145 and the very adequate and proper remedy proposed by the Greens. For example, Senator Brown is not wearing his jacket. Is that industrial action? He is breaking the rules of the Senate. If we pass this bill, supposedly the government would have to stop paying him. That is a very extreme example, but that is the sort of behaviour that could occur in a workplace, as absurd as it sounds. The employer can turn around and say, `We must stop your pay.'

SPEECH.PARA: I can recall examples of industrial action by gaming employees at the casino to which I was a party. On one occasion they decided not to count chips. That sounds to most people as a fairly unusual form of industrial action. Presumably under this provision that the government and the Democrats are supporting, if they do not count the chips, they do not get paid. It sounds ridiculous. There is absolutely no discretion under these provisions. Employers must stop the pay, regardless of the circumstances or the particular type of industrial action. This provision that the government and the Democrats have agreed on is ridiculous and is quite rightly being picked up by the Greens in their amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to the analogy that Senator Sherry makes in relation to Senator Brown's attire, because it makes a point that I was going to make anyway. What this bill, as amended, with very constructive input from the Australian Democrats, seeks to achieve is a change in the culture of the workplace. The Australian Labor Party and their friends in the union movement have always sought to presume in industrial rela tions that it is us and them; that it is the bosses and the workers.
—It often is.
—It is in many cases, Senator Sherry. What we seek to achieve with this legislation is a change in the culture of the Australian workplace.
—You know that is never going to happen.
—Senator Sherry says that there is never going to be a cultural change in the Australian workplace.
—Not in all workplaces.

—Maybe not in all workplaces, but we do seek this cultural change. The case of Senator Bob Brown's jacket is a good case in point. He probably will not wear out as many jackets as I do in this job, because he keeps them nicely hung in the back of his office cupboard. And more power too him—not too much, though. The dress codes in here, and the rules and the regulations on the behaviour of senators are generally created by consensus and cooperation. Senator Brown has sought to change that. I understand that Senator Brown has a motion before the Senate to discuss it at some stage in the future. Quite frankly, you make my point, Senator Sherry.
—But under this provision he would not be paid while that was going on.

—Absolutely not. That is a rule. I wear my coat in here. Sometimes I feel that I shouldn't, but I believe that senators over the years in their great wisdom have decided that we should all wear coats. They have decided that female senators do not have to have that apply to them. Some senator may come in here one day and decide not to wear his pants, and we would have to have a debate about that as well.

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of this measure is not to have an `us and them' situation. We are trying to develop a cultural change in the Australian workplace. That is what people who are opposing these amendments and opposing the bill cannot come to grips with. That is why there has been an ideological tussle. The Australian Democrats and the government, in putting together this agreement on these amendments to improve this bill, share the belief that we can have improvements in Australian industrial relations. This amendment moved by the Greens would be detrimental to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This new industrial environment sounds like a pretty scary place. It means that an employer can ask almost anything of an employee, however reasonable or unreasonable, even if an employee says, `No, I do not think that is a reasonable thing to do for various reasons, including health and safety.' We will not have an improved workplace but a workplace of fear and at times exploitation. If, by the end of the week, you do have not quite enough money to pay your employee, I am sure you can trump up a few things you can require your work force to do to which they will have to say, `I really cannot do that.' So maybe by the end of the week you can manage to dock them one or two days a week. That is a rather bizarre scenario, but we are dealing with a rather bizarre bill and a very bizarre part to the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I was hoping to have heard from the Democrats by this stage. I am happy to defer this issue if there is any chance whatsoever that there might be a movement in relation to this very silly proposal by the government. It is a proposal which will have many unwanted responses from employers who may not have any desire to dock their employees for what could be a ban limitation or restriction on the performance of work. It could be almost anything.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a point that Senator Margetts made. She has made it twice now. I guess you can generally win an argument if you build a straw man out of enough straw and dress it up with enough clothes to make it look like a real argument.

PARA.BREAK: The reality of the argument is that the workplace environment that we are building is one that starts off being made on agree ment. What you are saying is that an employer will go and ask an employee who has negotiated a workplace agreement to do something that is unreasonable. Senator Margetts, you roll your eyes because again you look at industrial relations through the paradigm of having us and them—these nasty bosses and these nasty employees.

SPEECH.PARA: There are nasty bosses out there. I am sure there are a hell of a lot of them. Senator Sherry, you and I will agree that that is not going to change the day after this bill passes into law. Of course it will not. If you want to achieve change as a nation, if you want to achieve change in industrial relations, you have to help build that new environment.

You would prefer to keep Australia in the old environment, not to change it, not to move forward to an environment where you actually build a regime which encourages more cooperation and more agreement. The reality here is that you agree between the employer and employee on all of those relationships and workplace matters and what you are saying is that that is irrelevant and that will never happen. You believe that could never happen because employers are all nasty and the employees are subjugated by these nasty employers.

You would know from your own experience that that is not always the case. Things are changing and we hope this bill might change things more. However, if you build up a straw man and say that employers will direct people to do totally unreasonable things, the fact is they already have agreements in place as to what their terms of employment are, the sorts of tasks they will be undertaking—job descriptions and so forth. Again, you have built up a straw man which you seek to knock over. People who want to understand this matter should realise that is what you are doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Campbell's talk about a straw man needs a bit of testing. The example that comes to my mind with this provision and the amendment moved by Senator Margetts is the nursing profession. In the state of Tasmania the nursing profession in public hospitals are covered by federal awards. If they decide, because they do not want to disrupt patient care, that they do not want to do a certain amount of paperwork, then the Tasmanian government is directed by this legislation, if they can be, to withhold all payment for the entirety of the shift. That is what this provision is proposing to say.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the government is seeking to impress upon groups like nurses, who do not want to take direct action but want to make an industrial point, that they have to either lose their pay and perform the work and make a token gesture, which will be pointless and have no effect on their employer, or alternatively say, `We'll go all the way.' You are saying to us, `If you do anything you don't get a penny.'

I just wonder whether this provision is going to push groups who might take a minor action to a point where they will say, `What the hell. We are going to lose pay. Why don't we take the action?' Or will it be teachers? A lot of the teaching profession are seeking coverage by federal awards. From time to time they take action. They say that they are not going to fill in term reports or the like. If they say that they are not going to fill in term reports, how long do you dock their pay—until they do it? Are you saying to teachers, `Well, you might as well go all the way?' But when you do that you come back to this question of orders to stop or prevent industrial action.

Is the agenda of the government with these amendments to come back and say, `We are going to force people to take action because we can injunct to stop it?' The culture of the amendments may be to remove the rights of many employees to take any form of industrial action in real terms. I think the Democrats ought to look very closely at this provision because I do not think they fully appreciate the impact that this will have on the industrial climate, particularly for groups who have traditionally been reluctant to take the absolute form of industrial action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Democrats and government are talking over this again, I endorse the opportunity that Senator Margetts has flagged that the Democrats at least sleep on this. We have to take from the silence so far on the matter that they have not understood the import of what this section means. As Senator O'Brien says, the workplace is going to be driven to greater industrial action by this section, not to lesser industrial action. You may as well be hung for a sheep than for a lamb. If you are going to lose your pay you might as well go out on strike as have a work to rule.

SPEECH.PARA: It has not been thought through by the government, let alone the Democrats. This is a new period of workplace relationship in which the government says to the employer, `You must punish your employees.' No matter what your relationship with them is, if they invoke a work to rule campaign on a matter that is worrying them it will radically worsen relationships, not improve them.

If this goes through, employees in any workplace in Australia who take such action are going to be penalised. Without any reference to the courts or an adjudicator the employer must dock their pay. So they are immediately going to be facing penalties totally out of proportion to what they are doing.

The question arises: what happens when an employer asks employees to do something which is illegal, which infringes upon workplace safety provisions or some other law providing for the protection of the wider society? I imagine the court is going to have the commonsense at the end of the day to make sure that the workers get back their pay. But in the meantime they are going to have to be docked. They are going to have to take a penalty. The employer is obliged, under this proposed section of this legislation, to impose that penalty or presumably that employer is going to be in breach of the law. What a remarkable set of circumstances.

I say to the Democrats: at least take this home and look at it again. Senator Margetts has brought up a matter of extraordinary importance to the workplace in Australia. This issue has not been canvassed in public. I doubt there is anybody out there in the Australian workplace who is aware of this particularly insidious proposed section of the law where the word `may'—bad as that might be—has been replaced by the word `must'. An employer will be set against an employee by a government who have failed to see the full ramifications of what they are doing in this proposed section.

Anyway it is a very critical moment for reconsideration. There is a lot weighing on this. Again I thank the government for responding, as they have done on every occasion. Yes, it is black and white. It is very clear that what Senator Margetts has said is dead right. The matter is deadly serious. But there is still this silence from Senator Murray and the Democrat benches. It is a telling moment. It will be gone very shortly and it is a matter for prudence to be brought into place so that at least overnight consideration is given to the matter that Senator Margetts has brought before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray says that he would like to seek the call, so I am very happy to speak very briefly to allow Senator Murray to take the call. I do not know how, but Senator Campbell managed to somehow represent the Greens (WA) as wanting to go back in time. No, we want to go forward in time. We actually believe in workplace democracy. We believe in the new workplace. The new workplace of real best practice is, in my belief, the ability to bargain collectively, to reduce the vertical decision-making process and to increase the democracy within the workplace so that everybody can benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: That is my vision of the workplace. It is certainly nothing like the position Senator Campbell seems to think he wants Australia to be in. If this is the vision the coalition is saying it has for industrial relations, then in fact you are saying that you are hoping everything is going to work out okay.

For all of the people who heard all of the evidence in this committee of inquiry, to suggest that you can put a provision in a bill on the basis that human nature will be terrific is ridiculous. We have to make legislation on the basis of how it might be misused. In a very competitive environment, we have to assume that if it costs less to do things in a certain way then that is the way it will happen.

How many times have we heard industry say, `If you're going to want standards, you're going to have to have them legislated, because our competitor will not use the same standards.' That is what they are saying these days: if you want standards enforced, they need to be legislated. Industry of course wants industry based standards. They know the reason they want that. They will not have to enforce them.

But in this particular case, in relation to human nature, if you allow a provision to be misused, it is ridiculous to leave it so open for misuse. I am not saying that industry is bad. I am not saying that business is bad. But I am saying that there is copious evidence that people are human and that these kinds of issues will come up again and again. It is very silly not to address these kinds of errors in the bill when we see them instead of coming back at very short notice to try to fix them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just moved from a straw man to straw men. Senator Brown in his contribution to the debate a couple of minutes ago used the same line of argument that Senator Margetts tried to get away with—that is, `What happens if an employee is forced to do something illegal? This nasty Commonwealth government will force the employer not to pay them.' You are saying that an employer who is breaking the law is forced to abide by this part of the law.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is—whether you like it or not; and it will not assist you in building your straw man to have facts around to interfere with that construction process—that industrial action can include only failure to perform work which it is the employee's duty to perform. It is not an employee's duty to perform illegal acts, even if the employer directs that such acts be performed. You cannot have it both ways.

Senator Sherry relies on Senator Brown's lack of a coat as an example. Senator Margetts raises an example which is not real world. You have raised one that is so bizarre that it is irrelevant to the debate. You can stand here and keep making these points and say that, if this happens, the world will come to an end. But the reality is that all of the cases you have created so far are simply unrealistic.

In response to Senator Margetts, what you fail to respect in your argument in relation to the cost of things is the cost of having a system that is failing at the moment. You are defending a situation at the moment which involves enormous costs. You believe this is a low cost option. You are defending a system that is failing in relation to our current system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reminded of Kafka or perhaps catch‐22 when you are condemned for keeping silent but you cannot get a word in edgeways. Perhaps I will have my moment now. I will begin with two questions to the parliamentary secretary. Perhaps you could take some advice. My impression is that, with the common law at present, it is the case that an employer is entitled not to pay an employee. Is that the case? That is my first question. I would like to know the common law position. My second question concerns whether the section we are considering is an extension of the existing section 124 of the current labour act and continues a current practice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to both those questions is yes, Senator Murray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a vast difference between an employer being entitled not to pay an employee and the provision now in this legislation which says that an employer must not pay an employee. That is what Senator Margetts is on about. In relation to the request of Senator Murray, the answer from Senator Campbell simply says that what Senator Margetts is saying is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I go back to the supposition that an employer might ask an employee to do something which turns out to be illegal—for example, to work at a new piece of machinery which is not reaching adequate safety standards. That is something itself which will be a matter of dispute until it is determined by an arbitrator. But, in the meantime, if the employer is sure in her or his mind that the machinery is okay—notwithstanding what the employee thinks and notwithstanding the fact that at a later hearing it turns out that the employer is wrong—he or she will have to dock the employee to penalise them. It will be up to the employee to get to the court to justify the action they are taking. The whole weight of responsibility goes across to the employee considering a work‐to‐rules campaign or some other action short of a strike.

The question Senator Margetts posed to the Australian Democrats at the outset therefore stands. Will they consider at least taking a furlough overnight to get independent advice on what is turning out to be a very critical matter for the Australian workplace?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second time I have answered the question. It is straw man No. 3 here. This is the new one, Senator Brown, as you are saying, if there is a bit of machinery that may be unsafe. If it is unsafe and if it is a danger to health, it is specifically excluded from this provision.
—No, you are not listening to what I said.
—I did listen but maybe I am not hearing well enough.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is starting to get a little repetitious. From our point of view, if Senator Murray wants the matter deferred, we are happy to support that. But I think it is the time when Senator Murray should indicate to us what he wants. If you want that, Senator Murray, we, as an opposition, are happy to accommodate you.

—Now that I have the opportunity to get up again without Bob bobbing next to me, I have a third question I want to ask as a follow-up to my first two. Is it the case, and could you outline it for us, that you have to read 187AA with 187AD and that the court, if an application was made under 187AD, would not be required to grant a penalty in this matter? Perhaps you could spell out the ramifications of the two read together.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, the answer to your question is yes. It is open for the court not to impose a penalty.
—My further question to the parliamentary secretary is: does that provide appropriate protection for employees and employers in the situation outlined by the speakers so far?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe, Senator Murray, that it complies with the principle that we are trying to apply to the whole of the bill which you, better than most other senators, are aware of, which is a fair go all around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally I will go back to where Senator Margetts began, and that is the recent action by people in the Commonwealth employed not to implement the dole diaries. The government has made it clear that under this provision those people would be docked their pay. They would have been penalised then and there. There would have been no resort to the courts and no independent arbiter. They would have got a summary penalty on the spot. There would be no alternative for the employer, who, in this case, is the Commonwealth anyway, but that the penalty must be imposed from the minute that action starts.

SPEECH.PARA: That is quite clear. That is what the Australian Democrats are voting to enforce. That is the provision of this legislation which will rule as of the passage of this legislation tonight or tomorrow. That is the responsibility that the Democrats must share if they do not take independent advice and do not take the opportunity that Senator Margetts is presenting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little confused as to the response given by the parliamentary secretary when Senator Murray asked him about the effect of 187AD of the workplace relations bill. As far as I can see, it deals with the power of the court in respect of contraventions of sections 187AA or 187AB. But 187AA is not really relevant, because it requires the employer not to make a payment to an employee for a period in which the employee engages in industrial action, and then it qualifies that.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 187AB, however, talks about `organisations not to take action for payments in relation to periods of industrial action'. It says:
An organisation, or an officer, member or employee of an organisation, must not:

I cannot quite follow the response that was given by the parliamentary secretary to Senator Murray. I cannot see that his response gives any clarification to the matter that was raised by Senator Margetts initially.

I add another point. Given the point that the parliamentary secretary made in relation to a payment being withheld because of an employee refusing to obey an instruction to perform an illegal act, I ask: what about the case where an employee has a strong objection based on conscience at a particular time to the performance of a particular task? Is that not then requiring the employer to not make payment to the employee in respect of the exercise of that objection based on conscience?

The second point that I want to make relates to contracts that are entered into from time to time. I am not talking about AWAs; I am talking about contracts for the performance of a job. The clauses of a number of contracts contain a provision that requires the contractor to perform the tasks in accordance with the laws of the Commonwealth or the state. Section 187AA(3) says `a contravention of subsection (1) or (2) is not an offence'. It is not an offence under this, but the party to the contract to receive the supply of goods could insist that a contractor who has made payment to an employee for a period in which the employee engages in industrial action had breached the provisions of the contract. That would be so, would it not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit worried. Senator Murray is not here. I notice that he left the chamber with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith). I do not want to embarrass him by our moving to a vote in his absence. It would be quite extraordinary. I am sure you can stall sufficiently for him to come back in, Senator Campbell.
—We might be able to get back to the amendment in front of us, too.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine raises two issues. On the last one, it is fair to say that you do seek an advisory legal opinion for which I am not qualified or well enough paid to respond to you. I am sure that would be an interesting point. I could give you a legal opinion: I think that you are wrong. But that advice is worth exactly how much you paid for it.
—What about what taxpayers paid your advisers?

—Again, my advisers are not here to give an advisory legal opinion on a case that may occur at some stage in the next 25 years. I did do a little bit of contract law as part of a business course many years ago. I am aware of the principles that you raise. Even though I did very well in that particular unit, which involved torts and contracts, the advice I give you is worth exactly what you paid for it. The first point relates to the penalties and the flexibility in relation to 187AD. I stand by the answer I gave to Senator Murray, that is, it remains open for the court to decide that matter.

PARA.BREAK: Even though you said you raised only two points, you actually raised three which I think are important. The other one was conscien tious objection. We would hope, in the event that an employee had strong conscientious beliefs in relation to various matters, that they would be matters that would be, particularly, in relation to performing tasks, functions or matters at work and would be things that could be the subject of discussion with their employer. That would be the hope. In the case that that was a forlorn hope, again, I would imagine that the answer to the first question would be the ultimate test of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to repeat it but I have to say that I cannot see how the answer to the first question, that is to say 187AD, covers the situation at all. I really do not see that, when it relates to the requirement on the employer in respect an employee. Section 187AD relates, in effect, to the actions of the contravention of 187AA or 187AB. Contravention of 187AA is classically the payment by the employer to the employee. That is a contravention of 187AA. In 187AD it talks about contraventions of 187AB which relate to an organisation, an officer, a member or an employee of an organisation. It does not deal with that question of an employee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise if I confused you. I slightly confused myself because you raised three points. I set out to respond to two of them and, in responding to the third, I referred back to my first answer. I thought I had totally confused everyone in the chamber but I had not confused you enough. I actually said to the adviser, `I think that should just about confuse them all.' I am glad that I did not confuse you enough.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal point I was making in relation to conscientious objectors was that they should be matters that are worked out. I think it is fair to say that there may well be people with conscientious beliefs. I know when I first enrolled in university my conscientious belief was that I did not want to be a member of a student union. I had no alternative when I was a student but to belong to that union. Otherwise, I would not be given my grades or even a permit to park in the student car park. I had no outlet for that.

It is possible in that circumstance that someone may enter into an agreement or a workplace relationship and that was not a matter of discussion when the workplace agreement came into place. It may well be that those conscientious beliefs were private matters that both the employee and the employer thought were outside that sort of negotiation and discussion. I think that is a very valid point you have raised, Senator Harradine.

It may well be that an employer may ask an employee to do something that was outside their conscientious beliefs and that it was not the subject of an agreement. It is not impossible for me or the government to see that occurring, although we would hope that would not be the case. That is one example of a matter which should be kept under review.

The government will keep these matters under review and we believe it will work effectively. But if the problems that you have raised in the debate do emerge, then the government will undertake to assess that and, if amendments to this section are required, of course we will bring them back here under that circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Brown jumped that time. Many of us were waiting to see whether there was any possibility that this could be deferred. I ask Senator Murray whether the Democrats have absolutely satisfied themselves that they have not done the wrong thing by the Australian workers in this amendment.
—I listened carefully to the debates and I must say it was Senator Brown's intervention which decided the matter for me. Therefore, I propose that we do not defer the debate and we move to a vote.
—Put a jacket back on!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that says a lot about the seriousness with which the Democrats have taken the argument put by all other members on this side. Indeed, Senator Harradine most tellingly pointed out that matters of conscience in the workplace, where an employee determines that they will not carry out an instruction of an employer because it is against their conscience, are now to be summarily penalised. The secretary says, `If that happens, we will look at it.' It is going to happen. The employer has no choice in those circumstances but to withhold pay on a matter of conscience.

SPEECH.PARA: I can think of issues that Senator Harradine is thinking about. I can think of a number of issues which I feel very strongly about, but I am astonished and flabbergasted that, despite this debate, the Democrats are going to join with the government and support a measure like this which is even going to penalise people who act in good faith on their conscience in the workplace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know I did say to Senator Brown in jest that he should put a jacket on, but that was the state of incredulity I was in when Senator Murray gave his response. We have had some very legitimate points and questions raised by Senator Brown, Senator Margetts, Senator O'Brien and Senator Harradine.
—Me.
—Yes, and Senator Jacinta Collins. The parliamentary secretary could not answer them adequately.
—Be fair.

—I do not think you could answer them adequately. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) dashed down into the chamber and Senator Murray went out with him. I bet I know what he said to you, Senator Murray. He would have said, `Don't you back down on this or the deal is off.' That is what he would have said to you. For the minister to come into this chamber and threaten you, Senator Murray, is not the way to behave.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. That is an imputation against a member of the other chamber, is entirely against standing orders and should be withdrawn.
—It is a clear imputation and I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Chairman. If the minister wants to come in here and pressure Senator Murray—

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I want to put on the record that I was not threatened, nor did the minister refer to a deal or tell me not to back off—or any of the words you used. We were actually discussing another matter and then we discussed the matter before us. We now have an undertaking from the parliamentary secretary that the government will deal with this matter appropriately if the problems outlined emerge as said.
—That is not a point of order, Senator Murray. That is a point of explanation. There are times to make points of explanation and it is not now.
—We are up to opposition amendment No. 294. We have not yet had the Democrats on one occasion concede that we have been right on one of our amendments.
—They voted with you for one.

—Except for one. That is the same for the Green amendments. Not one argument that we or the Greens have put has been accepted. It is a case of, `We can't break our agreement; we can't break our deal.' Minister Reith dashed down here into the chamber—quite extraordinary scenes. I have not seen a minister from the House of Representatives carry on like this in my six years in the Senate. I am sure, Senator Murray, that he put the position to you very bluntly and very clearly. That is very regrettable.

SPEECH.PARA: This serves to highlight that, regardless of the argument that is put to the Australian Democrats in a very clear, concise and well argued way, time and time again you simply have a closed mind. Through the hundreds of amendments that have been moved, you have not been prepared to concede on at least one occasion that the deal you entered into with the government was wrong on at least one point. I think that really highlights the very closed mind that you and the Democrats have adopted on the debate on this bill.
