SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just commenced schedule 15, registered organisations. There are a number of vitally important issues that I want to address on this schedule. The first is the proposed amendments in relation to union organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two key aspects to which the opposition is strongly opposed. We are firmly opposed to the creation of enterprise unions. The problems they will create for the industrial relations system as a whole are manifest. The introduction of enterprise unions will lead to a multiplicity of unions, to the detriment of employers and the community as a whole. It will create federally registered unions which cannot be party to a federal award, thereby creating a gap in representation rights. It will permit the federal registration of a union which would traditionally, and indeed exclusively, be registered under state law. This will create a conflict between federal and state industrial relations systems.

What is achieved in return? We do not think anything. At worst, these enterprise unions will be nothing but bosses unions. At best, there must be severe doubts whether a union which is exclusively centred on one enterprise can, even assuming adequate funding, appropriately represent the interests of members better than an industrial union. And what of its funding base? How can a union with so few members and such an inadequate funding base properly represent its members? We do not think it can and we believe that the government knows it.

The opposition is also firmly committed to opposing any changes to the existing `conveniently belong' rule. The Democrats did their best to prevent the repeal of the rule and they succeeded, but I must say that the compromise they have reached—as is often the case with compromises—does not improve their position and actually creates a provision which is so complicated that many industrial relations practitioners around Australia must be scratching their heads wondering what it all means.

The great tragedy is that the existing rules operated effectively to avoid what can be the harmful effects of union competition, including demarcation disputes and the problems associated with employers having to deal with a multiplicity of unions. I cannot recall at the committee hearings any employer support for the concept of competition between unions at a workplace brought about by the types of provisions proposed. In fact, I can recall only employer evidence that was supportive of the existing provisions in the existing act.

The changes to the rule could lead to an increase in union conflicts as contests about effective representation develop. It is also extremely unfair that enterprise associations are exempted from the operation of the rule. There is no justification for this other than discrimination against organisations that are not enterprise organisations.

The second vital issue is the question of disamalgamation. The opposition's position on this issue is crystal clear. The opposition is concerned that the amalgamation proposals in this bill may create a multiplicity of unions. However, we accept the disamalgamation proposal in so far as it relates to the original preamalgamation constituent unions because we do not believe this parliament can prevent a union which has democratically amalgamated with another from democratically disamalgamating.

PARA.BREAK: But, as to that part of the disamalgamating proposal that permits constituent unions to further disamalgamate to their state branches, the rationale to which I have referred simply does not apply. Those individual state branch es did not individually elect to amalgamate and, therefore, there is no question of their individually electing to disamalgamate.

SPEECH.PARA: The third and final issue I wish to address is one that I have discussed before—right of entry. The opposition totally rejects the regulation of right of entry exclusively by a statutory scheme. The regulation of right of entry by the commission on a case-by-case basis is the only appropriate system because only it can take into account individual circumstances peculiar to particular employees or industries.

The Health Services Union of Australia has pointed out a very important example to the opposition. Many of its members work as health care workers in residential nursing homes. The relevant award takes this into account and permits unions to access residential homes so that the union can look after the interests of its members. Yet this bill prohibits the entry of unions into premises used for residential purposes without the permission of the occupier.

What happens to health care workers in residential nursing homes? There is effectively no right of entry. The opposition will move an amendment to remove this particular problem and I urge the Democrats to support it. They must realise that this is but one example of the practical problems which the statutory scheme has that they have signed up to.

There is another example which I am sure will concern Senator Bourne—the problem of looking after the interests of outworkers. An effective right of entry provision requires entry not only to the place of outwork but also to the place from which the work is outsourced—that is where the records are and that is where the boss is. Under these provisions, unions have no right of entry to these places. We will move an amendment to address the problem and hope the Democrats will join with us.

The Democrats have signed up to this statutory scheme. They should do everything they can to ameliorate its worst excesses, particularly the very important examples I have highlighted. To facilitate the speed of the debate, as I mentioned before, I seek to incorporate six pages of notes that go to the specific amendments.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
The Opposition is opposed to the creation of enterprise associations and is moving amendments accordingly. The Opposition will therefore vote against this new definition for `enterprise association'.

This amendment was originally intended to delete the definition of `enterprise branch' (consequent on our opposition to enterprise branches of registered organisations). Assuming Govt/Dems (146) is agreed to, the Opposition will still move this amendment in relation to `enterprise association' for the reasons stated at Govt/Dems (146).

The Opposition is opposed to this amendment. If the Commission or Registrar believe that an officer or employee of an organisation is the most appropriate to exercise the inspectorate powers the Commission or Registrar should not be deprived of that option.

The Bill repeals, from the objects clause of the "Registered organisations" Part, the objects of encouraging the development of organisations and of encouraging and facilitating their amalgamation. This amendment deletes this repeal. The Opposition believes that this existing Object of the Act should be retained. Organisations of employees and employers are vital to a cooperative industrial relations system, and therefore they must be encouraged and facilitated. The amalgamation process has, on balance, been a success and should at least be facilitated where it is desired.
This is a consequential provision to give effect to the amendments permitting enterprise associations. Because the Opposition is opposed to enterprise associations we will not support this amendment.

The Bill originally repealed the requirement that only associations capable of creating an industrial dispute can apply for registration (this requirement would prevent the registration of enterprise unions). The Opposition proposed to omit the original repeal because of our opposition to enterprise associations. Govt/Dems (149) is to the same effect and the Opposition will therefore support it on that basis.
Given Govt/Dems (149) this amendment is no longer necessary and the Opposition will not move it.

This amendment permits the creation of `enterprise associations'. The Opposition is opposed to enterprise associations. The introduction of enterprise associations will lead to a multiplicity of unions, to the detriment of employers and the community as a whole. There are also specific problems with this proposals. It creates a Federally registered union which cannot be party to a Federal award (thereby creating a gap in its representation rights). It permits the Federal registration of a union which would traditionally, and indeed exclusively, be registered under State law ( thereby creating conflict between Federal and State industrial relations system).

The Opposition is opposed to the reduction in the minimum number of members required for registration of an organisation. The Opposition queries whether a union which is exclusively centred on one enterprise can, even assuming adequate funding, appropriately represent the interests of members better than is done by existing structures. We also query the inadequate funding base of a union with so few members.

The Opposition does not accept the changes proposed by this amendment to the `conveniently belong' rule in relation to registration of organisations. The rule has operated to avoid what can be the harmful effects of union competition, including demarcation disputes and the problems associated with employers having to deal with a multiplicity of unions. The changes to the rule are confusing and will inevitably reduce the effectiveness of the rule. They could lead to an increase in union conflict as contests about effective representation develop. It is also extremely unfair that enterprise associations are exempted from the operation of the rule. There is no justification for this other than discrimination against organisations that are not enterprise associations.
Despite Govt/Dems (151)—(154) the Opposition remains opposed to these provisions and will vote against them.

In the criteria for registration of organisations, the amended Bill repeals the requirement for an association of employees to be industry‐based or otherwise for there to be special circumstances (this requirement would prevent the registration of enterprise unions). It inserts a requirement that the Commission be satisfied that the organisation would conduct its affairs in a way that meets its obligations under the Act. This amendment deletes the repeal and the new provision.
This amendment is to the same effect as Opp (308) which of course the Government voted against in the House of Representatives. The Opposition will support the amendment.
Given Govt/Dems (155) this amendment is no longer necessary and the Opposition will not move it.
This amendment is consequential upon Govt/Dems (152)—(154) which the Opposition will not support. Accordingly, we will not support this amendment.

The Opposition does not accept the changes proposed by this amendment to the `conveniently belong' rule in relation to changes to rules of organisations. The reasons for this are the same as I explained at Govt/Dems (152)—(154).
Despite Govt/Dems (157) the Opposition is opposed to this provision and will vote against it.
This amendment is to the same effect as Opp (311) which the Government previously voted against in the House of Representatives. The Opposition will support it on that basis.
Given Govt/Dems (158) the Opposition will not move this amendment.

The Bill repeals the existing objects of the "amalgamation" Part. This amendment deletes this repeal. The Opposition believes this existing Object of the Act should be retained. The amalgamation process has, on balance, been a success and should at least be facilitated where it is desired.

The Bill provides that the objects of the "Withdrawal from amalgamations" provision is to provide for disamalgamation of newly amalgamated unions and for the de‐amalgamation of branches of unions. Whilst accepting the first object, this amendment deletes the second object. As to newly amalgamated unions, the Opposition is concerned this proposal may create a multiplicity of unions. However, we accept the proposal because we don't believe the legislature can prevent a union which has democratically amalgamated with another from democratically disamalgamating. As to State branches, the Opposition notes that the rationale for the disamalgamation proposals relate only to amalgamations resulting from the legislative changes in 1991. This proposal is inconsistent with this rationale.

The Bill defines "constituent part" to mean both a union which amalgamated with another union and the branch of such a union. (All the substantive provisions dealing with disamalgamation than apply to constituent parts as defined). We accept the first definition and delete the second definition (in this way we delete the application of all the disamalgamation provisions to branches of amalgamating unions). The arguments in support of this position are again those I stated earlier at Opp (313).
As a consequence of our deleting reference to branches of unions, this amendment makes a consequential amendment in this provision.
As a consequence of redefining "award" to include certified agreements (see Opp (243)) these amendments make consequential amendments to this provision.

The Bill provides that a member's resignation from a union is effective 2 weeks after notice is received by the union. This amendment reinstates the existing time period of 3 months. Two weeks is insufficient time for administrative arrangements to be appropriately changed.

The Bill inserts a new provision which exempts certain branches from the financial reporting requirements (this is directed to assisting enterprise unions). These amendments delete this provision and make some consequential changes. These amendments flow from our opposition to enterprise associations.
The Opposition will vote against this amendment. There is no justification for placing a time limit—a such a short period of 12 months—on a union's right to recover moneys owing to it.

The Bill inserts a provision which permits the Registrar, either in the circumstances set out in the regulations or if there are reasonable grounds for doing so, to investigate union affairs on new grounds. This amendment confines this only to the situation where the registrar has reasonable grounds for investigating. It is only appropriate the Registrar have reasonable grounds for acting before investigating union affairs.

The Bill makes special provision for the accounts and audit of an organisation whose income is less than $20,000. This amendment reinstates the existing threshold of $10,000. There is no rationale for this change.

The Opposition welcomes the repeal of the right of entry provisions in the original Bill. However, for reasons I have already explained, the Opposition believes there are considerable defects on the alternative proposal in Government/Democrat amendment (160). The Opposition is firmly committed to award right of entry and believes that any statutory scheme can not be as effective. The Opposition will therefore vote against this amendment.

This amendment was originally moved in opposition to the right of entry provisions in the original Bill. However for the reasons stated the Opposition remains committed to opposing the right of entry provisions as amended by Govt/Dems (160).

These amendments amend the proposed right of entry provisions so that unions can enter premises from which work is given out (to be performed outside the premises). They also remove the 24 hour notice requirement in the case of these premises. I have already explained the reasons why the Opposition is moving these amendments.

This amendment deletes proposed s285D(3) of the amended Bill concerning right of entry. For reasons already explained, the Opposition believes it is important that statutory right of entry must be able to be exercised in relation to premises used for residential purposes.
The Opposition opposes these amendments because they are inserted as part of the introduction of enterprise organisations. We are opposed to enterprise associations and so oppose these amendments.
Given Govt/Dems (161) this amendment is unnecessary and the Opposition will not move it.
These technical amendments are consequent on the proposed right of entry provisions. The Opposition is opposed to those provisions and opposes these amendments on the same basis.
Given Govt/Dems (162) this amendment is unnecessary and the Opposition will not move it.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 4—Representation rights of organisations of employees

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment deletes s118A (which provides the Commission with power to give unions exclusive representation rights for certain employees). We also accept the Bill's repeal of s118 (which permits the Commission to consult in making a s118A order). For reasons already stated, the Opposition believes that if the existing `conveniently belong' rule is to be modified to permit greater competition between unions any restraints on that competition should be removed. Consistent with this, the capacity for employers to seek these orders from the Commission should be removed. Consequentially, Commission consultation provisions must also be removed.
These amendments are consequential upon Opp (4). If Opp (4) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.
Whilst this amendment appears to be a cosmetic change at best, it does improve the Bill somewhat. The Opposition will therefore support the amendment on that basis.
Given Govt/Dems (15) this amendment is no longer relevant and the Opposition does not move it.
These amendments are consequential upon Opp (4). If Opp (4) is not agreed to the Opposition will not move this amendment.

This amendment provides that an existing application under s118A, whether the substantive hearing of that application has begun or not, continues to be governed by the pre‐repeal (or pre‐amend) s118A (whereas the Bill says that an existing s118A application, if the substantive hearing has not begun, is to be governed by the post‐amend s118A). The Opposition believes that it is unfair that an application commenced under an earlier law should be determined according to a subsequent law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —On the issue of Clayton's unions, the Greens are supporting the opposition in its stance. In this bill there are a number of ways in which the bargaining power has been weakened and this is just another one. The setting up and the encouragement of Clayton's unions to pretend to workers that they are getting real representation will be very detrimental to the ability of people to stand up for their basic rights in the workplace in Australia because largely these unions will be limited by the resources that they can amass themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Unions that we deal with already have difficulty getting on top of current industrial relations legislation. Clayton's unions, obviously, do not have the kinds of resources, researchers and legal advice necessary. They do not have people who can work with specific groups of people. That means they will be, if you like, dependent on the information that is largely provided by the employer.

Considering all the other things in this bill which weaken the bargaining position of the employee, I do not know how anyone could support further weakening the position by setting up and encouraging Clayton's unions rather than developing the real ability to collectively bargain in ways and with the resources to stand up against the corporate resources—we are not just talking about small firms—and sometimes the resources of governments, which is the reality of the new industrial scene in Australia.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity to seek leave to incorporate all my remarks on schedule 15.
Leave granted.
The remarks read as follows—
SCHEDULE 15:
GOVT/DEM 146 (OPPOS 301)
The Democrats support this amendment and will speak on the deletion of enterprise branches and the insertion of enterprise unions later in the debate.
GOVT DEM 147
The Democrats support this amendment. The statutory right of entry rights for union officials are much expanded by later amendments, rendering this extra power unnecessary.
OPPOS 302

The Democrats oppose these amendments. These seek to make clear that the amalgamation of unions is to be encouraged and facilitated. The simple fact is that the reality of amalgamation has not met the promise. Unionisation rates continue to fall, unions have spent more energy on restructuring than on recruiting. While we supported the union amalgamation rules when first raised seven years ago, I think it is now appropriate that the Act adapt a more neutral stance on these issues.
GOVT/DEM 148

This amendment seeks to establish the definition of enterprise for the purposes of enterprise unions. The definition is different from that used for enterprise agreements and deliberately so. An enterprise union can be formed in relation to a simple employer or an operationally distinct part of an employer. The term "operationally distinct" was deliberately chosen. As the explanatory memorandum makes clear, the fact that a place is a separate workplace does not make it operationally distinct. In jointly moving this amendment, I believe that "operationally distinct" requires something considerably more than that. It must be an operation, a distinct operation. In industrial terms, that would mean an operation capable of organising and negotiating its own industrial affairs. In major corporations, that would mean an autonomous business unit. In the Government sector, it would probably mean a Government department or statutory authority. What the Commission should seek to avoid is a situation where the senior managers charged with industrial negotiations end up dealing with more than one enterprise union in their operation. This is a fairly tight criteria and combined with the tight criteria in proposed 189(1C), it will ensure that truly independent, truly enterprise based unions can be formed, and not sham bosses unions as part of a divide and conquer campaign.
GOVT/DEM 149, OPPOS 303
The Democrats support this amendment.
GOVT/DEM 150-153
These amendments establish a range of changes to union registration rules. I will deal with them briefly.

Following extensive submission from both unions and employers opposed to the Government's competitive unionism model, the Democrats have been able to persuade the Government to re-instate a version of the "conveniently belong" rule. This will avoid the free for all which would have been the result of the original bill. Unions already spend millions of dollars a year trying to steal each other's members, and the Democrats do not believe that the public interest would have been served by freeing this up completely.

Under the compromise in this amendment, where a union applies for a rule to cover areas covered by another union, the current union can object on the ground that the members could more conveniently belong to it and be more effectively represented by it. The second criteria is a particular improvement in our view. It means that if a union is failing to perform, it can find itself liable to competition. But, if it is performing, then it should keep its coverage.

The amendments also set the extensive rules for registration of enterprise unions. These are very tight criteria designed to ensure that enterprise unions are viable and capable of performing their functions under the act, free from influence from the employer and outside bodies and have the support of the majority of employees wanting to be covered. A union which meets these criteria would be supported. But, the amendment would avoid the establishment of bosses union, unions like the Metway Staff Association and the Bond University Staff Association, set up by employers to cut out real unions.
Other amendments seek to increase the minimum number of members of a union from 20 to 50 members. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

The Democrats oppose these amendments to delete items 6, 9, 10 and 11. The amendments we have negotiated provide an adequate alternative response to the issue the Opposition is pursuing with these amendments.
OPPOS 305 (delete item 7)
The Democrats oppose this amendment, as the proposed new 189(1)(d) provides a more appropriate criteria than the old paragraph (9d) the ALP wants to retain.
GOVT/DEM 155, OPPOS 308-9

The Democrats support these amendments. Enterprise branches were a recipe for prolonged litigation and internal brawling within unions. We are pleased the Government has been persuaded not to proceed with those provisions.
GOVT/DEM 156
The Democrats support this amendment.
GOVT/DEM 157
The Democrats support this amendment to delete the provisions in relation to enterprise branches.
The Democrats support this amendment for the same reasons I made in speaking to amendment 152.
OPPOS 310
The Democrats oppose this amendment as we believe that our alternative approach on conveniently belong will provide a better registration regime.
GOVT/DEM 158, OPPOS 311
The Democrats support this amendment as enterprise branches would not be a positive development.
OPPOS 312

This amendment seeks to retain section 233 which expresses the desirability of union amalgamations. Given that performance has not matched promise, the Democrats believe that is appropriate to not prefer the amalgamation of unions, and we oppose this amendment.
OPPOS 313-8
NOTE: ASK THAT OPPOS 313-5 be dealt with together
OPPOS 313-5

The Democrats support these amendments. While we believe that the amalgamation process has not been particularly successful, we do not believe that the total massive splintering of existing unions under the fairly open ended provision proposed by the Government are in the public interest. To allow unions to splinter on factional grounds or regional grounds, or to splinter back to trade-based unions, would not be in the public interest. There may be some merit in allowing unhappy marriages—amalgamations which have not worked—to be unravelled, and the ALP's amendments achieve this. Therefore we will support the ALP amendments in preference to the Government's proposal.

The Government's proposal to allow unions to disintegrate in any which way was obviously linked to the original competitive unionism model. Given the more regulated and orderly approach taken to rules with the re-insertion of a "conveniently belong" rule, I think that the original disamalgamation provisions are clearly inappropriate as the bill now stands.
OPPOS 316-8
These amendments we will not support as the definition of award does not include certified agreement.
OPPOS 319-321 (Delete items 19, 21-23)
The Democrats oppose these amendments.
GOVT/DEMS 159 (new section 264A)

The Democrats will support this amendment. This amendment has arisen out of the sloppy bookkeeping by some unions which wait several years before picking up on outstanding dues. I do not think that it is unreasonable to say to unions to keep their books fairly up to date and to not leave outstanding fees drag on forever. There were proposals floating around to restrict the capacity for recovery of unpaid fees to just 3 months, but we felt this was quite unreasonable, and the 12 months rule I think is a fair compromise.
OPPOS 322

The Democrats oppose this amendment. The regulations could provide some guidance to the Registrar as to when an investigation is needed. They will be disallowable. I think that is an appropriate system.
OPPOS 323

The Democrats oppose this amendment. This provision reflects the simplified reporting arrangements for companies. As the unions often complain they face reporting mechanisms more onerous than companies, they should not complain when we seek to reduce them to those of companies.
GOVT/DEM 160

These amendments set up the new statutory scheme for right of entry by union officials. The Democrats totally reject the proposals of the Government that right of entry should be restricted to a written invitation. This could have resulted in union members being singled out for targeting by unscrupulous employers.
The statutory scheme has three main elements.

First, union officials will be required to obtain a general permit for entry from the Industrial registrar. Abuse of right of entry provisions could result in the permit being removed. This is based roughly on the provisions in the NSW Carr legislation.

Second, the scheme establishes a general right of entry where the union has award coverage to a workplace for the purposes of consultations with employees, on the giving of 24 hours notice. The NSW legislation provides for 48 hours notice, so 24 hours is in our view more appropriate.

Third, the scheme establishes a right to inspect wages books and investigate breaches more thoroughly where the union has a member or members. This distinction we believe is appropriate. Employers have complained to me of unions with no members, merely out of spite, coming in and tying up the employers books and generally acting in an unhelpful way.

In our view, unions should be concerned about the rights of the 33 per cent of members that are their members. They must have the right to recruit and meet with employees. We have provided that. But, in terms of enforcement, that should come back to only where they have members.

It should be pointed out that while this statutory scheme applies in relation to awards, nothing precludes the parties including even more generous right of entry provision in certified agreements or AWAs. I don't believe that agreement should reduce the right of entry clauses as this would clearly breach the no disadvantage test and the public interest requirement.

I want to speak briefly to proposed section 285D(3), which makes it clear that a person in exercising right of entry is not entitled to enter any part of premises used for residential purposes except with the permission of the occupier. This mirrors the provision of section 300 of the NSW Act. Several unions with members in nursing homes and residential care have raised concerns about this provision.

In moving the amendment, I wish to make it absolutely clear that this section should not be used by employers to prevent unions entering nursing homes or residential care units. The provision would operate only to prevent entry to those parts of the home used for residential purposes. And they would be the private rooms of the occupants. And even then, entry could be agreed to with the permission of the occupier. The occupier is not the employer, but the residential occupier, the aged person in the room. Clearly, the common facilities of the unit, such as common rooms, dining rooms, bathrooms are not being used for residential purposes, and would be available for inspection under this clause.
I commend these provisions to the Senate.
OPPOS 324
The Democrats oppose these amendments. The right of entry scheme we have negotiated in our view provides a sensible balance of union, employer and employee rights.
GOVT/DEM 161
The Democrats support these amendments.
OPPOS 325
We support a limit of 50 rather than 20 or 100.
GOVT/DEM 162
The Democrats support these amendments.
OPPOS 326
The Democrats oppose this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to make it clear that it is in an amended form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) At the end of subsection 285B(2), add ", or any premises from which work is given out (to be performed outside the premises)".

(10) At the end of subsection 285D(2), add ", unless work is given out from the premises (to be performed outside the premises) in which case the person is entitled to enter the premises, and exercise powers, under section 285B or 285C without giving any notice to the occupier of the premises."
These two amendments are in regard to outworkers, particularly in the textile, clothing and footwear industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that opposition amendments 9 and 10 to government‐Democrat amendment 160 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray has incorporated his comments. Unfortunately, I know from past experience that it took me several hours to get a copy. So I ask him verbally, on this occasion, whether he could give us some information in relation to government‐Democrat amendment 160. My understanding is that both the Democrats and the government have been appraised of certain difficulties arising from this amendment, in particular with respect to outworkers, and that some further consideration has been given to those difficulties. Senator Murray, is there any further information that can be given to us on the issue of entry and inspection of premises with respect to distributors of work and outworkers?
—Would you repeat that? It seemed a very broad question. Senator Collins, I am happy to answer questions in relation to outworkers. If you can be specific, that would be helpful.
—I am quite happy to be more specific. It will probably take a little longer than I would hope would have been necessary, but I am quite happy to be more specific.

SPEECH.PARA: Some specific problems with respect to outworkers are addressed in our amendments 9 and 10—which the Democrats were successful in having incorporated into allowable matters. This will be utterly worthless if the union is not able to gain access to inspect records of those organisations or companies that are responsible for distributing outwork. I know this issue has been raised directly with both the Democrats and the government. Unfortunately, that is one of the consequences of government‐Democrat amendment 160 in its current form.

Unfortunately, given the process that we have of incorporating statements, I do not know whether Senator Murray has addressed that in the statement he has just incorporated. As I said, it took me several hours to get information on the last occasion. I got only a semi‐literate statement back in relation to a statement that was incorporated by the Democrats. So on this occasion I ask Senator Murray if he can add any light to the situation of any additional consideration which was given to the issue of addressing the needs of those trying to remedy what can often be quite severe exploitation of outworkers. I am sure, cross‐party wise, we are all aware of the valuable work that the union has been seeking to do. I hope my question is now quite clear and that Senator Murray may be in a position to let me know what, if any, further consideration has been given on that point because it was my understanding that some had been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, when you did refer to the government earlier the question was seeking a quite general response in relation to outworkers and it is helpful to me that you have refined that somewhat. Senator Murray is obviously quite capable of putting his own position on the record. Again, I say to the senator that a number of honourable senators—particularly Senator Sherry on behalf of the opposition—have helped the progress of this bill by freely agreeing, without any coercion whatsoever, to incorporate their comments. They have given me the courtesy of showing me those comments in plenty of time before seeking leave. I am sure Senator Murray would give any other senator that same courtesy. Of course, it is open to any senator—not that I encourage it—to refuse leave if they are worried that they will have trouble getting access to those comments.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the right of entry provisions in particular, which I am sure you are concerned about, when it comes to outworkers, subsection 285BGB(4) provides capacity for a permit holder to require an employer to produce records at a premises at which the employees work and at some other agreed place. In other words, the fact that the employees do not work at the employer's premises does not preclude the permit holder from gaining access to the time sheets, pay sheets and other relevant documents. We believe that a number of concerns which have, without any doubt, been legitimately put and are accommodated under subsection 285B allow, as I said, permit holders to require employers to produce those records.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point that it has to be agreed to, and that is a critical problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —The parliamentary secretary has just referred to the clause of the bill, but the significant point is that it is an agreed place. That is just the problem. This particular point of the legislation is perhaps the most serious because it is outworkers in the existing system who were being strained to the utmost. What we have now is the parliamentary secretary talking about an agreed place.

SPEECH.PARA: Those of us who were on the economics committee received evidence from a number of people. I would like to refer the parliamentary secretary to the real world of outworking. I refer to evidence that Ms Annie Delaney, the outwork coordinator for the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union, gave the committee as an example of typical conditions outworkers were working under. She cited the cases of Mrs Mi and Mrs Nguyen. She said:
They inform me that they never receive rates equivalent to the award and that they have relied on their daughters to assist them to perform the work over the last five years.

They have four children aged from 3 to 18 years old. One of the children, who is now 18 years old, has been involved in production for the last five years. The younger children, aged 16 and 12, are also involved in production daily. They estimate that the children work an average of three to four hours a night and from 10 to 12 hours each day of the weekend.
They estimate that their children are involved in production for approximately 35 hours a week in total. They themselves are involved in production for an approximate total of 98 hours a week.
That is, by the way, each. She went on:

They state that they have no choice but to get their children involved to assist them. They state that the family's average income for the total hours is approximately $500 to $700 a week. They state that without their children's help they could not get enough to get by on.

They inform me also that they have been subject to intense pressure and intimidation to complete work in less than the originally allocated time. They state that they have no choice but to complete orders in the time the contractor requires or they risk not getting paid and the discontinuation of work from the contractor.

They state it is not uncommon to be given work to be completed in five days but then the next day they begin receiving calls from the contractor to finish the work earlier. They have often been pressured to complete an order in three to four days and have to go without sleep for at least one day to complete the order.

There have been times when they have had to get their children to assist them and work through the night to finish an order. They state also that they know many families are in the same situation as themselves. They state they are often not paid for one, two or three lots of work at a time and that this is used by contractors as a form of intimidation and harassment.

They state it makes them worried all the time about whether they will receive the money they are owed. They report that there have been many instances where they have been told that if they do not finish the work early they will not receive any payment. They state that they have often been threatened with fines from the company for not completing an order early.

They state that they have worked for companies who pay cash only. They state that they are aware of particular companies who deal in cash only. They state that it is their experience that these companies hold over a percentage of the first six month's work. This could be a figure amounting to $2,000 or $3,000.

I could go on quoting from many examples, but I put this example to you because for you to suggest that this sort of an industry and this activity in industry could be dealt with by agreement is ridiculous. You should reconsider your position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said, Senator Childs. I did not suggest that. What you have just said—
—It's what's in the clause.

—No, it is not what is in the clause because, quite clearly, you have not read it. What you have just described is exactly what is happening under the industrial relations system designed and implemented by the Australian Labor Party and their friends in the ACTU. Clause 285B(4)(a) of government amendment No. 160—and you have either misread it, misunderstood it or misrepresented it, and I know, Senator Childs, you would not seek to do the latter—states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to produce documents of the kind mentioned in any of subparagraphs (3)(a)(i) to (iii) at the premises at which the employees work or at some other agreed place. . .

If there cannot be an agreement, if the employer says that you have to travel 500 miles to go to see them and the union or other representative does not like that, they can go to the commission and say that this employer is being unreasonable and the commission can demand that documents be produced. But the reference to `agreed place' is not agreed as per anybody else but basically that if it is reasonable there be an agreed place that that is where the records be produced.

That is what we are doing. It is a fair dinkum move and it is a step in the right direction. The situation you have just spent 10 minutes outlining is what has happened under your system. I commend the provision of the bill to the Senate. I ask the Senate to oppose opposition amendments Nos 9 and 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —One issue I would like to quickly highlight here in this discussion about it needing to be by agreement is that if you look at subsection 4 it concludes with the comments:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . require the employer of the employees mentioned in section (2). . .
If you go to subsection 2 it refers to:
. . . employees work who are members of the organisation.

The point I make with respect to the TCFUA and outworkers is that they cannot get access to those workers because they cannot even get access to the distribution point of the work. We will not be able to resolve the problem with archaic clauses like this.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after midnight, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the hour is late and that it has passed midnight, but I do rise on the adjournment debate tonight to speak on a very important issue—that is, the continuing issue of the possibility of an airport at Holsworthy in south western Sydney. For the people of the region around Holsworthy, the Sutherland shire and the south coast, it is approaching midnight for them because it is becoming clearer that this government has every intention of siting Sydney's second airport at Holsworthy.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the current Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) claims that the government's preferred position is Badgerys Creek, it becomes clearer day by day as each announcement is made regarding the current environmental impact study that Holsworthy could well become the site for Sydney's second airport. As I have said on previous occasions when I have spoken on this matter, that will have a devastating impact upon the lives of hundreds of thousands of people in this region.

Recently, on 6 November, the minister released a series of maps setting out the runway options for the two sites being examined—that is, Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy. In the media statement the minister made that day, he indicated that the EIS team had developed two options for both Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy. Further on in the statement he said that the runway locations and alignments on which the designs for the airport will be based are described in the brochure released by the EIS team.

The environmental consultants that have been engaged to undertake the EIS are a firm called Rust PPK Ltd. From what I can gather, they have had limited experience in respect of undertaking work on the development of a major airport. They, along with the Department of Transport and Regional Development, produced a glossy brochure, which I have with me. This brochure was part of the kit released by the minister on 6 November. Contained within that brochure are maps setting out the runway options for the two sites.

I now wish to specifically focus on Holsworthy. There are two sets of options. One is called the northern option, which is close to the suburb of Lucas Heights, where the nuclear reactor is located. It is also close to Sydney's large waste disposal area, at Menai, and it is not very far from large housing suburban areas in Menai, Engadine, Sutherland and a range of other suburbs in that area.

The runways on the northern option are within the boundaries of the Sutherland shire which, as I said, already contains Australia's only nuclear reactor, contains a large waste disposal site that takes the great bulk of Sydney's waste and contains Australia's largest oil refinery. It appears that, if this government has its way, the Sutherland shire will also have visited upon it Sydney's second airport.

There is another option, which is the southern option at the other end of Holsworthy. If it were to be selected, it would have a devastating impact upon the residents of Helensburgh. It would take flights virtually right over the top of the Woronora water catchment area.

What I specifically wanted to draw to the attention of honourable senators this evening is that this brochure, which contains these maps, has some very major errors in it. In particular, the map produced by the EIS team has three of the major suburbs in the wrong locations. The suburbs of Engadine, Loftus and Woronora are shown on this map in the wrong locations. I will seek leave to table this map, which is the map handed out in the minister's kit that day.

One has to ask how it is that, on such an important issue as this—the siting of Sydney's second airport—the company engaged to conduct the EIS and the department which is the proponent of this second airport cannot even get their map correct. It shows one of the major suburbs of the Sutherland shire—Engadine—probably five to 10 kilometres from where it actually is.

You really have to ask the question: how is it that this can occur? It can be nothing short of incompetence on the part of the company and the department. It demonstrates the disregard that this government has for following a proper EIS process—something that it has stated all the way through would be evident in this environmental examination.

If this is the sort of community consultation that we are getting, then one can only say, `God help the community.' If a company cannot even get the map correct, as it currently exists, how can anyone in the community have any faith in a process which is supposed to be about locating Sydney's second airport?

I also wish to take this matter further. As I said at the outset, it is becoming clearer that this government really wants to put this airport at Holsworthy. Last night I attended a public meeting conducted by the Sydney Airport Community Forum in Cronulla, and that meeting was held to enable community consultation with respect to proposals for flight paths out of Mascot airport. Airservices Australia has developed a range of proposed flight paths, and this meeting was held along with a series of meetings in other parts of Sydney to discuss those flight paths.

The Sydney Airport Community Forum is chaired by Mr Joe Hockey, the Liberal member for North Sydney. He chaired the meeting last night. At that meeting he stated that it was his view that Sydney's second airport should be located at Holsworthy. This is the member for North Sydney—who represents an area that probably would be lucky to see one plane flying over it a day—telling the citizens of the southern shire and Holsworthy that they should have Sydney's second airport. He holds a senior position as chairman of the Sydney Airport Community Forum—a body which is supposed to be about consultation.

It appears a decision has virtually already been made. I am here to say tonight, and I will continue to say to this Senate, that the people of south western Sydney and of south eastern Sydney and of southern Sydney do not want another airport in their locality. What they do not want and will not accept is incompetent companies and an incompetent minister and an incompetent department putting out brochures which are supposed to be about community consultation when they cannot even accurately locate on a map the suburbs people currently live in.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Public Sector Motor Vehicles: Wholesale Sales Tax

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 July 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will those pooled Z‐plated motor vehicles which senior public servants drive from work to home to work, due to lack of garaging and security facilities at their place of work, also be subject to wholesale sales tax or will they remain exempt where those employees make a nominal contribution to the upkeep of that motor vehicle.

(2)(a) What is the total expected sales tax revenue to be raised from the Government removing the wholesale tax exemption from certain public sector motor vehicle purchases; and (b) how many cars will be affected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the government's proposed legislation dealing with removing the sales tax exemption for certain government vehicles, pooled Z‐plated motor vehicles which public servants drive from work to home will remain exempt.

The proposed legislation provides that vehicles purchased by governments will be taxable where they are part of a car remuneration package as defined. Vehicles are considered to be part of a car remuneration package if an employee can use the car for private purposes over and above:
(i) travel from work to home and home to work;
(ii) travel incidental to performing duties of employment; and
(iii) travel that is minor, infrequent and irregular.

(2)(a) I refer the Senator to Table 3: Revenue Measures on page 4‐7 of Budget Paper No. 1, 1996‐97, which details estimated additional revenue from this measure for the financial years 1996‐97 to 1999‐2000.

(b) Based on available information about the number of motor vehicles provided by the three tiers of government and used partly or wholly for private use as part of employee's remuneration, it is estimated that around 11,000 vehicles annually may be affected by the measure. Uncertainty, however, remains about how this measure may affect future government purchases and turnover rates of motor vehicles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 17 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answers to question on notice nos 2066 and 2091 (Senate Hansard , 19 June 1995, pp 1380 and 1395) and, in particular, to the former Minister's statement that the extensions are being constructed on ground well above the Hannans Lake water course and the relevant WA Government authorities are aware of the findings of KCGM's [Kalgoorlie Consolidated Gold Mines Pty Ltd] hydro‐geological study:
(1) Can a copy be provided of the complete hydro‐geological study referred to above.
(2) What is the current ground water level in metres below ground level in monitoring bores 1, 2, 3 and 4, as detailed on the tabled map.
(3) Can all the sampling results from the monitoring bores/production seepage recovery bores and interceptor trenches since they were first installed be supplied; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth and the Australian National Railways Commission (AN) do not hold this document. Any request for a copy of the study should be directed to KCGM or the Western Australian Department of Environmental Protection.

(2) AN has advised that since the tabled map was prepared four more monitoring bores have been installed. When measured on 11 October 1996 water levels in the bores ranged from approximately two to 14 metres from the surface.
(3) AN does not possess these results.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the joint defence exercise Operation Tandem Thrust:
(1) Will Federal and State police ministers be introducing new programs to ensure police liaison in each centre to maintain effective communication and practices between civilian and military police.
(2) What role will the Australian Federal Police play in relation to maintaining service/civilian relation and good order for the duration of joint training.
(3) Does the Federal Government have a current policy about prostitution, which was legalised during World War II.
(4) Will the Federal Government require State governments that have not yet decriminalised prostitution to update their law before March 1997.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. There currently exists a very good working relationship between Australian Defence Force (ADF) military police and the respective State and Federal Police forces. Within this working relationship, effective communication is maintained at all levels and on a regular basis. During times of increased military activity, these communications links are maintained on a daily basis. The military police provide detailed briefings on the numbers of activity participants and expected levels of interaction with relevant communities, and will assist and supplement local police as required. I am advised that, due to the size of Operation Tandem Thrust, the ADF is developing specific plans to ensure the necessary liaison and communication with relevant police forces is maintained in an effective and appropriate manner.

(2) I am advised that the exercise will centre largely on the Shoalwater Bay area of Queensland. As the exercise is being conducted in Queensland, responsibility for maintaining service/civilian relations and good order will fall to the Queensland Police Service.

(3) There is considerable variation in the laws of the States with respect to prostitution. However, subject to any international obligations on Australia, such as with respect to child prostitution, it is for the States to determine the content of their own laws in this area.
(4) No. This is a matter for the States. There are no proposals for the Commonwealth to legislate in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 8 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the Budget allocation to the Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC) for the financial years 1995-96 and 1996-97.
(2) Why has the Budget for ERDC been reduced by nearly 50 per cent.
(3) Has ERDC been forced to cancel any contracts or commitments for research as a result of these budget cuts; if yes, please provide details of projects which have been cut, cancelled or deferred.
(4) Is it a fact that ERDC cannot now enter into any new research and development contracts this year because its limited funds are required to meet existing contracts.
(5) Are these cuts in any way related to the Government's recent decision to maintain the diesel fuel rebate to the mining industry.
(6) Can the Minister confirm that the new Australian Cooperative Research Centre for Renewable Energy will lose the $750 000 funding promised by ERDC the financial year 1996-97.

(7) How can the Government claim any commitment to environmentally sound energy production at the recent intergovernmental Greenhouse Gas Conference without an equivalent funding commitment to this area.

(8)(a) What are the total cuts to environmentally sound energy production in the 1996-97 Budget; and (b) what commitments will the Government be making to environmentally-sound energy production in the 1996-97, 1997-98, 1998-99 and 1999-2000 financial years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Budget allocation to the Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC) in 1995-96 was $11.838 million and in 1996-97 was $6.55 million.

(2) ERDC had accumulated unspent funds to a level that the Government considered was in excess of its immediate financial needs. As such, in a one-off saving, which contributed to meeting the Government's fiscal target, the 1996-97 appropriation was reduced.
(3) No. ERDC now has access to adequate funds to allow the Corporation to recommence contract negotiations for projects to which commitments had been made previously.
(4) No. See response to (3) above.
(5) No. See response to (2) above.

(6) The Australian Cooperative Research Centre (CRC) for Renewable Energy will not lose any funds committed to it by the ERDC. In discussions between the CRC and ERDC, it has been agreed that ERDC's commitment to the CRC for 1996-97 will be $375,000, but the remaining $375,000 will be paid later.

(7) The Government recognises the importance of cost-effective alternative energy sources, including significant environmental benefits and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The development of robust cost-effective measures to minimise the environmental impact of energy supply and use is one of the objectives of the White Paper on Sustainable Energy Policy, which is expected to be completed by March 1997.
(8)(a) There are no cuts to environmentally sound energy production in the 1996-97 Budget. For an explanation of the reduction in the 1996‐97 appropriation for ERDC, see the response to (2) above.
(8)(b) Future commitments by ERDC to environmentally sound energy production will largely depend on future appropriation funding, which in turn will be decided within the Budget context.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (1a) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated that `There is no record held of discussions or conversations involving Lieutenant Commander Kelly or Lieutenant Strack in late 1991':

(a) How did the Commanding Officer HMAS Penguin investigate Cason's claims on 29 October 1991 that Lieutenant Commander Kelly and Lieutenant Strack appear to have publicly implied criticism of the Fun Dive Group's knowledge of nitrox and helium diving operations;
(b) What documentation was used to substantiate that that investigation was in accordance with Defence instructions;
(c) Was the investigation thoroughly and competently conducted; and
(d) Could Lieutenant Commander Kelly and Lieutenant Strack have misled or made inaccurate statements during the Commanding Officer HMAS Penguin 's investigation.

(2) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (2) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated that `No record is held of any discussions conducted during the Hazards of Deep Diving Seminar at Prince Henry Hospital on 16 September 1991':

(a) Is the Minister aware that a Mr John Parsell made the following statement regarding the seminar: `During the seminar three doctors who had been involved with mixed gas diving overseas and in the Navy here in Australia. . . All three doctors said it was highly dangerous introducing this type of diving within this State';
(b) Is the Minister aware that this statement was made by Mr Parsell in a letter to the New South Wales Minister for Health on 30 September 1991; and
(c) Is the Minister also aware that Mr Parsell's letter resulted in New South Wales Department of Health Ministerial 91/10134.

(3) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (3a) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `The Royal Australian Navy (RAN) may make available non‐classified technical or scientific information if requested by a consultant, for the compilation of public papers and reports':

Did the RAN provide Dr D Gorman with a copy of HMAS Penguin letter 88/1/2 (DS 321/91) dated 26 September 1991; if so, did the RAN consider that the release of the letter containing highly critical and unsubstantiated statements concerning a private individual was possibly an infringement of that individual's rights; if not, can the RAN explain how Dr D Gorman obtained a copy of the letter.

(4) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (6a, b and c) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated that `The procedures were the use of mixed gas diving to depths down to 200 metres'; using both open circuit and semi‐closed circuit sets':
(a) How did the RAN substantiate `depths down to 200 metres, and
(b) Will the RAN provide copies of the documentation used to substantiate this statement.

(5) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (10b) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `No. Recreational mixed gas diving at that time was not endorsed by major world bodies involved in underwater medicine and diving including. . . and recreational diving bodies such as the Professional Association of Diving Instructors (PADI), the Federation of Australian Underwater Instructors (FAUI), National Association of Underwater Instructors (NAUI)':

Is the Minister aware that the International Association of Nitrox and Technical Divers (IANTD) and American Nitrox Divers International (ANDI) were set up in the United States of America in 1985 and 1988 respectively, as alternatives/competitors to existing recreational diving bodies such as PADI, FAUI and NAUI; if so, why does the RAN make a practice of only recognising certain companies and refusing to acknowledge the existence of, or recognise, their competitors; if not, why was the RAN not keeping current and up‐to‐date with developments in recreational mixed gas diving in Australia and overseas.

(6) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (11a) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `Lieutenant McIntyre did not write his report immediately after Fun Dive's presentation as he attended in a private capacity and therefore did not believe a report would be required. It was not until WorkCover expressed concerns about fun dive's proposal that he wrote a report on what he had heard and seen':
(a) How and when did New South Wales WorkCover receive a copy of HMAS Penguin letter 88/1/2 (DS 321/91) dated 26 September 1991;
(b) Who authorised the release of this official RAN correspondence to the New South Wales Government;
(c) Was Annex A to HMAS Penguin letter 88/1/2 (DS 321/91) dated 26 September 1991 discussed at the meeting between the RAN and New South Wales WorkCover on 30 September 1991; and
(d) Did Annex C to HMAS Penguin letter 88/1/2 (DS 321/91) dated 26 September 1991 come from HMAS Penguin 's own library.

(7) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 2626, paragraph (21b) (Senate Hansard , 1 December 1995, page 4829) which stated `The RAD did not hold any documentation to substantiate the alleged details of the proposed dive by Mr Cason'; and with further reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (13) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `It is not accepted that the Commanding Officer used unsubstantiated information':
(a) Why did the RAN provide professional advice on civilian issues such as recreational mixed gas diving without documentation to substantiate its claims; and
(b) Is this practice permitted by Defence instructions.

(8) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (15a) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `It is considered that the initial discussions would have been general and not considered of a controversial nature and therefore falling within the guidelines for exchange of professional and technical information with other government agencies'; and with further reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (15) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `The details of Lieutenant McIntyre's letter, which were corroborated by discussions with Prince Henry Hospital'.
Why didn't HMAS Penguin seek and obtain approval for discussions with the Prince Henry Hospital Hyperbaric Unit as it did with New South Wales WorkCover on 26 September 1995.

(9) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (16) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `The details of Lieutenant McIntyre's letter, which were corroborated by discussions with prince Henry Hospital, were sufficient to warrant bringing the matter to the attention of WorkCover'; and given that the HMAS Penguin 88/1/2 (DS 321/91) letter was dated 26 September 1991, the authorised meeting between the RAN and New South Wales WorkCover took place on 30th September 1991 and Lieutenant McIntyre's report was dated 3 October 1991.
(a) Is the Minister aware of a telephone conversation between the RAN and Inspector Appel of the New South Wales WorkCover on 20 September 1991;
(b) Is the Minister aware of a telephone conversation between Inspector Riley of the New South Wales WorkCover and Lieutenant Commander Barnes on 23 September 1991; and
(c) Can the Minister explain the validity of his answer considering the apparent conflict of dates and events.

(10) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (4a) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `The RAN policy is that where material is published which contains private opinions of RAN personnel the writing must contain a notice to the effect that the views expressed are private and not the official view of the RAN'; and with further reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (16) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `The unsubstantiated details were not reported as fact to WorkCover'; and given that the Commanding Officer HMAS Penguin stated in his letter 88/1/2 (DS 321/91) to the Flag Officer Naval Support Command dated 26 September 1991 that `WorkCover understands that the most authoritative source of information on mixed gas diving in Australia is the RAN diving school':
(a) Is the Minister aware that Lieutenant McIntyre's report was faxed by HMAS Penguin on 3 October 1991 to Inspector Riley at New South Wales WorkCover;
(b) Is the Minister also aware that Lieutenant McIntyre's report did not contain a statement stating that his views were private and not the official view of the RAN, as required by RAN policy; and
(c) Can the Minister explain the validity of the answer, `The unsubstantiated details were not reported as fact to WorkCover'.

(11) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (15b) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `The reason for the close timing of the meeting and its approval document is not recorded. It is assessed that due to constraints on the availability of personnel to attend the meeting a tentative time was set subject to higher authority approval. This approval was forthcoming':
Does the Minister therefore agree that arrangements were apparently made for representatives of the Prince of Wales Hyperbaric Unit to attend the meeting at HMAS Penguin prior to 30 September 1991.

(12) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (15c) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `This question should be referred to New South Wales WorkCover or New South Wales Department of Health. Flag Officer Naval Support Command approved discussions with WorkCover and these took place'; and given that the New South Wales Minister for Health gave the following answers to questions on notice in the New South Wales Legislative Council on 2 May 1996:
`Yes' to the question ` If officers from the Prince of Wales Hospital Hyperbaric Unit attended the meeting, was it as guests of HMAS Penguin ?'.
`Dr Gleeson and Mr Gibbons' to the question `If so, who stated this?'

`I am informed by the area that the hospital administration is unable to recall the identify of the person who issued the verbal invitation to attend the meeting' to the question `If officers from the Prince of Wales Hospital Hyperbaric Unit attended the meeting, who at HMAS Penguin invited (authorised) them to attend':
(a) Will the Minister now reconsider his answer to question on notice no. 35 (15c) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996);

(b) As Lieutenant Commander Kelly was the senior RAN officer present at the official meeting with New South Wales WorkCover on 30 September 1991 and given that the Flag Officer Naval Support Command letter N5/5/87, dated 30 September 1991, only gave approval for discussions with WorkCover: (i) why did Lieutenant Commander Kelly allow unauthorised representatives from the Prince Henry Hospital Hyperbaric Unit to attend the meeting, and (ii) will disciplinary action be taken against Lieutenant Commander Kelly for failing to strictly comply with the directive of the Flag Officer Naval Support Command; and
(c) Has Lieutenant Commander Kelly misled the RAN about his role in inviting representatives from the Prince Henry Hospital Hyperbaric Unit to attend the meeting at HMAS Penguin on 30 September 1991.

(13) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 35, paragraph (19) (Senate Hansard , 18 June 1996) which stated `The allegations that the RAN had no idea of the developments in mixed gas diving since at least the mid‐1980's, is entirely refuted,': given that the Minister has not answered the actual question asked; will the Minister now answer question on notice no. 35, paragraph (19):

Why did the RAN provide professional advice to the New South Wales WorkCover about recreational mixed gas diving when it had no idea of the developments in recreational mixed gas diving since at least the mid 1980's.

(14) Is the Minister aware that ex‐Lieutenant Cason, having voluntarily withdrawn from MCDO Course 1/75, was posted as Executive Officer HMAS Curlew (a MCDO billet) in late September 1975 while the then Lieutenant Gibbons (a qualified MCDO) was posted to a general seaman billet in HMAS Brisbane in early November 1975, some 6 weeks late.
(15) What is the weight of a Drager FGT in its carrying case, ready for shipping.

(16)(a) Is the Minister aware that the advice received by WorkCover from a number of government and semi‐government organisations regarding the safety or otherwise of recreational mixed gas diving in 1991 was based on `the proposed 200m dive and the way it was proposed to be conducted'; and

(b) Is the Minister aware that there is no documentation held by New South Wales WorkCover, Prince Henry Hospital Hyperbaric Hospital or the RAN that can substantiate statements by Lieutenant McIntyre and HMAS Penguin about an alleged 200m dive by the Fun Dive Group.

(17) Is the Minister aware that the New South Wales Minister for Health has stated in the New South Wales Legislative Council on 6 June 1996 that a search of the records has failed to locate a record of any advice about recreational mixed gas diving given by the Prince Henry Hospital Hyperbaric Unit or any member of the unit to the RAN.

(2) Material to be stored at the site will ultimately be determined, under licence conditions, by the Victorian EPA. It may include all or any of a range of solid prescribed wastes.

(14) Yes. Monthly sampling of the water discharge from the quarry, required under terms of the Victorian EPA licence, generally show:
Total dissolved solids 7000 mg/l

pH 7.5

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Margetts

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 10 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the serious threat which the global trade in toxic wastes poses to people and the environment, has the Government signed and ratified (a) the 1989 Basel Convention; and (b) the 1995 amendment which bans all toxic waste exports from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) to non-OECD countries; if not, when does the Government intend to do so.

(2) What steps are being taken or planned to ensure that the 1995 amendment to the Basel Convention, which bans all toxic waste exports from OECD to non‐OECD countries, is fully enforced in this country.

(3) Will the Government assure that it will strongly resist the attempts by some governments and corporations to redefine hazardous wastes listed under the Basel Convention or to remove from the list any wastes banned for export from OECD to non‐OECD countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Australia ratified the Basel Convention for the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal, which aims to minimise and control transboundary movements of hazardous wastes, on 5 February 1992.

(b) The amendment referred to was adopted by consensus in September 1995 with the support of the then Government. In the Australian explanation of vote following the amendment, it was made clear that Australia would not consider ratifying the ban amendment until the current work on the definition of hazardous wastes was completed to our satisfaction. The amendment can only be sensibly implemented when its scope is clearly defined.

(2) Australia will decide whether to ratify the ban amendment through the newly-established treaty-making process, which includes preparation of a National Interest Analysis. The Government will ensure that there is full and effective consultation on this through the Hazardous Waste Act Policy Reference Group. As indicated above, Australia will only consider ratifying the ban amendment when there has been clarification as to what definitions of hazardous waste are covered by the Convention and the ban amendment.

(3) The Government is committed to full implementation of the Basel Convention as it has been ratified by Australia, and is consulting widely on the correct definition of what is and is not regulated as hazardous waste. An Australian Technical Group has been established to provide technical advice on this issue. Australia is an active participant in the international process of drawing up lists of hazardous wastes under the Basel Convention, and will be guided domestically by the results of that process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to Item number Set 1, of the Commonwealth Records Series A6242, entitled Australian Personnel A-Z, a document which was under control of the department:
(1) Is this a closed document.
(2) Was the document an open document when submitted to the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia; if so, what was the reason for the change in status of the document.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, this is a closed document. The status of the document is, however, under review and it is likely that it will be changed to open access with exceptions.

The series referred to consists of security cards created for Maralinga Range covering the period 1955 to 1967. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy is currently arranging for these records to be transferred to Australian Archives.

The security cards contain personal information such as physical characteristics, full name, date of birth, sometimes a photograph, as well as information on occupation, employer, home address and period of work at Maralinga. Some cards also contain information on civil offences. Australian Archives will determine if any cards are to remain exempt from being placed in open access.

Cards created in the years 1966 and 1967 will not be opened prior to the expiry of the thirty year period. That period expires on 31 December 1996 for cards created in 1966 and 31 December 1997 for cards created in 1967.

(2) Records held by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and by the Australian Archives do not indicate that this series was ever submitted to the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia.
