TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 22 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1)(a) What options and/or obligations does the Minister or any other authority have to enforce compliance with the conditions of export woodchip licences; and (b) what options and/or obligations does the Minister have to prosecute or sanction those responsible when breaches of licence conditions are identified.

(2) With reference to the Brady's Creek Rural Access Program in Tasmania, what steps have been taken to initiate prosecution of all relevant parties for the admitted breaches of woodchip export licence conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1)(a) Under Section 32 of the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations, the Minister may suspend an export licence for up to 28 days if the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe that:
(i) the holder of the licence has not complied with a condition or restriction of the licence, and
(ii) because of that non‐compliance damage, degradation or disruption of the environment has occurred or there is imminent threat of such an occurrence.

The Minister may also revoke a licence if the holder of the licence fails to comply with a condition or restriction of the licence, whether or not the holder of the licence is charged with an offence against section 9 of the Export Control Act in respect of failure to comply with the condition or restriction.
(b) Under Section 9 of the Export Control Act failure to comply with a condition or restriction of a licence is punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding $50,000.

(2) The Rural Access Program is a small grants program which funds a diverse range of projects which assist rural and remote communities to be robust, innovative and self‐sufficient. The objective is to assist rural communities to develop appropriate social or community infrastructure that contributes to the competitiveness of rural industries.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has no record of any funding to Brady's Creek under the Rural Access Program. I therefore cannot see the relevance of the Rural Access Program to the alleged breach of woodchip export licence conditions.

I have asked the Woodchip Export Monitoring Unit to inquire into the alleged breach of woodchip export licence conditions in the Brady's Creek area. Officers of the Unit have visited Tasmania and spoken to relevant parties. I will make a decision as to the appropriate course of action when the Unit's inquiries are complete and a report has been provided to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday, 7 November 1996 (Hansard page 5071), Senator Faulkner asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a series of questions without notice relating to Mr Max Moore‐Wilton's positions with the Victorian Public Transport Corporation and Southern Hydro Pty Ltd.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that since taking up appointment as Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in May l996 Mr Moore-Wilton has attended six Board meetings of Southern Hydro Ltd and five Board meetings of the Public Transport Corporation. The average duration of the Board meetings is approximately 3-3½ hours per meeting. Travelling to and from Board meetings is, where possible, made outside core working hours. In some cases the opportunity has been taken to hold official discussions in Melbourne in conjunction with particular Board meetings. On two occasions both Board meetings have been held on the same day to minimise absence from Canberra. On some occasions Board meeting dates have been changed in order to enable official PM&C commitments to be met.

(2) I am also advised that all direct costs of Mr Moore-Wilton's attendance to the affairs of the Public Transport Corporation and Southern Hydro Ltd involving air fares, accommodation and incidentals have been met by the relevant organisation and have been fully vouched in accordance with the financial regulations of the Victorian Government. No Commonwealth allowances have been claimed for duties related to either organisation.

(3) In accordance with the approval granted prior to his appointment, Mr Moore-Wilton is entitled to allocate up to one working day per month to each of the organisations on the understanding that all official duties relating to his position as Secretary, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, are carried out satisfactorily. In his capacity as Secretary PM&C he is on call at the Government's convenience subject to any official recreation or sick leave requirements. No overtime is payable. I am advised that departmental records show that Mr Moore-Wilton averages an approximately 50-60 hour working week. Any time taken to attend to Public Transport Corporation and Southern Hydro matters falls well within the standard excess hours Mr Moore-Wilton devotes to his official duties in any one month.
Supplementary Question

PARA.TAB: I am further advised as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Moore-Wilton was on duty in Canberra on Monday 9 September.
Mr Moore-Wilton attended a meeting of Commonwealth/State senior officials at the Commonwealth offices in Melbourne on the afternoon of Friday 1 November.

As indicated in the previous answer Mr Moore-Wilton attended six Southern Hydro and five Public Transport Corporation Board meetings over the seven month period since his appointment as Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
